name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: As you know, the first item on today's agenda is the commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon and the legally binding Fundamental Charter.  I would remind honourable Members that, for this occasion, there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no 'blue card' applications will be accepted.  Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for being here with us to celebrate together the tenth anniversary of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the legally binding Charter of Fundamental Rights.  On 1 December, during a beautiful ceremony at the House of European History in the presence of Presidents Ursula von der Leyen, Charles Michel and Christine Lagarde, we wanted to symbolically commemorate this anniversary and greet the beginning of the new institutional cycle of this legislature. Every time we come to Strasbourg and pass through Germany, we cross a border, and we do not notice it, but it is a border that has been bloodied for generations of Europeans since 1870.  It is normal for us to cross it in peace, but this is an achievement, it has been a great achievement, and we should not take it for granted, especially now that we are celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the Bulge, which awarded tens of thousands of victims, young Europeans and marked several generations. It is important to remember that the European project is the only one that has enabled us to build an area of peace, freedom and democracy. These are the values that we must defend every day, working for the European Union and making it stronger and more effective. The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon ten years ago was a great step forward for the European institutions and for the citizens, for our countries and, in particular, for Parliament, for European democracy, because it strengthened the democratic character of our Union, its effectiveness, its transparency and also gave an important role to its citizens. The citizens have a renewed voice with the Treaty of Lisbon. For ten years, Parliament has shared with the Council the adoption of the Union's annual budget and has played an even greater role in the implementation of European policies, but let us not forget that behind the figures, the budget lines and the financial framework there are always people and it is to them that Europe must be able to provide answers.  Thanks to the Treaty of Lisbon, respect for human dignity, freedom, equality, democracy, solidarity and the rule of law have become pillars on which the European Union is founded and have been legally binding on all Member States and institutions for ten years.  Unfortunately, discrimination also continues to affect our countries. The news tirelessly reminds us that violence against women and racism, various forms of intolerance are still humiliating so many European citizens. On the occasion of this anniversary, just a few days before International Day of Human Solidarity, I would like to renew our commitment to a freer and more supportive Europe.  We must continue to think about our future together. We have to walk together.  With great participation in the last elections, our citizens sent us a clear message: they want to contribute more to the European project.  I am convinced that the Conference for the Future of Europe, which we intend to set up in the coming months, is and will be an opportunity that we must not miss. It will be an opportunity to listen to the citizens, to understand their expectations and needs and also their hopes and to enable our democracy to function better.  It will be our duty to put these demands into practice and to complete this task in order to ensure that a Union that is able to face even more effectively the global challenges that lie ahead.  Of course, all this will have to be translated into parliamentary acts and politics, and I believe that our generation can rise to these challenges.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let’s face it – with the Lisbon Treaty, Europe settled after the failure to create a true European constitution.  We were not put down; instead, we learned from our setbacks, we actually made progress thanks to a moment of crisis of the European Union. The Lisbon Treaty created a union out of a community. It gave Europe a political face to speak as one in foreign policy, sitting at the same table of world leaders at NATO and, for example, on the Iran nuclear deal. It strengthens the role of citizens. Co-decision became the central way of legislation in Europe. The European Parliament, our institution, is today a powerful institution, and we added new responsibilities to the European level. The fight against crime, exchange of data, parts of the asylum policy became European issues. This decision has brought Europe more security and safety, and it gave a binding character to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, embedding our European way of life. The Charter tells us what it means to be in a European – social market economy, protection of our environment, rule of law, democracy and freedom.  Europe has never walked in a straight line. Both progress and setbacks shape it. The Lisbon Treaty was a huge step towards a modern way of cooperation among the European Union Member States.  Edmund Burke said ‘a state without the means of some change is without the means for its conservation’. So 10 years after the Lisbon Treaty, let us take the next bold steps now. The upcoming Conference on the Future of Europe is the best opportunity for doing so. As Giscard D’Estaing opened the European Convention, he said ‘let’s dream of Europe’ and I would say let’s dream again.  As our community develops, we must now answer fundamental questions. What are the main areas where the European Union must act in the future? We must carry out a competence check in the European Union. The European Union must focus only on issues where we really have a positive impact on citizens’ daily life. Still, in necessary fields, the EU also needs the right tools to act.  A second point for the future – how can we strengthen the parliamentary democracy at European level? – is still at stake. Because the citizens will only trust Europe when they will hold decision makers accountable. And a third point: how can we strengthen Europe’s role in the world? Standing in the clash between China and the US, Europe can either get lost in the chaos or speak with one voice. In our election campaign as the EPP this year, the listening tour was our starting point. Let’s now write the history of our union together with the people, working side by side with the citizens, national and regional parliaments, with the European Parliament in the central role as the House of the elected representatives.  For the European People’s Party Group we have a clear idea. It will be not about the minimum common denominator, but the best possible sum of our ideas. It will not be a theoretical exercise, but a concrete start for a more democratic Europe and it will not be a technical exercise, but a real debate about what it means to be a European. To create next to our national identity also the European identity. Let this 10-year anniversary be the start of a new European dream. The EPP group is ready to make the difference.  (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ten years after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, this is a good opportunity to take stock. We can say that, in its day, the Treaty of Lisbon was a success of the Portuguese Presidency, with a Socialist Government, at a very delicate time for the Union project. We all recall the trauma of the rejection of the European Constitution by two of our Member States in 2005 and the uncertainty that this generated. However, we must recognise that the work of the Convention in 2002 and 2003 was not in vain and that an important effort was made to retake the Union's challenges. Communities had focused too much on market issues, on market aspects, forgetting that we were able to make a process much more ambitious. We want a European democracy capable of solving the problems of citizens. Issues such as fundamental rights, the Europe of citizenship and also the promoting of social rights needed to be addressed. However, the referendums in France and the Netherlands showed that at least part of the citizenship did not feel involved in the process. Fortunately, many important aspects were included in the Lisbon Treaty and significant progress has been made as a result. On the one hand, the European Union now has legal personality and can adhere to international treaties and conventions. And the role of our house, Parliament, has also been greatly strengthened and citizen participation improved. The Charter of Fundamental Rights is legally binding and the rights of European citizenship have been enhanced. That's enough? Of course not. It is clear that citizens expect more from us, and that is why the Conference on the Future of Europe is an opportunity that we cannot pass by to relaunch the process of integration and make it more democratic, more dynamic and closer to people. Let's not make the mistakes of the past. Citizenship and civil society must be available from the outset; who feel engaged. And we can't make a priori decisions without counting on them. Actually, if there is political will, we can do much more with the Treaty. There's still a tour. For example, consolidate the list head system as well as transnational lists. With political will we could overcome the paralysis of unanimity on issues as important as taxation or foreign policy. And so we would achieve fair taxation and we could overcome situations such as the blockade, for example, of the accession negotiations of North Macedonia and Albania. Nor can we waste a minute on this issue. In reality, the members of the Council know this and, that is why, last week, they found a way to overcome unanimity informally to ensure carbon neutrality by 2050. I hope that it will not be left alone there and that the Council will formally agree to reduce the decision-making areas unanimously. Only in this way can we react in time, with determination to the challenges we face.  We started a new political cycle and it's time to be brave. Europe is not what it was ten years ago. We could talk about climate emergency, gender-based violence, refugees knocking on Europe's doorstep in the hope of having a future, child poverty; so many issues that we have to work on. Let us take this opportunity seriously and work with citizens and civil society to make our Europe stronger and better.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, we are at a very important time for the European Union. As you said in your inaugural address, you know, Mr President, you who have just accepted an extremely important office: ten years is a good age. In France, it is the age when children go from school to college and then to high school, i.e. they are entering a new era, a new life, the one where they separate a little - I was going to say, from the comfort of school - to go towards a situation that is more complicated, that allows them to face the world that comes. The world has changed in ten years; you know, we know that. The challenge we face now is no longer the challenge we faced ten years ago. Climate issues, social issues, issues of migration, population displacement, issues of democracy, the danger to our democracies and sometimes within the Union itself, the rule of law, are new subjects. We need to change the rules. In a changing world, we must also change our own rules, we must do so in a democratic way and with respect for the rule of law; I say this, and I turn to the Council: intergovernmentality must evolve, you must now rely more on the representatives of the citizens, that is, the European Parliament. The Lisbon Treaty made this first step. It is absolutely essential to continue in this process and the Council itself must become more transparent. Then the Commission will be able to rely on two co-legislators. Yes, this has just been explained. The Conference on the Future of Europe, which you referred to in your speech, Madam President, is something essential, again. In ten years, citizens and civil society have entered the public debate. We must now take into account, in an extremely strong way, their expectations. We cannot continue a European Union against or without citizens and civil society. That is why, for this Conference on the Future of Europe, we must not just listen to the citizens, we must involve them in our European project, to ensure that, finally, in the 21st century, there is a European citizenship that is being established, which is not the sum of the 27 citizenships of each member State. There is something higher: it is the general European interest. Madam President, Mr President, I know that Parliament will be there to help you ensure that citizens enter the public debate and civil society as well. Help us, do not let this opportunity pass us by, which is perhaps one of Europe's last chances to be able to get closer to its citizens. Mr President, I will conclude on that, 70 years ago, another event took place. Sir Winston Churchill spoke a few hundred yards from here, at Kléber Square, on a balcony, and he just said these few words, and I would like to quote them because it remains relevant: "The dangers that threaten us are great, but great is also our strength. There is no reason not to succeed in achieving the goal and establishing the structure of this united Europe." This was true 70 years ago, and it is even more true than ever today.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ten years ago, when I had just joined the European Parliament, the Lisbon Treaty was coming into force. Even today, I welcome what I see as a step forward in the construction of this transnational democracy that the European Union is destined to become. Without Lisbon, this Parliament would not have won the right to ratify or not ratify international treaties, it would not have won the right to co-decide, in most European matters, or to audition and appoint the main European leaders, starting with the European Commission. It is also in Lisbon that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has acquired this legally binding character in order to better protect dignity, freedom, equality, solidarity, citizenship and justice for all in the Union. But I also cannot ignore the fact that, for many of our fellow citizens, particularly in France, the Netherlands and Ireland, the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty was seen as a denial of their refusal, a refusal often motivated by the maintenance, at the very heart of the new Treaty, of outrageously neoliberal provisions, for example the central bank's ban on financing public investments, or the sanctification of the freedom of movement of capital, which is elevated to the rank of absolute dogma. It symbolizes in the extreme the imbalance between economic freedoms guaranteed in law and social rights, which are still too often in the status of declarations of intent. Ladies and gentlemen, the Lisbon Treaty allows the European Parliament to reject treaties which it considers to be contrary to the public interest. Let us dare, ladies and gentlemen, to do so by rejecting the free trade treaty with Mercosur, which can only aggravate climate change. The Lisbon Treaty also gives Parliament co-decision on the common agricultural policy, and dare we use this lever to demand a new proposal from the Commission, aligned with the Green Pact for Europe. The Lisbon Treaty opens a door for the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, to circumvent the rule of unanimity in tax matters. Dare to use section 116 to force, or at least propose, a harmonization of corporate taxes. Colleagues, let us be bold, the confidence of the citizens of the Union will be our reward.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we should be here to commemorate the ten years since what was supposed to be an agreement that would relaunch the Union towards a future of growth and prosperity.  Unfortunately, the reality of the situation is that that agreement has failed. And today the EU institutions are weaker. Today, Europe's citizens are weaker and today the European Union is in a deep institutional and political crisis. This is, in my view, the emblem of a failure of a centralizing policy approach that Lisbon wanted to bring, which was not respectful of the prerogatives of the nation states, the prerogatives of the peoples and the differences between european citizens, between the European nations that are seen here as a danger, whereas they must be a value, must be protected.  And Today I see similarities in the approach of that time in making the same mistakes, which, in my opinion, the Council and its predecessor, President Michel, made with regard to the Brexit referendum. At the time, the European institutions demonstrated an aversion to what was a feeling expressed by some peoples and the same mistake was made with Brexit, but the result was different.  If, then, it was possible to subvert the outcome of the Irish referendum, today, despite three years of errors and the wrong approach, in my opinion, committed by the Council, it has not been possible to subvert what was the result and the choice of the British people made in 2016.  My advice is not to make the same mistake. We will now have to negotiate an important agreement with the United Kingdom from January, and the approach that the Council in this House will have to take will not be an approach of wanting to punish the British people for their choice, an approach of trying to subvert a democratic decision made by the British people, but working towards an agreement that will protection our businesses. , which will help our citizens and allow us, even after 2020, to have a fruitful cooperation relationship with the UK.  If Europe, if the European institutions are unable to listen more to the citizens, to take into account the decisions and prerogatives of the Member States, I unfortunately do not know whether we will be able to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon in ten years' time.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Mr President, ten years have elased since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. A treaty that was supposed to be a treaty establishing a Constitution of Europe. This treaty is also one of the reasons for the establishment of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists in the European Parliament, because we defend our European values, and they are patriotism, patriotism, traditions and a free market.  The purpose of this treaty ostensibly meant more transparency, efficiency and ness in positions, but it did lead to division and the decline of democracy. The Treaty of Lisbon has led to excessive centralisation, the seizure of competences by national states and slow and cumbersome decision-making. The bureaucracy, as well as the short-sighted decisions that have been taken, have led to doubts about the work of the institutions by citizens instead of increasing their trust. The Lisbon Treaty is also one of the reasons for Brexit.  Today, there are people in this chamber who continue to allow themselves to attack national states, to challenge the decisions of legitimately elected governments and majorities. Today, there are people in this chamber who want to be punished for their sovereign decisions, such as decisions on migration or the admission of illegal immigrants. Is that why the Lisbon Treaty gave more powers to the European Parliament? I do not want to believe that this is because it damages the credibility of the project called the European Union.  I don't believe in federalisation, I don't believe in the super-state that is currently called the European Union. I don't believe in this project that wants to replace my homeland. I consider the Treaty of Lisbon a mistake because it was a compromise and a serious but wrong attempt at misguided federalisation. We don't need such federalization. We need a Europe of fatherness, a Europe of strong national states to respect, compete and fight for the European Union to move forward.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, it is a strange feeling for us to celebrate the anniversary of the Lisbon Treaty, when it should not have been adopted after the results of the referendums in France, the Netherlands and Ireland. The brutal sacking of Greece confirmed the violently undemocratic nature of the current European institutions and the need to change them profoundly to face the two challenges of our time: climate change and inequality. Annexing the Charter of Fundamental Rights to the Treaty could not be enough to achieve social justice in the European Union because, as the treaties stand, this charter unfortunately remains a hide-and-seek in a soulless market. These treaties are of course not a divine word, we must be able to question them without taboo and assume to say that the new social and ecological green pact cannot be implemented with the necessary power in this current framework. Investment in the ecological transition is constrained by the golden rule that also breaks our social protection systems. We see it in France with the breakdown of our pensions, driven and supported by the European Commission and which provokes a historic mobilization, again this week. We also see this with widespread dumping, which is encouraged by the dogmas of free trade and free competition. The fight against tax evasion is also made impossible or extremely difficult as long as European tax havens, such as Ireland or Luxembourg, have a veto. These treaties are being used as an excuse to refuse to act, they are wasting our time while we have to implement a revolution unprecedented since the post-war period. These outdated rules need to be put back on track and this is an opportunity with the Conference on the Future of Europe. We need stronger democratic control with mandatory consultation of peoples, a right of initiative of Parliament, transparency of debates in the Council, zero tolerance for lobbies. We need founding principles adapted to the times, a green rule protecting natural resources, universal access to the commons, sanctified public services, solidarity protectionism. We need a renewed collective project based on social and fiscal harmonisation from the top, in short a pact of harmonious and sustainable progress, rather than growth and stability, a central bank put at the service of the ecological transition and the new green pact. This is what would be able to reconcile the peoples of Europe with the very idea of European cooperation. This is what would enable us to be able to respond to the emergencies of our time. That is the lesson we should learn on this anniversary of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: – Mr President, if it hadn’t been for the Lisbon Treaty it is quite possible that we would not have Brexit now. So perhaps we should be grateful that you decided to expand your power, you started creating an EU super-state and you ignored nation-states’ democracy and voters. Indeed, the Labour Party at the time didn’t give us a referendum on it, they probably regret that now, and Ireland of course had a referendum, got the wrong results and had to vote again.  Let’s remember what Margaret Thatcher said in her Bruges speech, that Europe shouldn’t be an institutional device to be constantly modified according to some abstract intellectual concept. But that is what it has become. That is what it has become.  However, of course, the Lisbon Treaty did contain Article 50, the means of leaving the EU, and even that was a trap, designed to frustrate an exiting nation until they reversed their decision.  But Britain has voted free of that, thanks to the pressure of Nigel Farage and Brexit party,  which led to a reformed Tory party under Boris Johnson. We will be leaving the EU on 31 January. So by all means, celebrate your Lisbon Treaty, but we will be celebrating the regaining of our sovereignty, independence and democracy as a free country once again.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, when we look at the beginning of this century, something was missing in the European project. The Iron Curtain had already fallen, the European Communities were already a well—established reality, and yet they lacked something. In the words of my predecessor, Jacques Delors, Europe needed a soul. He said: 'It was time to give Europe a soul.' And this is what Lisbon is all about. If you ask the lawyers, they will explain that the Lisbon Treaty has given Europe a single legal personality. Yes, of course this was so, but it is more. The Lisbon Treaty has given Europe a soul, or rather it has rediscovered Europe's true soul: the soul that made us fight against tyranny and defeat it; the soul that brought down the Iron Curtain and reunited our continent. The Lisbon Treaty went to the core of the European identity: democracy, the rule of law, rights and liberties for all. And Lisbon gave center stage to the citizens of Europe. It has brought more power to the European Parliament: the House of the European democracy. It has called national parliaments to the forefront, and it has given to the European citizens the right to call on the Commission to propose legislation. It was a breath of fresh air that went through the European democracy. The European project, yes, was built around the economy, but Europe was always meant to be more than coal and steel; more than the single market. It was always meant to be a union, and with Lisbon, Europe rediscovered this vocation. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last ten years, there have been some terrible winds blowing over our Union. But our Union is like a reed, folding but not breaking. The new challenges do not paralyze it, but help it to move forward, because it draws its strength from the principles and values of its treaties and the European people. Our Union is not a fait accompli, it is a perpetual construction, it is a choice to be renewed every day and this is its beauty and its uniqueness. I am convinced that we have not yet used all the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty. Since 2016, as German Defence Minister, I have contributed to the advancement of permanent structured defence cooperation - this is typical of Europe, to call it that - in short, the defence union. It was already in the treaties, but its potential had not been discovered. The treaty has many more to offer. And to make Europe even more efficient, stronger and more sovereign, it is now up to us to implement the full potential of Lisbon - and we have heard many proposals in this room today. As we celebrate these past ten years, our eyes are now turning to the next ten years. They will be what we want to do with them, they will be what European citizens want to do with them. At the time of Lisbon, one still wondered if Europe could have an anthem or a flag. Over the past ten years, millions of European citizens have taken to the streets, waving the blue flag to the twelve stars, our European flag. And millions of Europeans were excited to discover the notes of the 'Hymn to Joy', the wonderful anthem of our Union. Europe is its citizens. That is why the Conference on the Future of Europe must also be their conference. We need to hear what they have to say, we need to respond to their concerns and hopes. This is the best tribute we can pay to the Treaty of Lisbon, a treaty that has given Europe a soul, a treaty that has created a citizens' Europe, a treaty that has put European citizens back at the heart of the European project. Europe is their choice, it is their future, and Europe is our choice, which we must renew every day in action. Long live Europe! (Applause)

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, it is a pleasure to join you in celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon. This commemoration builds a bridge between Europe's past and Europe's future, and what better place to mark this historic event than the European Parliament, a shining symbol of democracy? Institutions matter. They give legitimacy and ensure continuity, as Jean Monnet rightly said. They matter because they expand our capacity to act. They are a reflection of what we stand for. Let's look back at the moment. The Treaty of Rome confirmed the solidarity that binds Europe, it linked our fates forever. The Treaty of Maastricht recalled the historic importance of the ending of the division of the European continent; it helped heal our wounds. The Treaty of Lisbon made our Charter of Fundamental Rights legally binding. It anchored our Union in a bedrock of shared values and set the stage for the Europe we know today, founded on values and democratic institutions, respected in global affairs and committed to improving the lives of its citizens. We all feel a deep attachment to the fundamental freedoms of liberty, democracy and the rule of law. The Lisbon Treaty shines a light on these core beliefs. The Lisbon Treaty enforced our democracy by strengthening the Parliament's ability to steer a race for our Union. The Lisbon Treaty also gave Europe a more powerful voice in global affairs by synchronising Europe's foreign and security policy. Today we can present a more unified face to the rest of the world and to paraphrase former Swedish Prime Minister, Karl Bildt: I want Europe to be a player, not a plaything. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we look forward to it. There are so many challenges: the climate, the digital agenda, peace, security, defence, the ability to speak together with a strong voice on the international stage. More than ever, I share with you the conviction that we have reason to be confident, reasons to be optimistic. A new institutional cycle is starting, with a Parliament installed - and, I understand it - mobilized, forward-looking, ready to debate, ready to take full responsibility. We know what are the common objectives, the European Commission's programme, in phase - largely - with the Strategic Agenda of the European Council' departure, this prospect of a Conference on the Future of Europe to look at how together we can roll up our sleeves, shoulder to shoulder, move things forward and make progress towards a new European momentum. Ten years after the Lisbon Treaty, which has not yet revealed - I believe - its full potential, let us look to the next ten years with confidence, optimism and hope, without ever forgetting that we must carry this dream, this European ideal, with realism, with pragmatism, but above all with great determination at the service of all European citizens. , whatever their origin, whatever their nationality, whatever their conviction, based on these values so strong that inhabit us and that animate us. These values that make this soul, this european soul supplement.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Mr President, thank you to all those who have spoken, the debate is closed and we will stop for a couple of minutes. (The sitting was suspended at 9.49 a.m.) Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – 10 years ago, we hoped that the Treaty of Lisbon could strengthen the justice of national and linguistic minorities across the EU. We have now understood the disappointing reality that even the most outrageous violations affecting national minorities, such as the malina hedvig case, renationalisations or the use of language and symbols by minorities, have been smeared. The European Commission has not been afraid to invoke its lack of competence or competence in the Member States when there is no political interest in standing up for legal protection and principles. Unfortunately, in many cases, fundamental rights become an instrument of ideological struggle and a tool for measuring double standards. Some members who are not in line and are almost always Christian-Conservative-led members are also objectionable and hold to account issues that are in violation of national sovereignty. At the same time, this rigour disappears towards other Member States, usually left-wing, liberal governments, and the all-indulgent lack of competence remains. The double standard applied by the European Commission and the European Parliament over the last 10 years has damaged the COHERENCE of the Union and its faith in a common Europe. So there is still much work to be done for the future of Europe.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – It is now 10 years since the Treaty of Lisbon, which defines the functioning of the European Union, entered into force. This anniversary is of the utmost importance for the indigenous national and linguistic minority communities in Europe, as this legislation is the first legislation at EU level to require that the European Union is based on the values of respect for the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This was accompanied within a few years by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which clearly states that all discrimination, including discrimination on the basis of belonging to a national minority, is prohibited and that the Union respects cultural, religious and linguistic diversity. After 10 years, however, it has also become clear that the real content of these provisions still awaits. The implementation of the rights of indigenous national and linguistic minorities is difficult in many EU Member States and these principles do not come back from EU legislation. It is therefore very important that the next 10 years are not wasted. The consultation on the future of Europe and the Minority Safe-pack initiative provide a good opportunity and basis for commemorating concrete EU legislation and substantive content that goes beyond the principles on the next anniversary, so that indigenous national and linguistic minorities can finally gain their rights.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Writing. – At a time when the EU is 'celebrating' the 10th anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, peoples can draw valuable conclusions about the unpopular Euro-one way that has been built against them. The CFSP, PESCO, the new intervention funds have strengthened the militarisation of the EU and the aggression of European monopolies, in their fierce confrontation with the other imperialist centres and forces. The Treaty equipped the EU and governments with more barbaric means of promoting unpopular policy: state budget control, Euro six months, long-term memoranda, wage and pension cuts. It has strengthened existing ones and created new mechanisms of repression (Europolice, Euro-Border Guard, Euro-Prosecutor's Office, etc.), has made it more stifling to restrict popular freedoms and rights by strengthening anti-communism, persecution against KK. It turned the Mediterranean into a wet grave for thousands of persecuted refugees and migrants. The only rights actually guaranteed by the so-called 'Charter' are the 'inviolable' ownership of capitalists, the freedom to move capital, the recognition of employers' counter-tribution. The 'Euro-conditions' are nothing but shackles, with which the EU and governments chain workers to the chariot of capital interests. The peoples have the power to free themselves from the tyranny of monopolies, by disengagement from the EU and NATO, by taking power and the economy, by building a Europe of socialism.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – At a time when the EU is 'celebrating' the 10th anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, people can draw valuable conclusions about the unpopular Euro-one way that has been built against them. The CFSP, PESCO, the new intervention funds have strengthened the militarisation of the EU and the aggression of European monopolies, in their fierce confrontation with the other imperialist centres and forces. The Treaty equipped the EU and governments with more barbaric means of promoting unpopular policy: state budget control, Euro six months, long-term memoranda, wage and pension cuts. It has strengthened existing ones and created new mechanisms of repression (Europolice, Euro-Border Guard, Euro-Prosecutor's Office, etc.), has made it more stifling to restrict popular freedoms and rights by strengthening anti-communism, persecution against KK. It turned the Mediterranean into a wet grave for thousands of persecuted refugees and migrants. The only rights actually guaranteed by the so-called 'Charter' are the 'inviolable' ownership of capitalists, the freedom to move capital, the recognition of employers' counter-tribution. The 'Euro-conditions' are nothing but shackles, with which the EU and governments chain workers to the chariot of capital interests. The peoples have the power to free themselves from the tyranny of monopolies, by disengagement from the EU and NATO, by taking power and the economy, by building a Europe of socialism.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: Writing. – The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon 10 years ago was undeniably a significant step towards closer European cooperation. A more democratic institutional functioning, a strengthening of the rights of EU citizens, and a further shift of the EU from mere economic cooperation to European cooperation that puts citizens first. Citizens belonging to indigenous national minorities looked forward to the developments of 10 years ago with confidence. It was hoped that it would also bring about positive changes in the protection of minorities in the EU. With the Treaty of Lisbon, the concept of a national minority has become part of EU primary law. Article 2 of the Treaty mentions respect for the rights of persons belonging to minorities among the values of the Union, and Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits discrimination on grounds of language and national minority belonging. Since then, not much has happened other than the solemn declaration. The eu's enforceability of minority rights still encounters obstacles. So, from the point of view of minority protection, we have lost another decade. Many questions in this area remain unanswered. The Treaty of Lisbon will fulfilled its expectations if there are more positive and concrete steps on the part of the Union to protect minorities. Our task is nothing less than listening to citizens, fulfilling the 10-year promise and as soon as possible creating appropriate EU standards for the protection of indigenous minorities.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council meeting of 12-13 December (2019/2723(RSP)).

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it is for me both a special honour and a privilege to have the opportunity, for the first time since this new institutional cycle, to speak before this European Parliament. I would like to state at the outset my wish, my hope to develop quality inter-institutional cooperation in the service of the European project. I will try to give you a number of information in connection with the European Council that was held last week. The first point is about ambition. The ambition, in a way, to conclude a peace treaty with nature. Climate change is a threat to us and, a few hours after the European Commission announced the Green Pact for Europe - this great ambition of an action plan to win the battle against the climate threat - I am delighted to announce that the European Council has unanimously reached an agreement on the 2050 climate neutrality target. , providing for a longer period of time for a European country to implement this agreement, which was unanimously supported. It is a giant step in the right direction, in the right direction, and it allows us to make progress on what I have described, with other projects, as men and women on the moon project. I think we do need to set a course and an ambition. It's done, through this commitment. I would also like to highlight the fact that the European Council has rightly indicated, in my opinion, that this climate transition must be equitable, socially balanced, and requires financial resources. We have taken note of the announcement by the European Investment Bank of a very high ambition in terms of financing climate-related equities. We have also taken note of this ambition to set up a just transition fund to take into account a form of solidarity which must include the idea that not all European countries have the same starting point, that there are national situations that are not exactly the same. We have also noted the importance, in our view, of having a strategy that respects the choice of the individual Member States, with regard to their energy mix. These are some of the elements linked to this first essential topic for the coming years, the battle for climate change: to transform this challenge, this serious challenge, into an opportunity for more growth, more innovation, and to make Europe a leading continent for the green economy. This is a very strong ambition, and I mean all the mobilization at the outset of the European Council to try to make our political contribution to this objective as well. The next European budget will be very complex: it is a complex and a difficult issue because of the Brexit gap. We know that it means that some countries will have to pay more, and other countries will have to receive more. It means that we have to try to develop a process of negotiation between the leaders, with respect for the role of the European Parliament, based on the treaties.  This debate, the next European budget, is not only an issue of GDP percentage, it is not only an issue of national contribution - and of course it is very visible at the national level - but it is also an important question regarding the content, the priorities and the substance: what do we want to do in the next years? What is the added value we would like to develop in the next few years? It is why another important point will be the right balance we have to find between the classical European policies like agriculture and cohesion on the one hand, and on the other hand the new policies and the new challenges we have to face like migration, climate change and innovation. I think it will be very important to work with European leaders and also to work with Parliament with the support of the Commission, in order to try to take steps in the next few weeks, in the next months. Another important point with the annual budget will be the discussion regarding conditionality. For different countries, conditionality means different things: for some countries we speech about the rule of law; for other countries we speak about migration or about social or tax dumping. Another important topic regarding the European budget will be flexibility. I understand that many countries are in favor of more flexibility, and we will see if it is possible to try to make a compromise on these different issues. Another important point, in relation to the European budget, is of course the question of own resources. I have also noted, with regard to the budget, the strong signals sent by the European Parliament, including on this subject. That means - when we talk about this issue important - that we must look at: for some, it is a question of considering the expansion of the ETS system; for others, it is a matter of leading this debate in relation to digital taxation; for others, it is a question of how plastic waste contributions can be implemented, and other suggestions, as you know, are also mentioned. In terms of procedure, what are the next steps? Clearly, this Council has given me the mandate, as President of the European Council - the Council which has called on the European Commission to continue intensively, actively, bilateral consultations with the Member States - to make progress towards a compromise and to appreciate when we think we are getting closer to a political landing zone, during which we can try to move towards a final decision at the outset of the European Council. I also wished, in close cooperation with the President of the European Parliament, to have the opportunity for exchanges which I would describe as preventive with the European Parliament. A first meeting was held last night with delegations from the European Parliament, in order to take into account the institutional, treaty-based role of the European Parliament in this decision-making process and to express my respect and desire to develop this good cooperation with the European Parliament. We also spoke briefly about the issue of Brexit, briefly because during these two days of the European Council we became aware of the results of this electoral process and we expressed, with great serenity, with great calm, the fact that the European Council is ready to work with the other institutions, under the leadership of Michel Barnier , to whom we reiterated our confidence to continue the negotiation work. Unity, transparency, will be, as was the case yesterday, important keys to ensuring that this negotiation is a success. We, the Commission and the European Council, will follow the process very closely, day after day, week after week. It is certain that the level playing field requirement will be an important compass in the next stages of the negotiation. We also know that there are time constraints and possible procedures to consider around the summer if extensions are to be desired. But it is not our intention today to anticipate this debate. Let us begin first by acting, I hope, as soon as possible, the vote by the British Parliament and the European Parliament, which will also have to vote on the withdrawal agreement, after which we will see, step by step, how this negotiation is carried out in the best interests of Europe, and also by expressing the wish to maintain close cooperation. , very close, with Britain on the various economic, trade, but also security and defence issues, for example. We also had the opportunity to address the issue of this Conference on the Future of Europe. Several have mentioned it in this commemoration session on the Lisbon Treaty, a follow-up that the European Council takes very seriously. And we feel this aspiration of peoples, of citizens to be more mobilized, not to consider that it is in different countries or at the European level to vote once every four years or every five years, and then to be passive spectator of the decisions that concern them. We understand this call for the mobilization of civil society, citizen mobilization, national parliaments, probably, too. I must say, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our initial wish of the European Council to be a loyal and willing actor to cooperate in this process with the European Parliament. But of course, by also stating that for the European Council, it is essential, and you understand it well, to keep its capacity for action in the short and medium term on the strategic agenda. We know the strategic agenda in the short to medium term and we want to maintain that ability to move these extremely important issues forward, which must mobilize us. We also had the opportunity to discuss international relations, paying particular attention to the situation in Turkey. We have not had a very broad debate on Turkey in this Council - we will have the opportunity next year to open more strategic debates on the geopolitical and international level - but we have unambiguously reaffirmed our perfect solidarity with Greece and cyprus, given the recent developments you are experiencing. Finally, a word on the 2020 agenda. I also wished to present to the European Council colleagues a proposal for a working method, a proposal for a strategic agenda for next year, to identify the issues we will discuss next year, which correspond to the priorities of the European Council. Climate, as you have understood, will remain a central item on the political agenda of the European Council, in part as part of the process of implementing the European Green Pact. The digital agenda will also be an important theme. In the spring there should be a summit dedicated mainly to him - because, a few years after Tallinn and the broad implementation of the guidelines that were taken there, it is important to say clearly that we also have an ambition: big data, artificial intelligence, the deployment of 5G. On all these subjects, how can we be a useful player, a positive player too, at the start of the European Council? The issue of migration, of course, will also be a topic that will return to the European Council table next year and, of course, also security and defence issues, which are extremely essential. They are, in my view, linked to Europe's ability to speak with a strong voice at the international level, to promote our values, our interests and to ensure that this ability to be a positive forward-looking player, at a time when the world is changing a lot, at a time when benchmarks are being shaken. This ability for Europe to be a factor and an actor of stability, peace and prosperity to promote cooperation, to promote multilateralism, is an extremely important point. In particular, we will have the opportunity to strategically prepare several international meetings at the European Council. We will have next year different important summits with other countries in the world and other regions in the world. First of all, Africa: Africa is, in my opinion, a very important challenge for the future of Europe. I hope it will be possible in the next weeks and months with the European Commission to develop a good strategic partnership, a good preparation in order to deliver concrete results. Another important summit we will have next year is China. We spoke about climate change: this is one of the important topics we have to discuss with this important country, and in this regard we will also have the opportunity to work very hard in order to try to be efficient and to try to deliver more in order to try to get more results and to promote also our common interests regarding our strategic relationships with other actors in the world. Ladies and gentlemen, I conclude these few words by saying this: we are at the beginning of a new institutional cycle. I deeply believe that this institutional cycle that is opening up is an exceptional window of opportunity for the future of the European project. We are a little more than sixty years after the Treaty of Rome, after the founding fathers, after the mobilization of visionary Europeans: Helmut Kohl, François Mitterrand, who dreamed of free movement and the Schengen area, who dreamed of the common currency, the euro, who fought to advance mutual understanding, prosperity and stability. Our political generation - the one you represent in this Parliament, the one that is present at the start of the Commission or in the European Council - our political generation has an appointment with the future of the European project. There are three words that drive me as President of the European Council. Ambition: ambition for European citizens, ambition to carry this optimistic vision, this vision for the future. Confidence: working on a daily basis to strengthen trust between the institutions, trust within the institutions, but above all trust between the European peoples, confidence in our project, confidence in our European values. And then common sense, pragmatism, realism: keep both feet anchored in reality, as close as possible to the expectations of our fellow citizens who have big dreams, who have high hopes. This Assembly, your assembly, is the vibrant heart of the European project, because you represent, through your direct election, the aspirations, dreams, hopes, sometimes even the angers of the European peoples. I extend my hand and hope that together we can play a useful role for the future of the European project. (Applause)

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable of members, let me first congratulate President Charles Michel on chairing his first Council. It was quite an impressive start of the mandate.  Indeed one week ago, we discussed in the Parliament the European Green Deal. The day after I brought the same proposal to the European Council and the Council has endorsed the goal to make our continent climate neutral by 2050. We have explained to the leaders the core of our proposal and that is to transform our continent’s growth strategy. For too long, global growth has been based on predatory ideas. Humanity took away resources from the environment, and in exchange produced waste and pollution. This has to change and I am convinced this can change. With the European Green Deal we aim at a growth model that gives back to our planet more than it takes away from it. In fact, I am convinced that leadership on environmental protection and a sound, a strong industrial base are just two sides of the same coin. To support this kind of clean innovation, of course we will need a far—reaching investment in education, a far—reaching investment in skills development. But this investment in education and skills development has always been at the core of our European social market economy. So I’m convinced that this principle, which I call competitive sustainability, must be our principal for the future of the social market economy in Europe. Honourable members, all Member States have different starting points, and special problems to tackle, and I want to give you some examples.  Poland indeed, as President Michel said, will have to transform large coal mining regions, actually as does eastern Germany. So at the European Council, Poland has asked for more time to have a closer look at our proposal for the Just Transition Fund. I’m very keen on working with the Member States on this, and we have already started discussing how to support people and regions and companies that indeed have a longer way to come. Other Member States have different issues. Portugal for example. Portugal is one of the countries most affected by climate change: loss of coast; hurricanes; floods; horrible forest fires have taken already a very high toll. Last year 60 people lost their lives in the fires. Portugal started its clean transition already in 2005 and has invested significantly since then. It will close its last coal mine already in 2023. It already has a surplus in renewable energies, and together with the Dutch government, Portugal is now working on green hydrogen energy. So the question for Portugal is how to transform and transport its renewable energy through Spain, through France, to the other countries that need this renewable energy. From the Portuguese perspective, the European Green deal is about energy infrastructure, is about inter-connectivities and is about an adaptation to climate change. The third example is in Sweden. Steel companies are working on carbon free steel production. It sounds surreal, but it’s carbon free steel production and they are confident they can get there in a matter of a few years. But for that they need the reassurance that they will not face unfair competition from abroad. They want steel production to be sustainable for the environment and they want to remain competitive on the global steel market, and this is the essence of competitive sustainability. Indeed, many Member States during the Council were asking for the carbon border mechanism. We’re working on it, so that it can protect our businesses, it can protect the environment and respect WTO rules. Honourable Members, we started our work on the European Green Deal five months ago in this very same hemicycle. In the coming weeks and months, we will flesh out our plan. The Council has endorsed the European Green Deal. Your resolution will give it an even greater momentum. The task ahead of us is tremendous, but if we are together as three institutions, we will win that battle. That is a difficult one, a huge task and we have seen last week how much power is behind us if the three institutions work together. Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, nos ambitions européennes ont besoin de ressources adéquates pour se réaliser. C’est là le cœur de notre discussion pour le prochain budget européen. Nous convenons tous que la proposition actuelle est encore loin de cet objectif. La Commission soutiendra pleinement le président du Conseil européen, Charles Michel, dans ses efforts pour dégager un consensus équilibré, équitable et ambitieux. Je voudrais remercier le président du Parlement européen, David Sassoli, d’avoir défendu d’une voix forte, très forte, un budget approprié pendant la réunion du Conseil. Merci beaucoup, David, pour cela. Il est nécessaire d’être cohérent avec nos ambitions et nos engagements. Il y a l’agenda stratégique du Conseil, il y a les orientations politiques de la Commission. Les deux propositions sont fortement congruentes, mais si nous voulons des résultats à la hauteur de nos ambitions, il nous faut des ressources suffisantes. Et si le budget est trop limité, il n’y a qu’une seule solution: il faut discuter de nouvelles ressources propres pour l’Union européenne. Merci, Charles Michel, d’avoir mentionné maintenant l’ETS, l’emissions trading system. Cet ETS grandit, c’est à dire que cela pourrait être une source de nouvelles ressources propres de l’Union européenne. Meine Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! Auf dem Eurozonen-Gipfel haben wir über die internationale Rolle des Euro gesprochen. Der Euro ist ein wesentliches Instrument der Souveränität Europas in der Welt, aber wir verkaufen unseren Euro unter Wert. Es liegt an uns – wir haben es in unserer Hand. Wir wollen die gemeinsame Währung. Wir profitieren vom gemeinsamen Markt. Der Euro ist der stärkste Ausdruck der Zusammenarbeit und der Gemeinschaft, den wir haben. Aber wir müssen auch bereit sein, die strukturellen Voraussetzungen für eine gemeinsame Währung zu schaffen, das heißt, aufeinander zuzugehen bei den Themen, die wir reformieren wollen. Die Kapitalmarktunion muss vollendet werden. Unternehmen – und vor allen Dingen kleine und mittlere Unternehmen – müssen endlich überall auf dem gemeinsamen Markt Zugang zu Kapital haben und damit von der grenzüberschreitenden Wertschöpfungskette auch tatsächlich profitieren. Dafür haben wir ja den gemeinsamen Markt. Aber auch die Bankenunion muss vollendet werden. Es muss doch möglich sein, dass wir einen überlappenden Prozess haben, dass einerseits die nationalen Bankenrisiken reduziert werden und andererseits eine gemeinsame Einlagensicherung aufgebaut wird. Wir brauchen doch nicht auf die nächste Krise zu warten, um dann unter Druck endlich die Resilienz unserer Währungs- und Wirtschaftsunion zu festigen.  Auf dem Eurozonen-Gipfel war sehr erfreulich: die Entwicklung des sogenannten BICC (Budgetary Instrument for Convergence and Competitiveness) – long one – macht erhebliche Fortschritte. Die Hauptmerkmale sind vereinbart, die politische Einigung wird jetzt in Rechtsvorschriften umgesetzt. Das Instrument wird die Arbeitsweise der Euro-Gruppe grundlegend verändern. Es wird die Konvergenz über strukturelle Reformen verbessern. Natürlich muss es noch mit ausreichenden Finanzmitteln unterlegt werden. Was jetzt noch fehlt, ist das Stabilisierungsinstrument, und dazu arbeitet die Kommission an SURE, die Abkürzung für Skills Upgrading Reinsurance Element, das ist ein Stabilisierungsmechanismus, der vor allen Dingen bei asymmetrischen, externen Schocks die Stabilisierung herstellen soll, das heißt: Facharbeit schützen, Unternehmen in der Krise schützen – und ich meine, wenn ich von Krise spreche, eine äußere Krise, die kommt – und gleichzeitig die Weiterbildung stärken. Finally, honourable Members, one word on Brexit. With the clear victory of the Conservatives and Boris Johnson, our assumption is now indeed that the Withdrawal Agreement will be ratified by the end of January. And by saying that, if I look around in this hemicycle and I look at our very brave ‘remain’ MEPs, (Mixed reactions) I can only say, I’m sorry. We will miss you. We will miss you. Thank you for your courage. Thank you for having been at our side (Applause) We’ll never miss those who scream and yell. (Applause and shouting) And now, thank God, without you we are constructing our future partnership with the UK. Our new relationship should be as close as possible for the sake of our businesses, for the sake of our students, and of so many Europeans who stretch their lives across the Channel. This relationship will be clearly different from today’s. The UK will be a third country. Council has tasked that to the Commission, to lead the next phase of negotiation, and I want to pay tribute to Michel Barnier, who has earned everyone’s trust through the years. Thank you very much Michel for you dedication. (Applause) The timetable ahead of us is extremely challenging, it will end by December 2020, it leaves us very little time. In case we cannot conclude an agreement by the end of 2020, we will face again a cliff-edge situation and this would clearly harm our interest, but it will impact more the UK than us, as the European Union will continue benefiting from its single market, its customs union, and the 1 700 international agreements we signed with our partners, but it is clearly not in our interest. We will organise these negotiations to make the most out of the short period. On 1 February we will be ready to propose a mandate for the negotiations. The United Kingdom indeed will become a third country. But at the very end – I hope – for the sake of the European people and the sake of the British people, that we will have an unprecedented partnership. This is not the end of something, it is the beginning of new relations between neighbours, and I want us to become good neighbours with our friends in the United Kingdom. Long live Europe. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr. President! Mr Charles Michel, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work Welcome to the European Parliament! For the first time in the new role here in this House. We appreciate you as a convinced European, as a bridge builder. Even from your Belgian origin, this is due to the nature of politics, building bridges, coexistence. Therefore welcome and good luck! You need good luck with the tasks that are before you, because the European Council has become increasingly a blocked institution in recent years. Looking at the outcome of the European Council last week, the great success of 2050 – the phase-out of climate gases – is a great success, thank you for that. But in many other areas we again have no results. For example, when it comes to paying the costs of the climate phase-out, we are in the medium-term financial perspective. Has the European Council not had more discussions on this? Only the Finnish Presidency has presented the result. The question was not even discussed. Outside, entrepreneurs, researchers, students, mayors, farmers expect security are waiting, and the European Council does not even discuss the issue of MFF, which is why you will have a great responsibility in this task, which is to create clarity, to initiate debates and also to implement it. Specifically, with regard to the MFF, I would like to inform you that the Finnish Presidency's proposal is a pure provocation for us in the European Parliament. It is not debatable what the Finnish Presidency has put forward on the matter. It does not reflect the necessary investments that we need in the future of Europe. We also hope that we will finally move away from pure percentage discussions and towards the topics, the tasks, the content. That we are talking about issues and not just about figures, and above all, we need to move away from the net and gross contributor debate. If my own country, Germany, gets a proper external border protection in Greece and Italy financed through the European Union, then that is an advantage for Germany, but not a net contributor/gross contributor debate. We must move away from this perspective towards the European way of thinking. Secondly, I would ask you to have the courage to debate in the Council in the future. Over the last five years, we have had questions which have moved us on the subject of rule of law here in the European Parliament. In Poland, in Hungary, in the Czech Republic, in Romania, with the previous government, people took to the streets, had concerns about the future, and these debates, which have driven people around, were unfortunately hardly addressed in the European Council. This week we had the discussion here in the European Parliament on Malta. A journalist has been murdered for doing her job, for investigating the corruption of the state elites. And the Prime Minister has resigned because he has taken responsibility. So we obviously have contacts between politics and organised crime, and a journalist has been murdered for that reason. However, these issues do not play a role in the European Council. They are not discussed, even though they are the most fundamental issues for the European model of life. That is why I ask you to have courage, put these issues on the agenda – Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland. The Heads of State or Heads of Government of the European Union must have the courage to discuss these issues among themselves. I would also like to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats now welcome the clarity of Brexit. We now have clear negotiating partners, a strong mandate for Boris Johnson. We can give our blessing in the European Parliament. I would also like to express my thanks to Guy Verhofstadt for his work as Parliament's Brexit negotiator. We can now conclude as a Parliament because our objectives have been implemented and fulfilled in this Treaty, and in the further steps that are now to be taken, it must be made clear that the further partnership is designed for friendship, for cooperation. We all want close cooperation, especially the 50%, about half of the British who want the partnership, are strong in our thoughts. But one thing must be clear: a country outside the European Union cannot have the same standards as someone who is in the European Union. And it must also be clear that anyone who wants access to the market must accept our market rules. This applies to the City of London, and also to agricultural products. Everyone must respect our standards and it will be our benchmark seofto for assessing future outcomes in the talks in which the European Parliament plays a central role. Brexit is a historic mistake, but we now want to implement it in partnership and perhaps also develop it into a model of how we deal with our neighbourhood in the future. Finally, dear Charles Michel, one more request: the penultimate European Council has unfortunately produced a disaster for the Western Balkans. With the cancellation of the opening of negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania, there has been a great deal of frustration and disappointment in the region, and therefore the urgent request: if you come back to the European Parliament next time, after the next European Council, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have the request that the European Council then give the green light to the enlargement talks with these two countries. We must reach out to the Western Balkans, otherwise there will be more instability there.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, dear Michel, on behalf of the Social Democratic Group I welcome you to this Parliament and wish you every success, hoping that your Presidency will have strong leadership in meeting Europe's challenges and challenges. It's what we need: strong leadership and being courageous in decision-making. We have a responsibility to reach the commitments made, including each and every discussion held within the Council. If we aspire to build a greener, social and inclusive Europe, we need financial resources that live up to our ambition. And we also need a strong budgetary framework to deal with a possible economic crisis, and to ensure the security of our citizens within the framework of a common foreign and security policy. We welcome the fact that the European Council has agreed in the last conclusions on the objective of achieving climate neutrality by 2050, despite resistance from some Member State. We need to address this issue when we debate the future of the Union: the need to change the rule of unanimity, because only in this way will we be able to meet the challenges ahead. Although the Council's conclusions go in the right direction, the multiannual financial framework was the elephant in the room. The cuts proposed by the Council are totally unacceptable. Our group will prevent this proposal from becoming the budgetary framework that the Union needs for the next period. The Council's current proposal is totally unrealistic: less budget for cohesion, less budget for agriculture, less budget to connect Europe and border management, just to mention some of the headings referred to. The proposal also provides insufficient funding for research policy and for the fulfilment of climate objectives. More seriously, he does not even mention the Fair Transition Fund, the European Green Pact and the Children's Guarantee. I have said it on previous occasions and I repeat it again now: it is impossible to do more with less. If we want no one to be left behind on this path we are embarking on, the Council must bet on a strong budgetary framework. Yes, the Union budget will play a key role, but it will also have to be supplemented by additional own resources and more investment at national level. We therefore call for the incorporation of the golden rule into the Stability and Growth Pact to exclude sustainable investment from European tax rules. This reform would boost green investment and the creation of quality jobs. That is why we need the commitment to include the social pillar in the European Semester not be a mere symbolic exercise. We are committed to incorporating social conditionality to link the Structural Funds with the fulfilment of the social pillar. Mr Michel, if we are to succeed in our mandate, we need empathy and pedagogy. Only by exercising empathy between the Member States and pedagogy before our citizens can we understand the great benefits of having a stronger Union. And I conclude, with regard to Brexit, I will be allowed to use this speech today to convey a clear message of recognition and thanks to the British MEPs who for 46 years have written the history of our European democracy. We were talking about the tenth anniversary of the Lisbon Treaty. Our colleague Richard Corbett was the rapporteur of this Parliament on the report of the Lisbon Treaty. You deserve our respect, you deserve our recognition, you deserve our personal affection too. Be very clear: there is one thing that no one will be able to take away from you, and it is the pride of having been part of the history of the European project.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, dear Charles, first of all, welcome to the European Parliament and congratulate you on taking office. We are putting a lot of confidence and a lot of hope into the start of this new mandate because we need a real partner in the European Council who brings European themes and topics so that we can move forward. The message from the citizens in the last European elections was very clear. It is now up to us to implement it and I am sure that you, with your vision, your negotiating ability, will bring this new blood, this new wind that we need to be able to move forward together. This first European Council that you chaired brought good news, with the climate commitment by 2050. But we feel that in the Council there are Member States that are still on their positions and that the determination is not yet sufficient to enable us to move forward and implement this objective. It is very good to have objectives, it is already a step forward, but we now need to be able to implement them. And there is an important task for the Commission, which is to come up with proposals. We need to give the courage of the Member States to take this responsibility, to take this step forward, and it is clear that we must turn this climate project into an opportunity and that the Member States - even if they start from different starting points - must seize that this fight against climate change is a real opportunity. For this to be very clear, this must be reflected within the budgetary perspectives of the multi-year financial framework, which must be a real instrument to be able to deliver results on the climate project, but also on digital transformation and all other objectives. On how the multi-year financial framework can be a real European instrument, and not just a negotiation between Member States on the theme 'how much some earn and how many others lose', there is still work to be done. In my opinion, this will be the only way to get a decision on the budgetary outlook: to understand that this multi-year financial framework is in fact an instrument to implement our political ambitions, and not just a place of negotiation and haggling between who wins and who loses. On the budget outlook, in our view, it would be a mistake to look at things from the point of view of the allocation of available resources between conventional, old policies and new priorities, since we need to modernise the traditional policies, namely the Common Agricultural Policy and cohesion policy, so that these two policies can contribute to the achievement of the ambitions we currently have. rather than weakening them. That is where Parliament will go. We also resolutely support a strong European budget, not only thanks to the contribution of the Member States, but also based on own resources, on which we must make very clear progress, because otherwise we will not stop debating the European budget, which is entirely dependent on the Member States engaged in negotiating between who wins and who loses. That is why own resources are a first step towards a real European budget, built around European perspectives and objectives.  One last word on Brexit. We regret the results of the election in the UK - but now, at least, we have more clarity about what will happen, and Parliament will assume its responsibility. But I would also like to use this opportunity to thank our colleagues for their belief in this European project. They transmitted a very clear message to the British people that this Brexit is not the end of our story together: we will remain partners, and we will remain confident that all the British who really believe in a European project will stay together with us, and we will find the right way to collaborate and work together.  Thank you to Michel Barnier and thank you to Guy Verhofstadt for what they did for these negotiations. We still have things to do in order to have a strong agreement with our neighbors.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, while the heads of state and government were meeting in Brussels last week, the COP 25 in Madrid was stalling. So maybe, next year, it would be a good idea if the heads of state went to Glasgow – to the COP26 – to show the importance that they give to the topic of climate protection (if indeed they do). In light of the disappointing outcome of Madrid, it’s good to see that there was an agreement on climate neutrality in 2050 at the summit. This is a very important step, but of course it can only be one step forward: 2050 is quite late, and setting targets is only half the battle. What really matters is less the targets set for later on – they are important sure – but rather the actions you take today in order to achieve those targets. And for those concrete actions, the discussion on the long-term budget – the MFF – is the perfect opportunity, because the EU budget needs to support the climate targets and not undermine them. Right now, the proposals that we have on the table are not doing that job; they don’t match the climate talk. There are still too many harmful subsidies that are being dished out; too little going into the protection of climate and biodiversity.  So I hope Member States will start to walk the walk when it comes to climate and budget. It was disappointing to see that the Polish Government would isolate itself by not agreeing to the target. Let’s not forget that 70% of the Poles themselves are supporting that target, so I really hope the Polish Government will change its my mind: the later you start the transition the harder it will get, and the climate crisis does not stop at any one country’s border.  Brexit is – and remains – a tragedy, but this is not the end. We will never give up on our British friends. We will never forget them, and who knows: one day we might be able to say ‘welcome back, UK; welcome home’.  (Applause)

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, many Belgians – and many Flemings in particular – remember the way Nigel Farage welcomed the previous Belgian President of the Council here and the wording in which he did so. I thank him again for that. There is now a second Belgian President here and I would like to spoil the fun with which you all welcome and applaud him here. You've all listened to Mr. Macron. It, as you know, has jettisoned the Spitzen candidate process and replaced it with candidates whose common characteristic was mainly the knowledge of the French language. He has therefore appointed a French-speaking of Renew as President of the Council. As with the previous President, you have probably all thought: Belgium is a complicated country, let us take the Belgian Prime Minister, that will be a good manager of the European Union. But that too is a mistake. I am here to tell you that Belgium is one of the most lamentable Member States of the European Union. Mr Michel has submitted a budget of 11 billion debt by 2020, a deficit between Greece and Italy. So don't be under the illusion that Belgium is well governed. The citizens of Belgium do not think so, because Belgium has been left in a political chaos that has been going on for more than a year. We celebrated 365 days of the Belgian government crisis yesterday. No one from the Belgian political elite knows where the next Belgian government should come from. We have had elections, which are now being replaced by the analysis that there should actually be new elections. No one knows what needs to be done. Meanwhile, the remnants of the Michel government rule: 38 MPs out of 150. So Belgium is a minority regime that is actually governed in an almost dictatorial way.
