The only consolation you have is that you have appointed a multilateralist, an almost blindly worshipper of the European Union and of the ever closer Union. Bravo, congratulations. You have also appointed someone who is a staunch supporter of mass immigration. Because he has deliberately dropped his government on the possibility for himself to go to Marrakesh and sign the UN immigration pact there. So, my dear colleagues, speaking as a citizen living in Belgium, I can assure you that your so-called President of the Council is not a unifier, but rather a source and a warning bell of political chaos. We, of the ID Group, are in favour of a European cooperation but firmly against your ever-closer union state. Thus, the ID Group hopes that Charles Michel will be as disastrous for your European Union as he was for Belgium.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Council discussed many important issues last week, but may I just focus for a moment on Brexit. Indeed, the Conservatives won a historic victory last Thursday. 365 Conservative members of parliament were elected, giving an 80 seat majority over all other parties. Above all, this was a huge vote of confidence in Boris Johnson as Prime Minister and a mandate to get Brexit done. It was also a total rejection of the command socialism being offered by the main opposition party. I hope there will no longer be a willingness in the EU institutions to be taken in by a few people waving blue flags or of past political leaders coming to Brussels to peddle false messages to what became an echo chamber of self-delusion. The United Kingdom and the European Union will move ahead quickly in developing that ambitious, broad, flexible partnership, with a comprehensive free trade agreement at its core and many other areas of cooperation, so that we can together build a new partnership of friends and sovereign equals in tackling the great threats and challenges that affect us all. This is the great project for 2020, fuelled by the warmth expressed by the British Prime Minister for the other nations of Europe, and I thank President von der Leyen for her positive remarks and, indeed, the positive remarks made by a number of other colleagues. It’s in all our interests now to expedite the Withdrawal Agreement. It will be voted on in the House of Commons this week so that we can leave without further difficulty on 31 January. Provided there is efficiency, good faith and goodwill, we can then make rapid progress with negotiations on our future relationship so that a good free trade agreement and other arrangements can come into force by the end of 2020. This must be our joint aim. I know Michel Barnier approaches his task with this positive spirit and is ready to do all that is necessary to meet the timelines, and I trust that this House will be helpful in the process, and I wish you will a very happy Christmas.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Michel, I welcome you to the European Parliament since it is your first presence here. My group is very different from your policy, but I confess that the harsh attack you are under from the far right here in the European Parliament raises the bar of expectations that we have from you. And I would like to say that the first problem you have to solve is for the Council to stop blocking things that the European Parliament is asking for, things that the times demand and things - some of them at least - that the Commission also supports and which stop in the Council.  I start with a topic that is of great interest to our team, but it concerns me a lot as a Greek. It is not enough, Mr Michel, to condemn the aggression of the Erdoğan regime, which threatens peace and stability in the Mediterranean and the Aegean, which threatens Cyprus and Greece and which threatens to set fire to a sensitive area. It's not enough to verbally condemn! Sanctions are required. The Council decided to impose sanctions in June and October, but must activate them. So I would like you to tell me why you are not triggering these sanctions. Secondly, in order to achieve the objectives that you and Mrs von der Leyen have presented, on climate change, on social cohesion, on agricultural policy, on technological renewal, money is needed. And the European Parliament, by a large majority, has come up with a proposal that says that, in order to achieve these objectives, we need at least 1.3% of European GDP. My group would like more ambitious targets for the Social Agenda, for the climate, but at least. That is what the European Parliament is proposing by a large majority. So, what's going on? The Council, through the Finnish Presidency, is coming and proposes, in relation to the Proposals of the European Parliament, 13% cuts in regional development and cohesion, 27% in investment for people and social cohesion, 25% for LIFE, for climate, 30% in the Horizon programme, 48% in the Erasmus programme, 35% in the Connecting Europe programme. At the same time, if we compare your proposals for the new multiannual budget with the previous one, you propose a 132% increase for migration and border management and 650% for militarisation, defence and security. Which citizen can you convince with this policy? How long are you going to delay and postpone what's needed? Otherwise, all the fine things that have been said, both by Mrs von der Leyen and by you, on climate-neutral policy, on the social agenda, on farmers, on social cohesion, will remain words. That's what I'd like answers to your secondology.

name: Michael HEAVER
text: – Mr President, I stand today as a very proud Englishman – proud of Nigel Farage for battling for Brexit successfully after so many years, proud of my Brexit Party colleagues for steadfastly defending British democracy. And most of all, proud of the British people who, when asked at the general election, yet again, gave a very strong backing to leave the European Union. I know some of you. You’ve been lied to. You were spun a myth that the British people had changed their mind. No, we have not. And now we seek to usher in a fresh chapter in the history of our great nation as we take back control of our borders, our money, our laws – free to forge global trade deals and govern our own country without restriction. The future is bright for Brexit Britain. Now is our time. Prime Minister Boris Johnson, please do not let us down. It is time finally to take back control.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, it would be good to hear from you one day. Where is your political space? Where will you go when you leave the Parliament? Since Thursday night, we have clarity with regard to the withdrawal of the UK. Our British friends will leave the EU in an orderly manner at the end of January and become a third country. This is once again a moment to repeat: we respect but we regret. I’m sure existing friendships will last. The European Parliament is prepared to finalise its part of the withdrawal process in time for the deadline. As much as I am sad to see our friends leave, we must now look to the future, and we take note of the strategic choice of the UK’s Prime Minister to limit the transition period by domestic legislation. We take this choice seriously, but of course we regret that, through this act, a provision in the agreement we jointly negotiated and agreed will be blocked. So much for negotiating in good faith. The EU has prepared extensively for the task ahead, and we are looking forward to constructive negotiations, as we want to conclude an ambitious agreement. Our mandate for the negotiations will be based on the political declarations jointly agreed between the EU and the UK, and I hope that, with this declaration, we will be taken to the most unprecedentedly deep and diversified agreement we ever had with a third country, hopefully allowing us to tackle global challenges together while respecting European level-playing-field measures and the interests of the Union. Let me finish by saying that we must not forget that, in parallel to the negotiations, this House will spare no effort to ensure correct and full implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and will monitor closely the enforcement of citizens’ rights.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: There was a blue-card request from Ms Grapini. However, I am going to at this point say that we cannot take blue cards. I am under pressure to finish. Ms Grapini, I’m sorry, there are no blue cards, we are running out of time, so therefore I’d ask you to be very clear and stick to your time. We may even have a problem with catch-the-eye, but not for now.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have heard important words here from the President-in-Office of the Council, particularly on the Green Deal.  We welcome the fact that the Council has committed itself in its conclusions, albeit with Poland's opposition, to supporting the objective of achieving climate neutrality by 2050 in line with the Paris Agreements.  We are truly convinced of the historic turning point of the Green Deal not only for environmental protection, but also for economic growth, competitiveness and the quality of life in Europe. Meanwhile, the Green Deal has already achieved a first result: to put the needs of citizens, the real economy and infrastructure back at the heart of European policies, after years of almost exclusive debate on deficit and debt parameters in the budgets of individual Member States.  However, the European Council has shown light and shadow on this issue. The shadows? Investments and their financing. We cannot be convinced just in words, Mr Michel, we need action. We therefore expect the Council to make a clear commitment on the resources to finance the Green Deal without going too far.  A multiannual financial plan that is equal to the challenge we face and we must necessarily address the issue of the Stability and Growth Pact and give Member States the opportunity to break away from the deficit-to-GDP ratio the investments that will help us achieve the objectives of the Green Deal. President von der Leyen has shown courage and vision, but if the Heads of State or Government do not support her, her path and, above all, the path to European growth will be uphill.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, the first thing I want to say to Mr Annemans is that what he has said is a scandal. I’m proud that a Belgian is President of the European Council, instead of all the stupid things you have said. And if you don’t know, dear colleagues: if there is a minority in Belgium, it is the separatist of Mr Annemans who is the minority in Belgium. To Mr Farage and his troops, I want to say that they make a lot of noise for having zero seats in the British elections. Everybody said here: ‘we will miss our British colleagues of the Lib Dems, of Labour’. Well, I will not miss the Brexiteers going out, I can tell you. I will not miss them. Saying that, dear colleagues, there is a consent to be given by this Parliament. And I know that everybody says and thinks: ‘oh, this consent will be given automatically, because it’s like that’. We have foreseen that this consent procedure will end in plenary on 29 January, but in the meanwhile, there is a problem to be solved. I have received, since the elections in Britain, hundreds and hundreds of letters and emails of British citizens living in Europe, panicking about their status. I have received hundreds of mails of EU citizens living in Britain panicking about their status. And I think we need to solve that first, before we give our consent on this Brexit treaty. Why? Neither citizens, British or Europeans alike, can be the victims of this (in my opinion) not very intelligent choice of Brexit. And I want to appeal to the Prime Minister of Britain, to Boris Johnson, to be generous in his victory and to give to all the European citizens – and the British citizens alike, living on the continent – the full rights as they have today: automatically, to all of them, no ifs and no buts, as he always says, to do so. I want also to tell you that more and more people are coming back to another (and I will conclude with this) issue of European associated citizenship for British citizens who want to continue to feel that they are European, and I think we have to be open to that request.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, and first of all, President Charles Michel: welcome, and congratulations on your first Council. With the conclusions, for example, on your almost unanimity on climate neutrality, but we call it the unanimity – right? But it’s also very clear that a very important discussion is ahead of you on the MFF, on the budget. And maybe this is also something for some of the countries that are always talking about climate action and climate ambition, and one of those countries is my own –that may be climate action also means that you have to do something with money. So maybe the Netherlands, but also Denmark and Sweden and Austria, and probably Finland when they’re not President anymore, translate your ambition also into a higher budget that can help those countries to have a just transition on climate. Second point, and that is a question to you, it took you now, and well not you, but the Council, more or less one and half years to get to an agreement on a 2050 target. We only have one year until we go to Glasgow to agree on a 2030 target, and in between, in September we have a very important EU-China summit, where Europe needs to be ready. How are you going to make sure that the Council is ready for an increased climate target 2030 before we have on 13 September in Leipzig an EU-China summit? That I would like to hear – because that’s the real challenge – and I hope I can congratulate you on that outcome in June.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council, we are here today at the ball of the bad losers. Everyone, from the EPP to the Socialists to Guy Verhofstadt at the moment, regret the democratically expressed choice by the British people. The verdict of the ballot boxes is indeed a setback for you, you who, here in the European Parliament, in the European institutions, have multiplied the manoeuvres to try to prevent Brexit from taking place, you too who, at times, have tried to pass a text objectively contrary to the will of the people, a text contrary to the interests of Great Britain and , of course, unacceptable to the House of Commons. It is, however, a double victory for Boris Johnson with these results in the general election. First, a democratic victory. He enforced the 2016 referendum, enforced the choice of the sovereign people, completed the negotiations and formalised Britain's effective exit from the European Union. But it is also, of course, a political victory. He brought the people together, he gave his political family his greatest electoral success in more than thirty years and he freed himself from the great dogmas: migratory laxity or globalism as an inexhaustible horizon. In the negotiation that will begin the day after 31 January, because Boris Johnson will be able to defend British interests with the pugnacity we know him, we must defend the interests of our nations, be able to have a relationship with Great Britain, a great friendly country, an ally, a partner, but also be able to defend the interests of European nations and not be afraid of competition. , because competition also exists within the European Union, between our countries.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for One of the hottest political issues now, it's the environment. The debate is both infected and emotional, as they should be guided by facts and serious action. Unfortunately, the focus is on punishing ordinary people who use the car or the flight. In Sweden, we often hit ourselves by the chest, and it is happy to point out that public transport is largely run on environmentally friendly fuel. What is not said is that Sweden only has a domestic production of environmental fuel equivalent to 10 percent. The rest of the fuel is imported and contributes to a devastated rainforest in the Amazon. How environmentally friendly is it?  If this institution were to be serious in its environmental zeal, this insane circus of migrants would be stopped 12 weeks a year in Strasbourg. Then, ladies and gentlemen, let's talk about environmental gain. It could also stop the private jet it is using and has given more funding to. If you are not prepared to do so, it is honestly just populism and hypocrisy that you are doing.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, you also remembered the Iron Curtain today. Our subject, and your subject, is not the Iron Curtain. Your issue is unemployment and the impoverishment of European citizens, the weak social state, the militarisation of Europe at the expense of labour rights, the climate crisis, the banking dictatorship on European territory. Your theme is false and theatrical words when we face Erdoğan's unbearable challenges in Cyprus, Libya and Syria at the expense of the sovereign rights of the peoples of the region. It's the bloody distribution of energy resources in the region. It is when you say, and say, to Erdoğan that he is our strategic partner, when we sell him weapons and when we negotiate the refugee, that is, the souls of the people, by enclosing them in concentration camps and that, really, is indeed, - I am sure you are listening to me - an Iron Curtain. Which is a disgrace and a moral blow to Europe.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, colleagues, I personally believe that it is necessary to pay tribute to the people of Great Britain, Mr Farage, my Brexit Party colleagues, for showing the direction in which civilised and democratic Europe should take. Britain is not leaving Europsk, Europe is leaving the European Union as a bureaucratic institution, and I am convinced that, for the foreseeable future, the European Union will consist of independent nation states, cooperating with each other, living in peace so that they do not have to be managed bureaucratically from Brussels. Dear friends from the United Kingdom: good luck, Happy Christmas, and Happy New Year.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Commission and President von der Leyen have presented a very ambitious programme. That is exactly what we need, namely courage, orientation, ideas and leadership. Thank you, Mrs von der Leyen, for your suggestions. That is exactly what we need in Europe and what Europe can take forward.  But we have the Council on the second side. Dear President-in-Office of the Council Michel, Jean-Claude Juncker also had many great ideas during the last parliamentary term. Our problem, however, is: how many projects in the last parliamentary term could not be completed because the Council was unable to take decisions? How many delays have there been because individual Member States have blocked and they have not dared to take majority decisions in the Council? How many farmers in our country have to worry because the Council has again been unable to adopt the budget in a timely manner? How many researchers cannot plan their research projects? How many tonnes of CO2 cannot be saved because we are missing all these programmes at the moment?  I therefore urge you to remain ambitious and please bring movement to the Council. We urgently need this movement in Europe.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, all eyes were on EU leaders, hoping that they would commit to a climate neutrality target by 2050, but Poland refused to sign up and that’s not unanimity, even if the Council tries to call it so. I hope it’s only a question of time. Most importantly, I hope that all EU Member States will actually be committed to this away from fancy headlines and away from fancy quotes to newsrooms. I hope that you will have the courage to push concretely for this transition with ambitious measures as of now and not let a couple of bigger Member States bully their way through when push comes to shove. The European Green Deal is a step in the right direction, but if the Member States believe that this is the way forward, then they need to put money where their mouth is. Yes, we all know that there are challenges, but with challenges come opportunities if we are united in devising a strong way forward, the three institutions and all the Member States together.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, 237 billion is the gaping hole that separates the States from Parliament over the 2021-2027 budget. By its proposal, Finland has multiplied the divisions, because it does not satisfy a majority of states that, like Parliament, want more, nor a minority that wants less. And that is not to mention the Commission's new ambitions, which are obviously shared by all to make Europe a power up to the challenges of the 21st century. As to where to find the money, it is something else. Mr President Michel, the Heads of State and Government have entrusted you with this responsibility to resolve the squaring of the circle. No doubt you'll spend a few nights there. The first exchange we had last night was extremely fruitful and it bodes well; so we are ready to go with you. Because Parliament has the answer to this 27th degree equation: own resources. Yes, Europe needs to regain financial autonomy. Yes, the Union needs new own resources that contribute to our policies and provide room for manoeuvre. And it is at this intersection that the States, the Commission and the European Parliament will meet. The own resources that some states do not want are not the problem, they are the solution. And that is why we will not agree without moving forward on this issue.

name: Gina DOWDING
text: – Madam President, sadly, for all of us who think the European Union offers the best future for the UK and the rest of Europe, we now have to face the reality of Brexit. Last week, the European Council reiterated its commitment to a level playing field in standards and regulations in trade between the EU and the UK, but the new UK Government already threatens to break its commitments. We in the UK now have a serious risk to workers’ rights and environmental protections, to parliamentary scrutiny of trade deals, and therefore a risk – again – of the possibility of a no-deal Brexit at the end of next year. This Parliament, elected on proportional representation, demonstrates all that can be achieved by nations working together in cooperation, representing citizens against global corporate business interests and confronting the global challenges of climate breakdown, social injustice and the ecological crisis. Citizens of Europe look to their governments to protect them against the vested interests of financial and property millionaires and corporate power. Many of us in the UK will continue to look to the best in the EU to lead in overcoming these challenges.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Listening to what you have said, I have the impression that, despite zero and negative interest rates, there is no currency crisis in Europe for you. There is no labour market crisis, there is no economic crisis, there is no migration crisis, there is only the climate crisis. Well, let us talk about the climate crisis, which you last described as a state of emergency in Strasbourg. In my view, this is a totally exaggerated and hysterical action. However, there is a majority in favour. But what you don't understand then is that a good part of the European nomenklatura gets on the plane and then immediately flies on to Madrid to continue swearing, is your thing. Where you could deliver would be, for example, to keep this single-seat debate, these two seats to one, namely in Brussels or Strasbourg and not the travelling circus. But I'll give you another example of dishonesty: go into the garage of the house here and see how many 6 and 8 cylinders are in the MEP garage. One almost gets the impression that a new episode of The fast and the furious is being filmed, but certainly not an honest majority who are committed to climate protection.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr. Michel, we know each other. You were very disappointed with the Madrid climate summit. I can understand that, but with a mass of 27 000 participants, you can never meet properly. Then it's going to be a mess. That has been shown. And what is the ecological footprint of that climate summit? According to the Guardian, 60,000 tons of CO2. We see that these climate summits are becoming more and more a travelling circus. Next year is the climate summit in Glasgow and then in the coming months there will be summits in Vancouver, Durban, Cali, Kazan, Edinburgh, Kyoto and so on. It seems, ladies and gentlemen, to be the travel rhythm of Formula One. The difference is that the CO2 emissions of the Formula 1 race are much lower than those of the climate summit. Formula One wants to be climate neutral even by 2030. That's quite an achievement. I therefore call on the climate conferencers in this Chamber: stop these expensive conferences costing 100 million each, and take an example of the climate performance of Formula 1.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Madam President, after three and a half years of deception and dishonesty, we will be leaving this prison of nations at the end of January. And we won’t become a third country, as I’ve been hearing this morning. No. We’re going to become an independent, self-governing nation. And you can delude yourselves this morning inside this cathedral that all is well, but it isn’t. It isn’t. People do not want to be run and governed by faceless bureaucrats like Michel and von der Leyen. Did you hear them earlier? Dull as ditchwater. You’re being rejected, and it’s great news that in Poland, opinion polls now show a majority of Poles think they’d be better off outside the European Union. Brexit is the beginning of the end of this project. We are giving leadership and will take it to a Europe of sovereign states working together, being friends together, but not being run by the gang down at the middle there.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: It is not a great way to make friends if you describe them as dull as ditchwater. A little bit of respect for Members of this House and for our teams here. (Applause) And as I have the Chair, we all have faces, and the ones you describe as ‘faceless’ have been the most out there dealing with Brexit. So I would just defend this institution and my colleagues. (Applause)

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – Madam President, I just want to say that I'm from Poland and I'm quite surprised at what I've just heard about my fellow citizens in Poland – that they want to leave Europe. This is quite new. Maybe I live in another country.  Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Three comments. Firstly, I would like to thank the President very much for expressing his readiness last night to talk to us as negotiators of the MFF. I think this is a very good step. Thank you very much for your willingness to cooperate, which will certainly be difficult cooperation.  Secondly, I would also like to express my satisfaction that the Council did not close the negotiating door after seeing the Finnish Presidency negobox, because this may be a starting point, but it is certainly not the base for further work in the way the Finnish Presidency has indicated. It is good that the Council has not closed this stage, but has said that it will continue its work.  Thirdly, there is a very important political decision ahead of us. Brexit is either an opportunity or a difficult one. I think it is high time for difficult financial decisions.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, with the results in the British elections, it is now clear that there is in the House of Commons a sufficient majority to approve the withdrawal agreement and conclude Brexit by the end of January. This is, of course, a sad moment in the history of Europe, but it is also a democratic choice that we must respect. But it also proves that Mr Farage is wrong in saying that Europe is a prison of nations. Our duty now is to concentrate on our common future, and that means to negotiate with the United Kingdom sound and friendly economic and political future relations that can serve our common interests and that can safeguard the integrity of the single market and our high levels of environmental, social and labour protection. This is the key for successful negotiations, and only by the end of 2020 will we know if the ‘no-deal’ Brexit scenario is really off the table.  In concentrating on our common future, we also have to address the expectations of our citizens, the idea of a conference on the future of Europe, and the Green Deal. These are all very important, but there are shortcomings regarding the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework, the conclusion of the Banking Union and the euro, which should remind us that we should do better in order to answer the challenges of Brexit.

name: Lucy NETHSINGHA
text: – Madam President, as many have said, the UK election has given a tragic clarity on Brexit. Johnson did not get a majority of the votes: many more UK citizens voted for parties opposing his Brexit. However, our system has given him a large majority and Brexit will now take place on 31 January. I’m deeply grateful for the efforts of the Council, and Mr Barnier in particular, to keep as close a relationship as possible. I’m particularly concerned about the impact on cooperation in scientific and academic research. Partnership between European countries has been incredibly beneficial in advancing scientific and technological knowledge for the benefit of the whole world. I know that European institutions are concerned that the UK will try to undermine standards on workers’ rights and environmental protection and we share those concerns. We will try in the UK to do all we can to maintain those crucial workers’ rights and environmental protections. Finally, thank you all for your support of those of us in the UK who have fought to remain. We continue to believe that the UK would have a better future within the EU. Mr Farage is wrong. The future is in fantastic democratic institutions like this and I hope that one day we will return.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Agreement on climate neutrality 2050 - EU agrees. When I read your tweet, Mr Michel, on Friday night, I was delighted. This is a step in the right direction, and it's a great success for Fridays and the Scientists for Future. But how much is this decision worth when there is a risk of bad compromises in the multiannual financial framework? Instead of haggling over comma numbers, it is about the future of our continent, and we will only be able to shape our future in Europe. The Finnish proposal for the financial framework is too weak for this. If you stick to 25% climate investment, you will ensure that the Green Deal fails, and without much more for research and digitalization, we will also lose touch worldwide. Climate-friendly agriculture, climate-neutral industry, energy-renovated buildings, fast and affordable rail connections: all this must be financed and for all this we need space in the financial framework. That is why I would like to call – not only the Council, but also you, Mrs von der Leyen – to adapt your proposal on the Green Deal to the financial framework. Let us do this together. The bill is not yet up.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, your Europe is increasingly a slave to the banks and the interests of France and Germany. The new Commission and the last Council are there to demonstrate this. Franco-German Europe wants An Italy invading by illegal immigrants. Malta's famous agreement on immigrants does not exist. It's waste paper, it's a big bluff.  Franco-German Europe wants to impose the ESA to steal Italian money, with the complicity of the Pd and Five Star Government, an abusive government, built and imposed by Europe on the heads of the Italian people. Just as you imposed the Monti government in 2011 to get your hands on the pockets of Italians. But who gives you the power to trample on democracy and the will of the people?  Dear brussels bureaucrats, pack your bags, because very soon, very soon, the Italian people will send you home, forever.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: – Presidents, colleagues, the philosophy behind the Green Deal deserves support. A sustainable, realistic transformation is needed to meet the climate challenges. The Council rightly states in its conclusions that this requires research, development and innovation. Commissioner Vestager said this week: technology is not a nice extra to meet the climate challenges, technology is essential. But the Green Deal depends on the financing and there are still many unknowns, of course also linked to the multiannual budget. The Green Deal requires additional funding in addition to the EUR 260 billion allocated so far to meet the 2030 targets. I look forward to these funding measures. On the multiannual budget, President Michel said that he was 'working closely with the Commission to find a compromise'. I would like to remind the President that Parliament is also needed to find that compromise.

name: Brian MONTEITH
text: – Madam President, as sure as eggs is eggs, this is probably my last speech and I want to say: I am Scottish, I am British, and I remain a European. And you may sit there with your fixed expressions casting doubt upon all I say, but I was a courier of samizdat material to the Soviet Union and its underground. I supported members of Solidarność in the 1980s. I worked for the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Iron Curtain. This place is the antithesis of being a good European: it works against the diversity of our cultures and our economies. This jumped—up virtue-signalling student union is not even about a united states of Europe. Instead it works ceaselessly – ceaselessly – to merge everyone into one homogenised blob of central control. The UK wants no part of it. We are leaving, and good riddance. We are leaving not because of Dan Hannan or Dominic Cummings, but because Nigel Farage and Richard Tice set up the Brexit Party that rebooted Brexit. I encourage all – all – true Europeans to ... (The President cut off the speaker) (Interjection from Mr Monteith: ‘Freedom!’)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Could we stop the dog-whistles, please, colleagues. And being Irish, I understand what you mean by ‘freedom’.

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: – Romania rejects the purely mathematical criterion used by the Finnish Presidency to build the European Union budget. We believe that the draft budget is not an expression of a vision. If we operate with the logic of cutting without taking into account the needs of all Member States, we deepen the economic gaps between east and west, so we empty the concept of cohesion with content.  Proposals on transfers between funds cancel out any flexibility and increase red tape. That is why the current proposed reductions for cohesion and the common agricultural policy cannot be supported by the Eastern European states. Romania does not support Europe with two speeds. Europe has only one speed. We support the idea of achieving climate neutrality by 2050, but we are talking about an ambitious but complicated objective at the same time that calls for measures adapted to national conditions, and there are still major differences between the lives of European citizens, depending on the state.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am very pleased that the European Council is now in agreement with the objective of achieving a climate-neutral Europe by 2050. The state of the climate is serious. It requires us to act and it requires us to act now. When the countries of the world failed to reach an agreement, there were many of us who were disappointed. That is why it is particularly important that we now have as a common goal that we achieve a climate-neutral Europe. This objective is also in line with the Paris Agreement. In fact, changing to a climate-neutral Europe brings new opportunities, new business models, new markets, new technologies and new jobs – and indeed new green growth. The climate change transition is here to stay. It should be smart and it should be fair. And I want us to work together for europe to become the world's first climate-neutral continent.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, after the failure of the COP 25 in Madrid, Europe seems to be one of the few places willing to undertake the fight against climate change. This has to change. We must do more to encourage others outside Europe to do their part. For instance, China should no longer be defined as a developing nation. Europe will not save the planet alone. The Czech Republic is willing to do our part for the climate, but we will need help. The proposed Just Transition Fund should not just be the Cohesion Fund rebranded. There must be new funds. Equally, while a green investment plan is a nice idea, without the private sector these funds would certainly not meet the needs of industrialised countries, such as the Czech Republic, Slovakia and other countries in the region, which face a far greater challenge to meet the climate goals while maintaining their economies.

name: Alexandra Lesley PHILLIPS
text: – Madam President, well I see the European Parliament has already started to cut its emissions: there’s more people in the gallery than in the Chamber, and you lot are actually supposed to believe in this project. What a joke! For three years, most people in this building have been in complete denial. You hoped by bullying the UK and conspiring with Brexit naysayers in our own Parliament, the Great British people would be worn down and change their minds. How wrong you were: voters don’t live in your EU bubble. They don’t want lives run by unaccountable EU fanatics, and despite your best efforts, Brexit will be a massive success. The UK now has real leverage in negotiations, and I hope Boris Johnson will tell you lot to forget your level playing field, ditch your regulations, and we will embrace full-fat freedom.  We won’t just survive; we will thrive. Rather than fight the inevitable, the EU should watch and learn as the UK becomes truly democratic and global, because if you do not – mark my words – the federalists will see your stupid project relegated to the dustbin of history. Merry Brexmas.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I welcome the fact that the leaders of the Member States of the European Union have reached an agreement to make Europe carbon neutral by 2050. In my opinion, some very important principles need to be laid down before further steps can be taken. The most important of these is not the people, but the biggest polluting companies and the most polluting countries, which should pay the price for climate protection. The costs incurred should not be passed on to families, so the new rules should not lead to an increase in energy, food and fuel prices. Do not withdraw cohesion aid from poorer countries, as this would only increase inequalities within the EU. It should also be taken into account that respect for the principle of technology neutrality is essential for drastically reducing CO2 emissions. Finally, I would like to point out that Hungary demonstrates its climate commitments not only by words but also by actions, since it has reduced its CO2 emissions by 37% since 1990.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, I will leave a few words here on the conclusions of the European Council on the Multiannual Financial Framework, almost as short as the time that European leaders devoted to the Multiannual Financial Framework at that meeting.  This European Council was another missed opportunity for European leaders to agree on a budget that is fundamental for the European Union. It is now in the hands of President Charles Michel to do what has not been done so far. Our meeting yesterday, your initiative with President Sassoli and the Nego Team were a first step.  I would like to remind you, Parliament has been ready to negotiate since November last year and consent on the Multiannual Financial Framework requires a political agreement on own resources for the financing of the European Union. Finally, Presidents, the Council's proposal on the table is unacceptable. We want a budget in January 2021, but we won't be willing to compromise the budget with which... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, the British election was a clear and decisive victory for the Conservative Party. The UK will now leave the European Union, because the withdrawal agreement will be passed, and they will leave on the 31 January.  There are also protections in the withdrawal agreement for no hard border on the island of Ireland, and I very much welcome that, but we must be vigilant, Mr Barnier. You must ensure that, whatever proposals and discussions continue after the withdrawal agreement, the border will not exist on the island. The Good Friday Agreement must also be upheld and vindicated. The rights of citizens, parity of esteem and EU citizenship. Bearing in mind, many people in Northern Ireland wish to express their identity as Irish citizens and European citizens – in fact, the majority in Northern Ireland want to express themselves as European citizens. There is political realignment happening in Northern Ireland as we speak, and there’s no doubt the demographics are changing and there will be a new political dispensation at some stage in the future. So we have to vindicate the Good Friday Agreement and bring forward the proposals and test the demographic changes in the near future to ensure we know what the people of Northern Ireland are thinking with regard to their citizenship and a united Ireland.

name: Vangelis MEIMARAKIS
text: Madam President, I welcome the Council's conclusions on the illegal agreement between Turkey and Libya in particular, because the support received by Greece and Cyprus from the European Union is a step, important for the stability of the Mediterranean but also for the strengthening of our maritime borders. It is also strong evidence with arguments and is a response to the turkish side's unfounded claims. Nevertheless, as has been shown repeatedly in the past, the Turkish Government is provocatively ignoring the rules of international law, in this case the Law of the Sea, and is aggressively pursuing a political strategy that tramples on every rule and every acquis. And with these provocative interventions, Turkey and President Erdoğan aim to destabilise the Mediterranean and, by extension, Europe itself. The behaviour of regional troublemakers must therefore be dealt with at European level, uniformly, coordinated, directly and with sanctions. We need to look soberly and calmly at redefining our relations with Turkey and to prove in practice that Europe is not just a spectator.

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I listened carefully to Mr Michel when he spoke about the Conference on the Future of Europe, and I also looked at the conclusions. What we can see is that the European Council has so far been very unambitious in its approach to this great undertaking. Mr Michel, I hope that you will be able to help change this attitude in the Council in the new year. Because this conference is a great opportunity to turn Europe back on its feet, and after the Brexiteers have left us, it will actually be a new departure in Europe.  But for that we need a bold, ambitious approach and we really need to achieve broad citizen participation with representative citizens' dialogues. It is not enough to refer to the strategic agenda, or simply to say that we want to build on what has been done so far. I would like to make the appeal – with Willy Brandt: the Council should also dare to do more democracy and a new start on this issue in the new year and present a good, ambitious, concept in the negotiations with the Commission and Parliament in order to increase the confidence of the citizens .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, let me say of my joy at seeing that the Commission takes on the idea of energy interconnectivity, in particular by linking Portugal and Spain to the rest of Europe, particularly on the Border of the Pyrenees, as a priority for the Green Deal. Because this is not just an ecological issue and it is not just an economic issue, it is also a geopolitical issue. We can depend less on Russia if we open the doors of European energy to the Iberian Peninsula, because it will have clean energy and it will also have energy that can be imported from other regions and that can reach Europe, reducing our dependence on Russia. I would also like to greet President Charles Michel and tell him that I am a little disappointed by the Council's lack of vision on the Conference on The Future of Europe. There is one thing I wanted to tell you: it is important for the Council to work here. And there is a guarantee that Parliament must also give to the Council, and I am prepared to acknowledge that, is that we must listen to the citizens first. There should be no results before listening to the citizens. And so we are totally in good faith to do this exercise with the Council, so the Council wants it.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the conclusions were a unanimous position of the European Union, which confirmed Turkey's illegal behaviour, both in the Cypriot EEZ and in relation to the so-called memorandum with the Tripoli regime. In both cases, Turkey acts outside international law and outside UN Maritime Law.  Today, however, the Council reiterated its solidarity with the Member States whose sovereign rights are being violated. In essence, Erdoğan's attack is against the European Union, it is against international law, which is a acquis communautaire, and it affects the highest strategic interests of the European Union, which include energy planning in the Eastern Mediterranean. And yet, while we are discussing these issues today and the Council has decided on measures against Turkey, tomorrow the new Commission begins a dialogue to upgrade trade relations with Turkey.  Erdoğan will create a new jihadist regime in Libya. We must defend our highest interests.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I have two comments on the Council's results. First, the Member States have not lost a single word about the situation in Malta – and we are talking here about a contract killing in Malta, in which the highest circles of government are involved. I say it with all frankness: I find this shameful. My second comment relates to the Green Deal: if we get it right, the Green Deal can become the engine of growth for the European Union. The Council has confirmed that. "Doing the right thing" means: relying on new technologies, on intelligent solutions. Then, I believe, we can achieve climate neutrality by 2050. It is technologically possible, but it must of course also make economic sense. That is why I believe that climate policy and competition policy are two sides of the same coin, and I am pleased, Madam President of the Commission, that next year, in addition to the proposal for the Climate Act, you will also present your industrial policy at the same time, which I think is a good announcement and I am curious about your proposals.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, as you take the Brexit procedure forward, please be aware – please remember – that 53% voted in this election for parties that wanted another referendum on this.  Every opinion poll over the last year, except one, has shown that a majority of the British public would vote to remain if we had a new referendum, and Mr Johnson, with his 43% of the vote – only 1% more than Mrs May achieved two years ago – takes that as a mandate to go forward with a very hard Brexit. And make no mistake, he’s going for a hard Brexit, because he has already gone back on a previous promise to say that the House of Commons would vote on extending the transition period to allow time for negotiations. He’s already saying we will not extend; we will make it illegal to extend. He doesn’t want to negotiate a proper partnership or trade deal. His strategy in the negotiations seems to be ‘give me what I want or I’ll shoot myself in the head’. It’s not going to work. It’s going to lead to a disastrous Brexit.  And finally, Madam President, may I endorse what Guy Verhofstadt said, that this Parliament should not endorse any deal until the rights of citizens, both ways around, are secured.  (Applause)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm cúpla abairt a rá faoin gcruinniú ar an deireadh seachtaine a bhí ag an gComhairle agus – níos tábhachtaí – na himpleachtaí don Eoraip sa todhchaí. Mr Michel briefly mentioned Brexit at the meeting at the weekend – understandably so. But last night in our Group meeting, the always excellent and courteous Michel Barnier gave us an outline of what is going to happen over the next 12 months. I think one thing was very clear from what Mr Corbett said: that unless there’s goodwill and cooperation across the table, the outcome could be grave. So I would appeal to Mr Johnson not to be putting arbitrary and unnecessary deadlines into the negotiations and say to him that getting Brexit right is more important than getting Brexit done, and I hope that can happen. Also, I just want to mention briefly what President von der Leyen mentioned about the MFF. I hope all Member States remaining will step up to the plate and give us a proper budget, and if not, as she said, we need to develop our own resources.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Head of the task force for relations with the United Kingdom. Madam President, Mr President of the European Council, at the request of Ursula von der Leyen, our President, and as many of you have, of course, raised the issue of Brexit, I would like to say a few words on this subject, in response to your speeches. First of all, I would like to point out, as do many of you, that this is the very first time that our Parliament has debated Brexit knowing that it will really take place on 31 January, from now on. I say this with a lot of respect, and also a lot of understanding. I echo the speech of Iratxe Garcia Pérez, Dacian Ciolo and Ska Keller too, from many of you - a great deal of understanding towards all those, many of you here and outside this Chamber, who would have liked the United Kingdom to remain in the Union. But I also express respect for the British choice, from the beginning, and our responsibility, ladies and gentlemen, our mission, the one entrusted to me, is precisely to respect the will expressed by a majority of British citizens, and therefore to organise the orderly withdrawal in the interest of the citizens, in the interest of the economy, on both sides, and in the interest of the future as well. , through a treaty that is now here, which you know well since we have somehow co-constructed it together. I in turn want to thank the Brexit steering group and all the parliamentarians who participated, in particular Guy Verhofstadt. Now we are on the verge of looking to the future and I remember what our President Ursula von der Leyen said here on 27 November: "Whatever our future, the bonds and friendship between our peoples will remain indestructible". That is the line, ladies and gentlemen, for the times ahead, and that is what will lead us to work respectfully, ambitiously on a very strong and strategic relationship with the United Kingdom. This relationship will be based on an economic pillar, and we will work in particular with Commissioner Phil Hogan and all the other Commissioners concerned, under the authority of the Chair, and a strategic pillar, to which we will work with High Representative Josep Borrell and other Commissioners as a matter of priority. The United Kingdom will remain, as you said, a friendly country, an allied country, a partner country and we must translate this alliance, this friendship, this partnership into new treaties. I would like to point out that the framework for this future relationship, which is very ambitious, is written very precisely in the last 36 pages of this document that you have before you. And I want to remind you that this document, this political statement, is common. Every word counts, every word has been approved by us and by Boris Johnson. Again, every word counts. What can limit this ambition, ladies and gentlemen? Two things. The first is the time, the time we need to translate this ambition into treaties or texts. The second thing: of course, the differences that may arise between our interests and our objectives, in particular the answer that the United Kingdom will bring, in the coming weeks, to a question. The UK is leaving the EU, we respect that choice. He is not leaving Europe, of course. Does it want to move away, and to what extent, from our regulatory model? That is the question that is being asked. It is the response that will be given by the United Kingdom that will determine the level of our ambition. As of today, we have three projects to do together. The first is the conclusion of the ratification process for the withdrawal agreement. The second is the implementation of the agreement itself, in all its dimensions. This is not insignificant, both for the citizens whose rights written in this text must be respected, and also, I would like to remind you, Madam President - I also say this to Mr Kelleher and Sean Kelly and others - in Ireland and Northern Ireland, for peace and stability. The third project is that of the future, of the new negotiation, in a limited time. We have heard the British Prime Minister say that he will not want to ask for an extension of the transition. This extension is possible, it will remain possible until 30 June, by mutual agreement, which means that each of the two partners, the Union and the United Kingdom can say yes, or not, until 30 June. This time is limited, so it will not be possible, if I continue to be very frank with you, in this limited time, to do everything, but we will do everything we can. We can't do it all, but we will give it our all. So, of course, if we want to reach, at the end of the road, a new relationship in all its dimensions, it will take more time and continue beyond the end of the transition, at the end of 2020, to work with the British and negotiate. I want to make a final commitment under the authority of President von der Leyen and with the confidence of the President of the European Council, and yours. We will continue to work with the same method: transparency, frankness, dialogue with all the Commissioners concerned and with the Commission's services. I would just like to say one last word to Mr Michael Heaver, who spoke very vehemently earlier and said, ''We are proud to be British.'' Of course, we respect and understand this pride, but, Mr. Heaver, we are all here proud to be patriots, and we have no lesson in patriotism from you. (Applause) The only thing I want to say is that, to our patriotism, to our pride in being patriots, we add here an extra dimension, we think that our patriotism is today, and will be tomorrow in the world as it comes, stronger, because we add the union of Europeans and the common action of europeans.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Madam President, Madam President, dear Members of the European Parliament, thank you for the various messages that have been sent, for the opinions that have been expressed. The first point is that the climate was indeed the number one issue for this European summit last week. Thank you for the encouragement that has been expressed; I can see how much work remains to be done, and in particular the need, very quickly, to agree on the 2030 targets in order to prepare for the next COP, particularly in Glasgow. We will do so with the Commission, taking into account the assessments necessary to continue progress on this subject. Second element: yes, this is an important step that was taken last week by the European Council, because the decision is unanimous on the 2050 climate neutrality target, and it is only for its implementation that a European country has considered that more time is needed - we will come back specifically to this subject in June , in the European Council. Third, we opened the financing project because, in fact, to be credible and realistic, this issue of funding is essential. We will continue it in the coming months, in particular, but not only in view of the debate on the next European budget. And finally, a complementary point, which several have mentioned: I also believe that this strong position, carried by the European authorities - the European Green Pact, climate neutrality in 2050 - gives the European authorities and the institutions a clear mandate at the international level, especially in the context of next year's summits with China. Moving this agenda forward at the international level is also part of success, and I deeply believe that this decision is really essential, because it creates the conditions for putting Europe in a position tomorrow to have champions for the green economy, which is a good thing for prosperity, for stability, for development and for innovation as well. Finally, look at the progress I've come in a few months, no matter how impatient, I respect and hear. Just a few months ago, at the Sibiu Summit , at the beginning of 2019, only 9 out of 27 European countries shared this climate neutrality target by 2050. A few months later, there is unanimity around this extremely strong message. The second point is the question of the European budget. I share the view expressed in particular by Mr Weber and other Members of the European Parliament: this is an extremely difficult task. That is why, well before last week's summit, I took a long time, Mr MEP, to meet one-on-one with the various European leaders, to understand priorities, to understand the negotiating spaces and the spaces for compromise. But I also count on the political coherence of all politicians, because I mean here a line of strength that emerges and ambitions that are legitimate in terms of capacity to act through the European budget. At the same time, I also see all around the table of European leaders, heads of state and prime ministers, each of whom faces national parliaments composed of political majorities, with parties represented in this European Parliament. I also count on an ability in the future to bring the debate to a political coherence, whether it is addressed to interlocutors at the national level or at the European level, so that the same messages are carried by the political parties from which you presented yourself before the voters. Finally, third element: I do not want to avoid the question of Malta and the rule of law. I will be very clear on this extremely important subject. The rule of law is a foundation, is a founding value of the European project. And the murder of a journalist is obviously first of all a tragedy for the families, is a tragedy for the relatives, a human drama. But, beyond this human and personal tragedy for families, this is a serious and serious attack on press freedom, it is one of the fundamentals of this European project that unites us and brings us together. Investigations are ongoing, which must be based on the principles of the rule of law, on the principles of the separation of powers. It is up to the European institutions, each in its role and responsibility - the European Parliament has already started a number of reflections and reasoning on the subject - to assume their responsibilities. I will not try to escape my responsibilities when it comes to defending the rule of law, and it is in this spirit also that I have announced that I am prepared to to meet the family of this murdered journalist. (Applause) Finally, one more word on Brexit: I would like to repeat, say here again that each time - and this started with the referendum, three years ago - I respected the positions expressed by the British people in the referendum. I regret this decision, but I respect it, because it was expressed by the British people. The European Council last week - and Michel Barnier has just said it again with great precision - has put itself in order for the next steps. We know what direction we want, we know where we want to go, we know that transparency and unity will be essential to ensure that these negotiations are fair and respectful. We will protect, defend European interests, the level playing field, the interest also to preserve the integrity of the internal market. But I would like, with great tranquillity, with great calm - it will always be my spirit: the gathering - to say to those I have heard in this House who, once again, have practiced the annoying insult and insult rather than the argument, to tell them that I will not let myself be intimidated by this spirit of sterile controversy. With calm and determination, we will defend a strong, close relationship for the future with Great Britain. Finally, I will conclude with these few words, reiterating my conviction. Ambition, trust and common sense are, in my opinion, the guidelines that must dominate the action of the institutions, without ever forgetting that each institution is there to carry the hopes and dreams of European citizens and to ensure that this project that mobilizes us is a project that brings light for the future. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The award of the Sakharov Prize will start shortly. (The sitting was suspended at 12h05) Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I would like to congratulate the Commission for its efforts to find an agreement at the European Council on the 'European Green Course' presented by the Commission. Europe has announced a particularly ambitious target of becoming a climate-neutral economy by 2050, which will require not only huge financial resources and structural reforms in various areas, but especially the political will of the Member States to implement extremely difficult but necessary solutions. This will be difficult enough to achieve, as we can see from the ongoing negotiations on the next multiannual financial perspective. The negotiating package presented by the Finnish Presidency is not satisfactory for us, and for some EU Member States, such as Lithuania, EU support is aimed at reducing eu support by over EUR 2 billion compared to the current financial perspective, which is totally unacceptable. We will not accept cuts in funding for social policy. The european Parliament's position on ignoring the EUR 5.9 billion budget for the european union is also worrying. european guarantee for the child. The European Parliament will not support a budget that does not allocate sufficient funds to social policy priorities, as such cuts will affect the most vulnerable sections of society.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – We celebrated the 10th anniversary of the Treaty of Lisbon in Strasbourg. We are proud of this Treaty that defends Principles, Values, Human Rights, Rule of Law. Solidarity is a strong principle of the Treaty. We must preserve these principles, and they cannot be discounted. I agree that on climate change issues the EU will become a Leader. But we also owe it to the principles and values and the defence of the sovereignty of EU member countries to be leaders. A strong signal must be sent that the EU will respond by all means and defend the sovereignty of member countries from external threats. If Turkey does not understand words, let us proceed with the freezing of the EU Customs Union of Turkey. The US Senate has not been intimidated by Turkey's threats to recognise the Armenian Genocide and will also proceed with sanctions. The EU will truly be a Leader if it becomes a Leader in Principles and Values towards offending countries such as Turkey. Can the EU say 'So far and no more', can Turkey stress that, if it continues the violations in Cyprus and Greece, it will find the EU united with it and thus demonstrate its solidarity with all member states in practice?

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The European Council meeting highlighted the crisis and contradictions in which European capitalist integration is steeped. They proclaim a so-like ambition in the environmental field. They talk about instruments, incentives, support and investments. But they have on the table a negotiating framework of the Multiannual Financial Framework, with indication of values, which cuts the funds for "cohesion", harms countries with greater difficulties, such as Portugal, and directs resources to the major powers, feeding a militaristic and security drift.  In the Eurozone, the "budgetary capacity" they said would promote convergence is, after all, another instrument to promote the "competitiveness" of the richest, the largest beneficiaries of the euro and the single market, at the expense of more damage to them than ever. They wave a "Conference on the Future of Europe" to make it clear that this is yet another staged attempt to legitimise previously decided policies, increasingly discredited in the eyes of europe's workers and peoples.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: in writing. – We have to start delivering on the goal of carbon neutrality. Such an ambitious goal needs proper resources to promote and support the transition. We can find those resources, and at the same time avoid importing carbon and avoid endangering responsible European investment. An ambitious budget for the future – that is what we need. We need to put our money where our mouth is. One first and very important moment will be the way the Just Transition Fund will support the transition in all Europe, and where the money will come from. We will be very attentive on the proposal. We need to fight for agreements, avoid blockages at the Council, for this Europe to evolve. Banking Union is to be completed; more importantly, EMU is to be completed and a stabilisation mechanism within the EU budget is absolutely necessary. These are truly strong objectives, but bold action was again promised today by the President of the Commission, which as a member of this political family I acknowledge and support. Let us unite around the future of this European project. We wish all the best for the endeavours of the new President of the Council.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Mr President, after last week's British elections, it seems clear that Brexit will happen at the end of January. Although the election result in this respect clarified the situation, the uncertainty will not go away. As we know, the post-withdrawal transition period will only be in force until the end of 2020, and after that the future relationship between the EU and the UK will be wide open. At least now, the British Prime Minister's position has been that there will be no desire to extend the transition period after that. So next year will be a very heated period of negotiations, and I wish our excellent chief negotiator Michel Barnier, who has a big job ahead of him. Personally, I think it is important that we reach an agreement, which would create as few obstacles as possible to the movement of people, goods and services. I think it is important that our cooperation continues closely, particularly in the areas of education, research and security cooperation. This all depends, of course, on what kind of agreement we can reach. It is clear that outside the EU, Britain cannot receive the same benefits as as a member of the EU. There are no raisins from the bun. Both sides will suffer as a result of the difference, but agreements should be used to mitigate the disadvantages to people's everyday lives, business activities, Europe's competitiveness and security.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. I have many doubts about the effectiveness of the Green New Deal, presented in recent days by Ursula von der Leyen, to the European Parliament. It seems to me to be a cosmetic operation, with an extremely ideological approach, without a clear political will to solve the problem, which should not be considered only at European level. The EU should do everything possible to facilitate the growth and work of companies, instead of imposing more and more hard-to-comply rules, thus undermining the competitiveness of our companies and putting thousands of jobs at risk. The Council took note of the results in the United Kingdom. Having done everything possible over the past three years to prevent both the vote and the implementation of Brexit, the EU must finally face the facts and negotiate a trade deal quickly, in the name of loyal cooperation. The British people have sent a strong signal to this EU, which is not working.  The conclusion of the Brexit affair breaks the dogma and myth of the EU untouchable and irreversible.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Council rejected the proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework 2021/2027 presented by the Finnish Presidency and mandated the President of the Council to pursue bilateral contacts leading to the formulation of a proposal that can be accepted by all Member States. This decision was inevitable.  The Finnish Presidency's proposal was incompatible with the ambition demonstrated elsewhere on the Council's agenda, notably with the ambition to implement an ecological pact leading to an accelerated process of decarbonisation, achieving carbon neutrality in 2050, as part of a fair transition that leaves no territory behind, and to maintain effort in cohesion and proximity policies.  I also highlight the European Council's commitment to an orderly exit from the United Kingdom on the basis of the withdrawal agreement, calls for swift approval and ratification. Finally, and with regard to the EURO summit, I would like to continue the work of consolidating the new budgetary instrument for convergence and stability (European Stability Mechanism), integrating its debate into the process of strategic consensus led by the President of the Council.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I am pleased to welcome Jewher Ilham, daughter of Ilham Tohti, who came here today to represent her father at the 2019 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought award ceremony.  I would like to greet all the finalists of the Sakharov Prize, who have presented themselves and been presented by our Members this year, and who are here with us in the diplomatic gallery. We have with us the Brazilian representatives of the fight for human rights, environmental protection and conservation of the Amazon rainforest: - Monica Benicio representing her late partner Marielle Franco, killed in March 2018 - Claudelice Silva Dos Santos - Patxon Metuktire representing her grandfather Capo Raoni And for The Restorers, we have a group of young Kenyan schoolgirls - Stacy Owino - Synthia Otieno - Purity Ouma - Macrine Onyango On behalf of the European Parliament, I thank you for being with us today and we congratulate you on your courage and your strong commitment and we will of course continue to follow your activities. Before I go any further, I would like to invite you to watch a short video about this year's winner, Dr. Ilham Tohti. (A video is screened) Ladies and gentlemen, today we are awarding the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to Professor Ilham Tohti, who cannot be here with us and has been in prison since 2014. His struggle, for which he is still paying a heavy price, must be a source of inspiration for us. I would like to express my sincere thanks to your daughter, Mrs Jewher Ilham, who had the courage to come here on her behalf.  It is here, in the very heart of European democracy, that we can hear, but above all listen, the voice of those who cannot do so in their own countries.  By awarding the Sakharov Prize, this Parliament must speak up for freedom of thought and speech, an extremely valuable freedom, for many and too many who are still dangerous.  I am particularly proud and honoured to be able to award this award to Professor Ilham.  His struggle highlights the values of dialogue, mutual understanding, moderation, reconciliation and cultural diversity. It is those same values that under which the European project is based.  Ilham Tohti is a professor of economics, but he is also a voice that invites us all to moderation and reconciliation. He has committed himself to defending the rights of the Uyghur minority in China, with the hope of improving their living conditions. Uyghurs are constantly being persecuted in all kinds: physical, cultural, religious, economic and political.  Since April 2017, more than a million innocent Uyghurs have been arbitrarily detained in a network of prison camps, where they are forced to renounce their ethnic identity and religious beliefs.  However, these people are a great people, with a deep identity, and with a history of over 1,000 during which they have been able to develop a culture that deserves to be preserved. Ilham Tohti, through his militant activities, managed to give them a voice. Although he is being held in prison, his voice resonates today with that of his daughter and many other Uyghurs. For over twenty years he has been working tirelessly to promote dialogue and mutual understanding between Uyghurs and other Chinese peoples. Nevertheless, he was sentenced to life in prison on charges of 'separatism'.  The European Parliament calls for his immediate and unconditional release.  His struggle and all the suffering he has suffered remind us that we must fight for freedom of thought. It is a fundamental right that is sometimes won at the cost of human lives.  I would also like to mention, of course, with all of you, the winners of the previous editions of the prize, who are currently in prison and persecuted for defending human rights and fundamental freedoms, and sometimes even for the simple fact that they have won the Sakharov Prize: Nasrin Sotoudeh, Raif Badaw, the 'Damas de Blanco', various members of the democratic opposition in Venezuela and Asmaa Mahfouz.  Therefore, this Parliament urges the High Representative to take all necessary measures, in his contacts with the countries concerned, to secure the release and cessation of persecution of the Sakharov Prize winners. This request is extended to the Member States of the European Union and to our governments, within the framework of their bilateral relations, seek to convey the common values of the European Union and to defend human rights and freedoms. Today should be a day of celebration to celebrate freedom of thought and instead it is a sad day. Once again this chair is empty, because in the world in which we live being free to think does not always mean being truly free.   In the hope that Ilham Tothi will be released, that he will come and visit us, we turn our thoughts to him, his family members and all those who are unfortunately in prison with him. Your daughter, Jewher Ilham, gives us the honour of being here on her behalf and I give her the floor.

name: Jewher Ilham
text: representing her father Ilham Tohti, Winner of the Sakharov Prize. – Assalamu alaykum, peace be upon you. I want to thank the European Parliament and all those who made it possible for my father to receive the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. You have highlighted not only my father’s work and the persecution he has endured because of it, but you bring to the attention of the European Union and the rest of the world the plight of over one million Uyghurs who have been forcibly detained in concentration camps in the Uyghur Region. Thank you. Rehmet. It is an honour to be at the European Parliament today to accept the Sakharov Prize on behalf of my father. I am grateful for the opportunity to tell his story, because he cannot tell it himself. To be honest with you, I don’t know where my father is. 2017 was the last time my family received word about him. At that time, he was being held in Urumqi first prison. I have not seen my father since we were separated at the Beijing airport in 2013 – we were on our way to Indiana University, where my father was invited as a visiting scholar. Unfortunately, he never made it to the US. On that day, we were pulled out of the security line. I was given the choice of boarding the plane and flying to the US, or staying with my father. My father insisted that I continue. He said to me, ‘Don’t cry, don’t let them think Uyghur girls are weak.’ I went, and because of his encouragement, I am here in Strasbourg with all of you. But while I travelled on, he was detained, beaten, questioned, and now carries a life sentence at some undisclosed location. I will never be able to travel back to China and will likely never meet my family again. It is hard to believe that my father still physically resembles now the man I knew as a child. The man who worked at my bedroom desk in pyjamas after I complained he spent more time on his website ‘Uyghur Biz’ than with me. When there was a problem, my father always had a solution. He believed that when there was a problem, you need to fix it, just like when there is a hole in a fabric, you need to sew it. An unresolved problem, he thought, will lead to a bigger problem. And so, he moved his laptop into my room and he worked at my desk while I sat on my bed doing homework. This way, we could be together. Sometimes, he would forget how late it was, lost in his work until 4 in the morning. I would go in and out of sleep to the click of his fingers on the computer. I was a teenager then, with little understanding of why my father would give up his profitable business career and our trips to the Nujie halal meat market for the life that landed him in prison. There was a time when we could afford to buy a whole halal lamb or an entire sheep and share it with the neighbourhood. After my father committed himself to advocating for the rights of Uyghurs, halal lamb grew more scarce in our household. My father’s wealth went to supporting the Uyghur community – from poor Uyghur mothers to homeless children. When he purchased a server in the United States to secure his website ‘Uyghur Biz’, there was no money left for lamb. My father was not afraid of being poor as long as he could devote himself to the cause that came to define his life: fostering peaceful dialogue and understanding between the Han Chinese and the Uyghurs living in the western part of China.
