For him, the problem was clear. Uyghurs were being denied basic rights: the right to believe what we believe; the right to worship the way we want to worship; the right to think what we want to think. For him, the solution was simple: to engage with the Chinese Government in conversation about working with Uyghur people in a peaceful, non-violent and instructive way. The Chinese Government was not interested in conversations about working on the tensions building in the Uyghur region with a Uyghur scholar like my father – a man who was committed to peaceful resolution where the Han and the Uyghurs could live in harmony. Instead, they labelled him a separatist and locked him in solitary confinement for empowering the very people the Chinese Government wanted to control. Today, there is no freedom for Uyghurs in China – you know this – not at school, not in public, not even in private homes. My father, like most Uyghurs, has been labelled a violent extremist, with a diseases that needs to be cured and a mind that need to be washed. It is under this false label of extremism that the Government has put one million people – probably even more – into concentration camps, where Uyghurs are forced to give up their religion, language and culture, where forced labour is widespread and people are tortured. Some have died. History repeats itself. It didn’t end well before; it won’t end well now. China labels them as ‘re-education centres’. Sorry, but I don’t buy this term, and you shouldn’t either. ‘Extremism’ is the kind of language the Chinese Government uses to justify tearing families apart, controlling and monitoring every move of the Uyghurs inside and outside of China, and putting so many innocent people into camps. Even in my home in Washington DC, my phone and computer are often hacked. People ask me, am I scared? Yes, I am afraid. Sometimes I wake up in a cold sweat. Sometimes I worry that my speaking out will bring harm to my family living in China. Even speaking to you today makes me nervous. I’m sure my father was afraid, too. But when he identified a problem, he overcame his fear by working towards a solution, no matter what the cost. I’m here today because I want to support my father. So I ask you in this room and those who are listening: do you see a problem with the way the Chinese Government is treating Uyghur people? If you see a problem, please work towards a solution. Work from your place of influence. To the Members of Parliament: use your laws to hold Chinese Government officials accountable. To businesses: don’t be complicit in the Chinese Government’s persecution of the Uyghur people. To the scholars: continue your research to help expose these atrocities. To the NGOs: keep up the good work and hang in there. (Applause) To students: educate yourselves and never stop your pursuit of the truth and your fight for justice. This is not about fighting China. This is about protecting human rights. A special mention goes to my father’s students who are serving years in prison for supporting him and his projects. These brave people, as well as my Uyghur brothers and sisters, are not alone in the camps. Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Uzbek people are jailed in concentration camps simply for being themselves. Human rights lawyers and human rights defenders are held in prison simply for protecting the rights of other human beings. Elsewhere in China, Tibetans and Hong Kongers, the Chinese Christians continue to struggle to protect their identity and their basic human rights. In the spirit of my father’s work to promote a world of respect and understanding among different communities, I would like to bring to your attention the other finalists. Although they have not received the Prize, their dedication and work deserve equal attention. Therefore, I ask you to discover more about The Restorers, who are doing amazing work in improving the lives of women in Kenya and elsewhere in Africa. In Brazil, the causes of the late Marielle Franco, Chief Raoni and Ms Silva dos Santos must be supported for their tireless work on preserving the Amazon rainforest and the rights of marginalised indigenous people who live in the region. (Applause) These incredible people need to be heard. These people need your immediate support. Finally, while I don’t know where my father is, I believe he is alive. I believe that his spirit, as captured in the Sakharov Prize, honours the father I know who moved his computer into my bedroom when I needed him. Now, the Uyghur people need you. Thank you very much. (Loud and sustained applause) (The sitting was suspended at 12.35)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, I take the floor in the manner of the conduct under Rule 195 of the Rules of Procedure, as Mr Philip Lambert did yesterday. Two of my colleagues, Mr. Ismail Ertug and Mrs. Karima Deli, felt affected by my words. They want an apology. It's okay. When someone feels affected, there's my apology. I am a Bulgarian with roots in today's Macedonia, Serbia, even Turkey, and I would not be offended if someone called me a Bulgarian from Macedonia, but since Mr. Ertug and Ms. Deli have felt offended and want excuses, they have them.  But there is no excuse for the way the infamous Mobility package was spent. There is no excuse for a "supposedly" environmental policy of driving thousands of empty trucks to pollute the air. "Supposedly" socialists to deprive Eastern Europe of jobs and "supposedly" Europeans to give business to Turkey and To Russia. That also deserves an apology.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, just to rectify the situation: you have the right to disagree on the mobility package, which does not correspond to your position. But under no circumstances, as the chair of the Committee on Transport in this Parliament, with my colleague Ismail Ertug, will I tolerate your comments about my origins, for two things: the first is that you are sending racist messages, and the second is that I will never let myself be done, I will always stand up so that this kind of talk is never trivialised in this institution. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We now come to the election of the European Ombudsman in the second round, in accordance with Rule 231 of the Rules of Procedure. Let us try it now to see, but of course the Chamber is full, but we must do so in accordance with the Rules of Procedure in order to report attendance, because we need a qualified presence.  Meanwhile, I announce that Mr Nils Muižnieks' candidacy has been withdrawn and the candidates are: Giuseppe Fortunato, Julia Laffranque, Emily O'Reilly and Cecilia Wikström. Let's take the test. The vote is open.  The vote is closed.  We naturally have the full Chamber and therefore the necessary participants for this election.  I would remind you that the vote shall take place by secret ballot, that, in accordance with Rule 231(6) of the Rules of Procedure, the candidate must obtain a majority of the votes cast in order to be elected. Abstentions shall not be considered as valid votes. Since, pursuant to Rule 231(7), I have to check that the sitting is open before I declare the sitting open, we have carried out the check and there are at least 374 Members present.  The vote on the verification is closed. The number of Members present is sufficient and we can therefore proceed to the election. Information on elections by electronic means has been distributed, it is the same procedure that we used yesterday. Place yourself on the name of the candidate of your choice and express your preference by pressing the "+" button only once.  We are ready, the vote is open.  Everyone voted.  The vote is closed.  Number of votes: 694 Abstentions: 56 Votes cast: 638 Absolute majority: 320 They obtained votes: – O'Reilly: 291 – Laffranque: 251 – Lucky: 58 – Wikström: 38 No one got enough numbers to be elected. Since no candidate has obtained a majority, we now have to proceed to the third vote between the first two candidates, mrs O'Reilly and Mrs Laffranque.  We give time to upload names to our computers.  Here, we're ready. Then on the Ballot Laffranque, O'Reilly.  The vote is open.  The vote is closed. Voting members: 694 Blank ballots: 94 Votes cast: 600 Obtained votes: – O'Reilly: 320 – Laffranque: 280 Then, on the basis of the third round of voting, I declare Mrs Emily O'Reilly elected European Mediator.  And I congratulate you on your election. Following the outcome of the vote, I would like to inform you that I will sign Parliament's decision on the election of the European Ombudsman.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to wholeheartedly congratulate Ms O’Reilly on her election today. Ms O’Reilly, it is a very impressive sign of trust and confidence of the European Parliament and a recognition of your excellent work over the last number of years. The Ombudsman has become a very important pillar of the EU’s institutional architecture since its first election in 1995, and the Ombudsman’s role as a facilitator and a mediator for the citizens and the administration deserves all our full support. We have been working together in the Commission over recent years to make the EU administration better, more transparent and more efficient. Actually too few people realise this, but only 5% of the cases end up with a finding of maladministration, and in more than 70% of the cases the Commission follows the proposals of the Ombudsman. This shows a constructive spirit and a constructive relationship of the institutions with the Ombudsman in the day—to—day work. The Commission will continue to be a constructive partner with an open mind and, as before, we will deal with your proposals for solutions, suggestions for improvements and recommendations in a constructive spirit and with the shared objective of finding solutions that match the citizens’ and the public interest. The Ombudsman and the Commission have a common interest in getting the message across that the European Union and the institutions care about people’s needs and problems and do everything we can to address these problems in a concrete way. So Ms O’Reilly, once again, let me wish you all the best in your new mandate, and the Commission and I personally look forward to our future cooperation.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you to the Commissioner and, of course, good luck to the new European Ombudsman.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: – Mr President, did we not miss a vote on the original text to recital P by roll call?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: No, the text has been adopted beforehand, so this vote has not been taken.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, we would propose an oral amendment deleting recital W, because it’s referring to a report that we wanted to be made public but it was made public yesterday. So it’s redundant, in our view.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On a point of order. It is not possible for you to simply ignore it when checking is called here. That is not the way the votes are going.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The vote was perfectly clear, so the objection had no plausibility. If I myself were insecure, I would have it repeated. - Following the vote on recital Q:

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: "Mr President, yes, I am in place 213. Recall to the Regulations - it appears that it is not for the presiding officer to decide whether or not an audit should be implemented in the regulation. It is clear that if parliamentarians ask for an audit, it is by law.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: If you quote the Rules of Procedure, I must also quote them: it is up to the President to decide.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, based on Rule 180(4) of our Rules of Procedure, I would like to request, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, an oral amendment to our amendments numbers 6, 7 and 9 to correct an error. These amendments should only insert the qualifier ‘anonymised’ and not the words ‘or pseudonymised’. So, in other words, I request that the words ‘or pseudonymised’ be deleted from our amendments. This oral amendment affects amendment 6 twice and amendments 7 and 9 once respectively. It is needed to effectively preserve the confidentiality of medical conditions and to reflect the outcome of the Commission’s consultation on this point.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in this case, based on Rule 180(5) of our Rules of Procedure, on behalf of my Group I would like to withdraw our amendments 6, 7 and 9.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Okay, the amendments have been withdrawn. We shall therefore begin the vote with paragraph 23 - Amendment No 8.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as homophobic acts multiply in our society where insults, spitting, threats and physical attacks become the daily lives of a majority of people because of their sexual orientation, you now seem to be aware of the consequences of your policy. Unfortunately, your angelism in terms of migration policy distracts you from the real issues in this area. While homosexuality is punishable by death in many sub-Saharan African countries, a German study in 2015 revealed to us what many of us already knew, namely the link between religious fundamentalism and homophobia. It explained the strong rejection of homosexuals and transgender people in what left-wing ideologues call neighborhoods, which are in fact only territories confiscated by a political-religious ideology. What has changed since then is the massive importation, by an unseated and uncontrolled migratory flow, of populations originating from countries for whom religious dogma is the supreme norm. So I ask you, will the Commission finally deal with ...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, I am saddened by the actions of certain Member State governments when it comes to the disgraceful treatment of LGBTI citizens and voted in favour of the resolution to show my solidarity with these citizens. Has history not taught us the folly of separating one group of citizens from another? Equally, the idea that you can just create LGBTI—free zones is ludicrous and bemoans the ignorance of humanity. LGBTI citizens have every right to live, work and enjoy freedoms the rest of society enjoys. If certain Member States want to restrict the rights of their LGBTI citizens they need to think long and hard about whether it is compatible with their membership of the European Union. One of the proudest moments of my political life occurred in 2015 when the Irish people overwhelmingly, in a public vote, voted to extend civil right marriages to our LGBTI brothers, sisters, aunties, uncles, cousins, neighbours and friends. It is shameful that within our Union, there are still those who resist equality; it must be called out and opposed.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in July this year, the Gazeta Polska newspaper, one of the country's leading newspapers and supporter of the current Polish government, distributed stickers 'LGBTI free zone'. As a result, several local authorities in Poland have decided to declare themselves "free from LGBTI ideology" - this is what reactionaries call the ideal of equality. Poland is not an isolated case, it is a real crusade against equality that is taking place all over Europe. Because homophobia made institutional politics in several Central and Eastern European countries must not make us forget the homophobia that is also exploding in Western Europe, where acts of hatred are constantly multiplying: insults, widespread discrimination, assaults, murders. Human rights are universal and indivisible, those who attack the rights of LGBTI people are also those who attack women's rights, those who attack the rights of foreigners and migrants, those who attack the economic, social and cultural rights won by workers. An attack on certain rights is always an attack on all others. This resolution condemns the offensive against LGBTI rights in Poland; I agree, of course.

name: Sheila RITCHIE
text: – Mr President, the following comments have been made by members of the Polish LGBTI community: ‘Now it’s cool and trendy to be anti-gay, we don’t feel safe here’. PiS’s new focus on countering western LGBTI ideology has largely replaced its prior rallying calls against migrants. I see my colleague is no longer in the Chamber for me to call her out on her anti-sub-Saharan phobia, because it is the nature of phobia that you just choose another group to speak and act against. A PiS member of the regional parliament who led the campaign for the LGBT-free-zone declaration said recently: ‘For us, the whole LGBTQ thing is something abnormal. We feel it is a sick minority trying to impose itself on the healthy mainstream of society’. We were told in the debate that the Poles tolerated homophobia. They do not.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the climate of hatred fuelled by the Polish authorities towards the LGBTI community – and so is the attitude of those who justify violent verbal and physical attacks – is unacceptable.  When the fundamental rights of European citizens are being ful, the European Parliament is not watching, but the Commission and the Council must also condemn them.  That is why I am in favour of this motion for a resolution. That is why the process for the directive on non-discrimination and violence, which has been blocked in the Council for 11 years, must be completed. The legislative gap in protection against crimes generated by prejudice based on sexual orientation and gender identity must be filled. The rights of LGBTI people are fundamental rights, the European institutions and the Member States have a duty to respect and protect them in accordance with treaties, the Charter, as well as international law. Motions such as this make us realise that we are still in danger and that rights, even the right to love, must therefore also be defended. Europe, therefore, is not homophobic, put it in your head.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I understand, of course, the rights of the handicapped, but also the rights of all minorities. I am in the hope that everyone has their rights secured in general. I am, of course, against discrimination against LGBTI people. It should be recalled that such discrimination is contrary to fundamental constitutional principles as well as to European Union documents. I also believe that it is contrary to the Constitution and the law that Poland ensures. Indeed, declaring lgbti-free zones that are taking place in Poland could lead to hatred and homophobia, which is why I cannot agree to such a deal. However, I believe that this is an issue that Poland must resolve. I believe that polish citizens will oppose inciting hatred of their fellow citizens, of any ideology. That's why I've been delayed.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, once again we have a resolution called a ‘resolution on motherhood and apple pie’ that then turns out to say we need a common European policy on maternity and we need standardised European patisserie. I’m a libertarian: I’ve always found it utterly bewildering that governments should wish to discriminate against their citizens on grounds of sexual preference. I was an early supporter in my country of equality of the age of consent and of civil partnerships, but that isn’t what this motion’s about; it’s about the abuse of power to ‘Europeanise’ something where there is absolutely no basis in the European Treaties for Brussels involvement. And the reason these motions are repeatedly put down is solely as a sort of exercise so that virtue—signalling halfwits can then put out a press release saying: ‘X or Y voted against this and therefore doesn’t care about homophobia’. That is not the case. We care about due process. It is perfectly possible to believe in equality and dignity for all citizens, but also to believe in the sanctity of the ballot box and the democratic process.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, I strongly voted against the resolution, which supports and calls for LGBT propaganda and ideology in fraternal Poland. The Union must understand that there are still countries in Europe such as Poland, Hungary and Bulgaria where citizens believe that the family consists of a voluntary union between a woman, a man and their children. There are still places where people don't want to have anything to do with propaganda of debauchery and want solutions to the real problems that affect them.  The European Union has much more important issues ahead of it to deal with, rather than telling people how to live. Let's discuss them, let's let believers in family values and traditionalism decide for themselves where, with whom and how they want to live. The forced imposition of LGBT ideology, as well as the various child strategies that are already reflected in the building next door of the Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, is reminiscent of the troubled totalitarian times when the last word was to citizens, not dictators. With similar resolutions on the eve of the Nativity, the dictatorship is back, and this is unacceptable.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, LGBTI isn’t an ideology, it’s who people are. The point I want to make in my explanation of vote is that this resolution talks about homophobia in sport, and sadly, on occasion, and in places, that happens. What the resolution doesn’t talk about, though, that I want to mention, is the important role sport can play in tackling that homophobia. We’ve just had another very successful Stonewall Rainbow Laces campaign in football. I’m a member of the British Horseracing Authority’s diversity and inclusion steering group, and there’s really important, valuable work going on in British horseracing at the moment across the area of equality and diversity. So let me just make this point: unfortunately, sport sometimes is the arena of homophobia, but it’s also the place where we can help win the race to full equality and kick the homophobes and those who make homophobic abuse off the pitch for good.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Mr President, I abstained on this motion because it centres on criminalising hate speech, which is problematic and censorious. Who decides what’s ‘hate speech’? For example, in the UK, many of those labelled ‘transphobic’ are lesbians and feminists who won’t conform to the new intolerant transgender activists and their orthodoxies that actually demand that we women deny our bodies biologically and our autonomy.  Secondly, the EU’s attempts at disciplining other nation states and their democratic decisions because they won’t fit in with your orthodoxy does not win or help the arguments for equality. Bureaucratic imposition is not political victory. Passing motions is not winning hearts and minds.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, I voted against this resolution condemning Poland because I believe that the European Union should not interfere in the social policy of its Member States. I also denounce the discriminatory way in which the European Parliament treats Poland. He has already stigmatized it because of an alleged project to criminalize sex education, now he is attacking it because of stickers issued by some local authorities and bearing the inscription "area without LGBTI ideology". I condemn, of course, any discrimination against people on the basis of their sexual orientation. But, in this case, I think it is something else, a critique of the evil ideology of the genre. In any event, if clarification is necessary, the Union should ask Poland with respect, not by throwing such a brutal resolution in its face.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, in strongly adopting this Resolution against hate speech and discrimination on the on the subject, this European Parliament is making history, and it is making history when the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which prohibits discrimination on the way of sexual orientation, is 100 years old. It must therefore be said that it is nonsense – in this House – to have to listen that sexual orientation is an ideology. It's not. The freedom to love each other without discrimination on the other hand on the other hand is part of fundamental rights in the European Union and, therefore, the country that contradicts this is contradicting European Union law. At the time of Stonewall's anniversary, at the time of the anniversary of International Disability Day, as we recalled here yesterday, we need to know that there is a lot of Europe to be done; that when the 2020 Strategy is implemented, barriers to discrimination in employment, in health, but the most, the most intolerable discrimination is discrimination on the face of sexual orientation, and this is contrary to European law.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Mr President, I support this cross-party resolution on public discrimination and hate speech, whether online or not, against LGBTI people and express my solidarity in the ongoing fight for LGBTI rights across Europe and the globe. Tolerance and inclusiveness are the foundations upon which the EU was built and continues to build. We must work together in the fight on the ongoing backlash against LGBTI right across Europe. There is no room for LGBT-free zones across Europe or the continent or the globe. We must strongly support the role of education in promoting healthy relationships, self-respect and human rights and dignity. That’s particularly the case for girls across Europe. We must also protect the freedom of movement of LGBTI families through concrete measures and protection of the core EU rights as enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and we must not only defend them but expand them. So for example, in any free trade agreement, we must have an equality and human rights impact assessment, and if it fails, there is no deal.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted against this resolution because it is not homophobic to favour the traditional family of father, mother and children. Above all, however, I voted against this resolution because the European Parliament has once again shown today what a wonderful show event it is here. The rights of homosexuals are not strengthened by holding symbolic resolutions and Sunday speeches in the European Parliament, the rights of homosexuals are strengthened by consistently naming those who trample on the rights of homosexuals and who like to hang them on construction cranes. It is not the peoples of Europe who deny their rights to homosexuals, it is the culture that we import into Europe for millions and who are living out their murderous homophobia here. This must finally stop if we are serious about the rights of homosexuals!

name: Annika BRUNA
text: Mr President, while the condemnation of the violence suffered by homosexuals because of their orientation should be able to garner a broad consensus, including our delegation from the National Rally, the text voted today exploits this issue and requires our opposition. This resolution is a new opportunity for you to attack a Polish government which, on other issues, has not taken the liberal directions you demanded. Moreover, it misrepresents the rejection of LGBTI ideology, including legitimate opposition to gender theory, LDC and GPA, to homophobia. It unduly identifies populists as responsible for homophobic acts and speeches. At the same time, there is no link between immigration and the influence of Islam and the rise of homophobia in Europe, although statistics show this evidence. We reject any form of violence against homosexuals, but do not accept that you use this subject to convey your ideology and attack again a democratically elected Polish government.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! As Minister of the Interior and Administration, I have had the honour of sitting in the Law and Justice government, including a government that is being attacked in a wise and even pyramidal way today. As I hear from the representatives of the left that the Government of Law and Justice is discriminating against LGBT people in Poland today, I want to tell you that, as Minister of the Interior, I myself and my subordinate services, such as the police, have always protected people who felt threatened. It does not matter to me or to my government, my party, what sexual orientation a Citizen of the Republic is. Every citizen deserves protection, including homosexuals. I am ashamed, as a Pole, that these pyramidal nonsense, these pyramidal untruths that fall from your mouth here, were also inspired by representatives from Polish, the representatives sitting on the left side of the room. Unlike you, I am convinced, they know how much they lied. No one in Poland today persecutes homosexuals, does not persecute because of their sexual orientation. This is pyramidal nonsense, a pyramidal lie.

name: Martin HORWOOD
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to express my strong support for the resolution we’ve passed today in this Parliament against public discrimination and hate speech against LGBTI people. I have to tell Mr Brudziński and his Conservative colleagues that it is right, I’m afraid, to highlight the cases in Poland – cases which now include the extraordinary case of Bishop Szymon Niemiec of the Reformed Church in Warsaw, who is facing prosecution simply for conducting services of prayer and support for the LGBTI community in Warsaw. This is the kind of prosecution that completely fails to respect the underlying values of the European Union. LGBTI rights are human rights, and they must be respected.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Mr President, since 2002, Apple should have paid at least EUR 16 billion in additional tax in the European Union. French luxury giant Kering, which owns the Gucci and Saint Laurent brands, should have paid an extra 2.5 billion euros. Why are these multinationals exempting tax? Because you would have to be an idiot to keep paying for it when so many countries are reaching out to you with key tax evasion schemes. Competition from tax havens and loopholes in global tax rules have led to a deadly race to the bottom, which the European Union has failed to curb, and has even encouraged. However, Member States have a historic opportunity to weigh in on the ongoing negotiations at the OECD to reform these tax rules that allow multinationals not to pay their fair share of taxes. With this resolution, Parliament calls on them to be ambitious and to defend real tax justice measures, a minimum tax rate on businesses and a fair distribution of tax rights in countries. But we must not be satisfied with that. Without tax transparency or a credible list of tax havens, multinationals will continue to play with tax rules and European citizens will pay the price.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am very cautious and cautious on tax matters. I almost never vote for any unification within the European Union. In my opinion, the legislation is quite sufficient. But even this reservation of my could not have led me not to support this resolution. So I supported it for several reasons. Firstly, the proposals traditionally made by the European left have failed, for example, to the same percentage of corporate tax. I must say that the digitalisation of the economy is a very serious issue after clear joint action. Here, indeed, the tax revenues can go to different tax havens, it is a very simple way, and I welcome joint European action in this area of an economy that is really buoyed. That is why I supported this motion for a resolution after various left-wing proposals to improve this proposal have not passed.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I supported this proposal because I believe that we should make every effort to combat tax fraud and so-called creative accounting effectively.  I also share Parliament's call for the Commission and the Member States to meet the challenges of effectively taxing the digital economy in the Union. Finally, it is important to put an end to the situation where digital companies generate huge profits in the Member States, but do not pay any tax on this simply because they are established outside the European Union.  I believe that, in the absence of unanimity among the Member States, treaty procedures should be used to enable qualified majority voting on tax matters.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, while I welcome the initiative to begin discussions in this new Parliament on this complicated issue, unfortunately I was not able to support this resolution. This is an extremely complex issue, evidenced by the continuing deliberations at OECD level to find a solution for the fair taxing of digital companies. Let me be clear: I welcome efforts towards a fairer tax system in all EU Member States. Companies, like you or I, must pay their fair dues. However, we must also recognise that many large digital companies are international by nature. For this reason, I believe we must support the ongoing efforts at global, OECD level to find a solution to this problem by the end of next year. Unilateral action by the EU, as proposed in this Resolution, could damage our global competitiveness and even be perceived as an attack on US companies, potentially provoking retaliation. Still, I believe a continued, constructive debate on this issue will be important over the next 12 months.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, this morning we discussed in the presence of President Von der Leyen and the President of the Council, Charles Michel, the Council's conclusions on the tenth anniversary of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. And some spokesmen wondered how the Council had not considered the situation in Malta and others replied: why did it not consider the situation in Hungary, on which this Parliament adopted its resolution, or in Poland, in which the Commission took the initiative with the support of the European Parliament? The only way for the Council to do its job — because Parliament has done its own — is to adopt at once the framework of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights which has been adopted in the LIBE Commission and brought to the plenary of the European Parliament, to establish an objective, regular, periodic mechanism and, above all, to involve all Member States in compliance with the rules of the rule of law. And I would add: it is not tolerable that, at a time of budgetary constraints threatening traditional policies, including cohesion policy and regional policy, States that fail to comply with the rules of the rule of law should access European funds.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – (start speech with microphone turned off) ... Mr President, I am shocked by the latest news from Malta, corruption, gold visas, invoices in tax havens. The situation in politics there is clearly much worse than we imagined. To follow the murder of a journalist leading to the Prime Minister's office is outrageous and any responsible politician would resign immediately in such a situation.  Two years ago, my colleagues, some socialists, even tried to apologise to the Maltese Government, and it was precisely those who, on the other hand, were competing on how they would condemn governments that do not belong to their political option. They have double standards, double morals.  But corruption, political murders, a dysfunctionable rule of law happen elsewhere. I therefore call on the Commission to establish all possible grounds for a fair assessment of the rule of law according to all the same criteria for all.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution because I believe that the murder of a journalist in the context of European values in one of the countries of the European Union is such an extraordinary, huge crime that it is good that the European institutions are also dealing with it. Of course, we are not an investigating body, we cannot interfere with the independent activities of the judicial authorities in Malta. On the other hand, the foundations of the rule of law, the values of the rule of law, are European values and it is our moral duty at the moment to make it clear that we are making some kind of oversight of how political representation, but especially the judicial authorities in Malta, will investigate the matter. We will do our erms to ensure that these authorities actually act effectively, investigate the perpetrators of this heinous murder, this heinous crime, and that these perpetrators are punished, including, where appropriate, those from the political water circuit who, for example, had information and knowledge of this heinous crime.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Of course, I supported this resolution. The situation in which a journalist is murdered in a democratic state in a member state of the European Union and there are so many question marks is extremely appalling. And there could be no other attitude here than to support this resolution. On the other hand, I abstained at paragraph 8, because here there was a provision that Malta's non-implementation of the judicial reform could give rise to the initiation of the procedure provided for in Article 7. We have a situation where a journalist is murdered. We have a situation almost every week on the streets of Paris, in France, where people demonstrating are subjected to enormous repression by the police forces. People are dying. They are injured. We have the situation in Spain, in Barcelona. After all, we have a situation where Article 7 is not implemented in either of these countries, but is being implemented against my country, Polish. Why? That we are reforming the judiciary – the judiciary, which dates back to the time of the totalitarian state of communism. Well, there's some kind of logical inconsistency here.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, bees and the health of all pollinators is an issue of key importance to the public. The importance of pollinators for agriculture, food production, biodiversity and the landscape has been well covered in the parliamentary debates here, but the plight and survival of the bee has really captured the imagination and the hearts of the public, and we, as legislators, must respond to this and act accordingly and responsibly. This week in west Cork, in my own constituency, a new association has been set up to promote and champion the cause of the bee. The Fastnet Area Beekeepers’ Association has been established by Mairead and Michael Love to support beekeepers and will seek to educate those who wish to establish their own hives. Community-led initiatives like this are replicated across Ireland and Europe and it is essential that the future common agricultural policy (CAP) has the tools and the measures to support beekeepers. It might be a dream, but wouldn’t it be fantastic if every farm had at least one beehive?

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, I have strongly supported this text, which is even more alarming on the extremely worrying issue of pollinators in Europe and, more broadly, in the world. If this text calls for a tougher European initiative of the Commission of 1 June 2018 on pollinators, it is because the current situation has become catastrophic. The mass disappearance of pollinating insects, domestic or wild, is a threat to the survival of our societies, our ecosystems and to biodiversity in general. Agricultural production is largely dependent on pollination, it is a free service that bees give us. If they were to disappear, whole parts of our economy would collapse, our agriculture in the first place. For example, China, where entire regions have seen their insects disappear, is forced to pollinate entire fields by hand. Therefore, there is an urgent need to go beyond this text, to go to the heart of our collective responsibility and to support all the solutions that will guarantee the survival of pollinators.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I will not repeat what I said when discussing this report by Mrs McGuinness. I just want to thank you for this report and to give my appreciation for the fact that the European Parliament, with such great support, has agreed a report that makes concrete proposals on how to deal with the situation of pollinators and bees. We all agree that something needs to be done, because it is not just about biodiversity, but is essentially about farmers being able to continue working, because the declining pollinator population means a lower harvest. So we want farmers not to be considered pests, but to get support to manage the landscape well, and also to replace pesticides that are removed, which they can no longer work with, with other, effective preparations.

name: István UJHELYI
text: – As shadow reporter for S&D, i.e. as a carer for the subject on the part of S&D, I would like to thank the plenary of the European Parliament for supporting our proposal and for adopting the resolution on the EU initiative on pollinators by a large majority. In yesterday's debate, I argued at length why this report should be voted on, and it was obviously essentially a matter for Parliament to look at from the point of view of legislation and the encouragement of the Commission's work. Now, as a kind of closing word, let me add that we need to take the new green deal seriously. But not just here in Parliament, but as a private citizen. We need to change our habits, change our everyday, familiar activities. This is also the case for pollinators, insects, bees. That is why I supported the proposal, as a private person and as a decision-maker.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Mr President, I often warn against hasty, ideologically motivated actions and warn that these actions will have consequences. Ten years ago, this Parliament approved the promotion of biofuels in the name of green ideology. We can see the result – fields of yellow rapeseed wherever you look. The Czech Prime Minister takes subsidies for them and then benefits from them, conflict of interest as embroidered, we talked about it here yesterday. The fields are full of herbicides and pesticides, roundup calls it. Victims? Millions of bees and other pollinators are dying, tragedy. That is why I was happy to support today's initiative, but we should not forget one thing that the European Parliament also paved the way for this tragedy ten years ago.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, bees and their well-being is undoubtedly a matter of particular importance not only for me and for my country Bulgaria, but also for Europe. That is why I supported the motion for a resolution on the European Union pollinator initiative. The prohibition of pesticides dangerous for bees and pollinator insects is undoubtedly important. However, we must consider a realistic approach and realistic expectations.  Conclusions that are not based on scientific facts do not help anyone. Some proposals in this resolution were too extreme and unfounded. The protection of the beekeeping sector and pollinators certainly does not go through a declaration of war on other farmers who use insecticides and pesticides in a legal way. There are also safe pesticides on the market that can be used wisely and, according to the regulations laid down, do not harm pollinators. There needs to be a balanced approach that protects pollinators and the beekeeping industry on the one hand, but whoever allows farmers to do their job.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I will only say what my colleagues have said. At first glance, this topic looks like a subject that does not fall within the remit of the European institutions, the European Parliament. It is a subtle subject, but really extremely serious in terms of impact. This means that it is good that the European Parliament is also dealing with the issue of pollinators. We are dealing with a possible disaster that may occur for agriculture in the countries of the European Union by further rapidly declining the number of bees and other pollinators, and that this can indeed have both large and far-reaching economic consequences. I supported this report, let us look for a path that does not bring about liquidation, weakening the competitiveness of European agriculture, but which, at the same time, will allow the number of pollinators not to decrease further.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, it is clear that the digitisation of health care has become an inevitable reality. Technological advances, the deepening of the knowledge of our human body and its functioning have reached such a level that the next revolution can be only digital. More and more sums in this area - almost 10% of the Eu's GDP - demonstrate this: this is a crucial issue. This resolution, which we fully support, underlines the paradoxical challenge of data collection in an advanced world where gathering as much information as possible for more research is a necessity. It is important to put safeguards in place; data must be anonymized while facilitating its access and, at the same time, protecting it. And let's not forget that health remains a regal prerogative. The second challenge is patient and physician accountability. This digitization, this facilitation of health must not make us forget that all technological advances will not be able to replace a doctor who examines. Not all possible databases will erase the individual's uniqueness.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution because I believe that digitalisation certainly improves health care, accessibility, efficiency and is one of the solutions to the shortage of medical staff. These problems will be even greater as the population ages. Modern technologies can partially replace the presence of a doctor. Nowadays, when the active part of the population in particular prefers the possibility of eHealth, this is certainly the way to go. But it is necessary to remember the older generation and people who do not yet know how to work with digital technologies or do not have a connection. Therefore, even when introducing these eHealth services, it is necessary to remember the availability and facilities and training of staff. At the same time, I want to stress that the relationship between patient and doctor must never be disturbed.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I have been sitting on these benches for five years and I am saddened to find that very little is being said at European level about the health care of European citizens. I know that we have abandoned this issue, the organisation of this for the governments of the Member States, but we cannot tolerate it any longer, I find it untenable that someone's state of health, quality of life, prospects depend on the Member State in which they were born. It is untenable that there are differences in the quality and quality of healthcare that create an incomparably different situation for a Western European or an Eastern European, such as my Member State, my country, Hungary. That is why I am committed to creating a european minimum health service programme. Let us have specific standards under which we can provide every single European citizen with the same quality of health service in the future. I look forward to your support for this.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution. There’s no doubt in my mind that technology, digital development and better use of data can add real value and help improve all parts of the health and care system at a national level, at a European level, and indeed at a local level as well. However, we have to be cautious with this and we have to ensure the strongest possible safeguards and protections of some of that data, particularly people’s individual healthcare data, which – when aggregated to a population level – can help the development of new health technologies, new treatments, and indeed the strengthening of our health systems. We have to be particularly cautious in how we think about that data becoming a commercial product. We have to have the right safeguards and protections in place to protect this data.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar an rúin seo. Is féidir le r—shláinte feabhas a chur ar chúram sláinte faoin tuath in Éirinn – go háirithe i gcás meabhairshláinte. In Éirinn, tógann sé go leor ama chun coinne i bpearsa a fháil le comhairleoirí, síceolaithe agus síciatraithe. Tá ciall le seirbhísí comhairleoireachta a fháil go digiteach. Ach do cheisteanna faoi shláinte mheabhrach, níl gá i gcónaí le coinne i bpearsa. Mar sin féin, tá na seirbhísí sin ag brath ar leathanbhanda ardluais in Éirinn. Tá rialtas na hÉireann an-mhall go deo ag forbairt an phlean leathanbhanda. Gan an plean sin, ní bheidh na teicneolaíochtaí nua r—shláinte ar fáil in Éirinn cosúil le Ballstáit eile san Aontas.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 162) on Compatibility between the current EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement and the Commission’s proposal for a European Green Deal (2019/2976(RSP)). I should like to inform Members that for this debate there is no catch-the-eye procedure and that no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: representing the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, for environmentalists, having the green pact at the heart of the European agenda is great news, it is a great success. This is a great success for scientists who have been alerting us for years. This is a great success for the citizens who are mobilizing, for the companies that are starting to act. Of course, it is also a success for environmentalists, through the European elections. And it is a success for the world's youth who are mobilizing on these issues and calling for action. It is also an incredible opportunity, an opportunity for Europe to develop a shared project, a common horizon, to put our public policies at the service of technological, social and democratic innovation, at the service of the relocation of the economy, the creation of sustainable jobs in all our territories, more democracy. It is also an opportunity for our fellow Europeans to regain control of their lives, to regain control of their food, their movements, their housing, their energy, when our societies are so divided, so fractured today. The promise is strong, and the stronger the promise, the less it can be betrayed. The Green Pact cannot be a relabellization of a status quo, it can't be just a little bit more, just a little better, it can't be the same reassigned or re-labeled budget. We need profound transformations; We need breaks. Today, we need public investment of 1% of European GDP each year. We have saved the banks, we can save the climate, we can save the living, especially if it creates jobs and boosts the European economy. So if the green pact is to save the climate, it is to save the living, it is to revitalize our economy, it is to create jobs, at that time, the agreement with Mercosur cannot be signed. The agreement with Mercosur should not even be considered, as we all know, we have discussed it. Deforestation in Brazil has been doubled this year with Bolsonaro. We know how much this president attacks human rights every day, whether it is women, the freedoms of activists, indigenous peoples or homosexuals. We cannot, in the name of the values of Europe, in the name of climate, in the name of the living, go towards this agreement. The agreement with Mercosur, if summed up in broad strokes, is to export German cars to import beef and soybeans. This cannot be the Europe of the Green Pact, because this Europe is a Europe that contributes to the globalisation of junk food, the globalisation of animal suffering, the globalisation of deforestation, the globalisation of climate change and the globalisation of the disappearance of peasants in the mercosur countries as in Europe. As we know, our agricultural model depends on imports of plant protein. Each year, the equivalent of Germany's surface area is imported in plant protein. We must therefore not simply stop this negotiation with Mercosur, we must review our common agricultural policy and the version, the proposal that you, as Commissioner for Agriculture, Mr Hogan, cannot correspond to the Green Pact for Europe. More intensive livestock farming, fewer farmers, more concentration and pesticides, this cannot be the impact of a Europe of the Green Pact. Let's change the CAP and change our trade policy; it's necessary. The Green Pact can be this great opportunity for Europe. Mrs von der Leyen this morning said: 'We must listen to the european citizens, listen to them, they do not want Mercosur, they want us to act with ambition and concrete actions on climate, biodiversity and democracy'.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the topical debate proposed is one of great relevance, as it comes only a week after the presentation by the Commission of its proposal for a European Green Deal.  There can be no doubt that we face immense climate and environmental challenges. Europe needs to play its part in responding to these. If we do not, generations to come will question why we did not act decisively. The status quo is not an option. The EU needs to take the lead and work collectively to transform our economy and societies in order to put them on a more sustainable path.  I will leave it to the Commission to describe its policy proposals in more detail. The Council has not had time to discuss them, and it would be premature for me to take a position at this early stage. I can only say that the Council will engage constructively in examining the proposed policies and measures needed to achieve the European Green Deal. The Green Deal strategy cuts across almost every policy sector and will require careful consideration and coordination.  Against this background, I would like to focus my comments today on the Mercosur Trade Agreement. I’m sure that many Members of this House feel very strongly about the trade deal reached with Mercosur. I know that you have discussed it – for instance, recently, following the forest fires which have been ravaging the Amazon region. This is, indeed, deeply worrying for us all.  Just like here in the European Parliament, the discussion in the Council on the EU—Mercosur Agreement is still at an early stage. It is clear that sufficient time will be needed for a comprehensive examination of the negotiated agreement. Concerns that the trade agreement with Mercosur should be sustainable, also from the point of view of our green agenda, are fully understandable. What trade agreements can contribute to this objective is to export EU standards and sustainability goals to third countries. They can be a vehicle to convince others to implement ambitious environmental and climate policies and form part of a global response to climate change. Millions of jobs in the EU, as well as people’s livelihoods, depend on trade. We need to make sure that trade can take place, whilst ensuring that it supports sustainable development and the EU’s climate goals and contributes to a sustainable future.  I would like to recall that the Mercosur Agreement contains a robust trade and sustainable development chapter. This lives up to the highest standards, comparable to those in other modern agreements, such as the Free Trade Agreement with Japan or the trade part of the modernised Global Agreement with Mexico. The Mercosur Agreement contains a specific article on climate change, committing the parties to effectively implement the Paris Agreement. There were also commitments on fighting deforestation. Private—sector initiatives strengthened these commitments, for example not to source meat from farms in recently deforested areas.  The trade and sustainable development chapter includes commitments regarding the sustainable management of forests. It safeguards relevant initiatives on sustainable agriculture. This includes EU private—sector actions on zero—deforestation supply chains and producer—led initiatives, such as the soy moratorium in Brazil to limit the expansion of soy plantations in forest land. The trade and sustainable development chapter also includes thematic articles on trade—related aspects of natural resources, such as biodiversity, forests and fisheries, including combating illegal logging. The agreement provides a platform to actively engage with Mercosur countries on sustainable development issues. The agreement lists a number of areas of potential cooperation with a view to ensuring that trade supports the sustainability agenda. It also offers civil society organisations an active role to overview the implementation of the agreement, including any environmental concerns.  Finally, the trade and sustainable development chapter is fully legally binding and enforceable. It is subject to a specific dispute settlement procedure, under which a complaint concerning non—compliance is first considered in formal government consultations. If the situation is not resolved, then an independent panel of experts can be requested to examine the matter and make recommendations. The report and recommendations must be made public so that they can be followed up by stakeholders, as well as by the relevant institutions of the parties. I know that many of you will strive for a stronger enforcement mechanism – even with sanctions. This matter has been discussed in the Parliament as well as in the Council. On this basis, the Commission unveiled a 15—point plan to make the EU sustainable development chapters more robust and effective. As shown in the bilateral dispute settlement case of Korea, these are not just empty words. What was obtained from Mercosur in terms of environmental and sustainability commitments is the outcome of very long and arduous negotiations. These commitments are a challenge for the Mercosur countries, but one they are ready to assume. We can be confident that an agreement with Mercosur that contributes to sustainable trade with the region, including a binding commitment by the Mercosur countries to implement the Paris climate deal, will provide the EU with the necessary leverage to pursue our ambitious climate and sustainability goals. The recent forest fires in the Amazon are representative of the sustainability challenges facing Mercosur, but I am convinced that it is only through working with Mercosur that we can get the change and global transformation we so much want to see.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’m pleased to have the opportunity to contribute to this debate and I welcome the opportunity to participate in a discussion which brings together a central plank of the von der Leyen Commission, the European Green Deal, and a key element of our international trade policy, the EU-Mercosur Agreement. The European Green Deal, which President von der Leyen presented to this House last week, is, as she said, the EU’s new growth strategy. It’s an opportunity to improve the health and wellbeing of our people and our planet by transforming our economic model. It sets out an ambitious roadmap for the EU to become climate neutral by 2050, cutting emissions, restoring the health of our natural environment, protecting our wildlife, creating new economic opportunities and improving the quality of life of our people. This will require important changes to our economy, our energy mix, our industrial processes, our production and consumption, and it is clear that our trade policy will have to play its part. We will ensure this is done at the multilateral, bilateral and unilateral level, coherent with our existing international agreements in the WTO and in our bilateral agreements, such as the EU-Mercosur Association Agreement. I believe that this agreement can contribute to achieving the goals of the Green Deal in a number of ways, and I say this as somebody who has been involved in the negotiations. As is the case with the recent EU trade agreements, it will include a ‘trade and sustainable development’ chapter. This chapter includes a legally-binding commitment to effectively implementing the Paris Agreement. This means that we will be able to engage with Brazil, as well as with the other Mercosur countries, on what they have pledged to achieve by 2030 under the Paris Agreement. That was not the case before the agreement was signed. This covers pledges from Brazil to achieve zero illegal deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon, to restore and reforest 12 million hectares of forests, and to curb illegal and unsustainable forest practices. This is what is in the agreement. The trade and sustainability chapter (TSD) also addresses issues such as biodiversity, circular economy, waste management and responsible business conduct in supply chains. All of these are important areas and important aspects of the Green Deal. The TSD chapter recognises the right of both sides to take measures and base legislation on the precautionary principle. This is the first time that this has been explicitly stated in an agreement with a major agricultural exporting block. The agreement will therefore help keep our consumers healthy, but it also will safeguard our high environmental and food-safety standards. The ‘political and cooperation’ part of the agreement foresees cooperation based on the UN Framework Convention on climate change and the Paris Agreement. In order to work together towards the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, you will also find in this part of the agreement provisions for dialogue and cooperation on issues such as oceans, seas and energy. This gives us the tools that the European Union does not possess today in its relationship with the Mercosur countries. The agreement with Mercosur contributes to the Green Deal objectives in other ways as well. Many green goods will be liberalised. It will be easier to provide environmental services. The agreement will help lower the carbon footprint of production in Mercosur. The agreement will encourage green public procurement and sustainable procurement practices. Strong IPR rules and improved enforcement frameworks will facilitate a more extended use of environmental and green technology transfer. Let us also not forget the benefits from enhanced civil society involvement in the implementation of the whole agreement, including the TSD implementation. This allows civil society in third countries to hold their governments to account, just as they do in the European Union. As always, implementation is key, and we need to take a more assertive trade and sustainable stance in our TSD policy, in line with the 15-point action plan for TSD implementation which was agreed in February 2018. I can assure this Parliament that the Commission will remain vigilant in this work and in this task. As you know, the Commission will soon appoint a chief trade enforcement officer. This will be an important new role, not only for market access issues but, equally, for trade and sustainability issues, on which we will all acknowledge there is an important and increasing focus. So my conclusion is clear. The EU-Mercosur agreement not only can, but is an essential part of any agreement internationally to support the Green Deal in many ways.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Greens are asking whether the Mercosur agreement is compatible with the Green Deal. The clear answer is yes. What is more, the agreement is even a necessary contribution to the Green Deal, just as Commissioner Hogan said. It is a milestone in legal history because, as Commissioner Hogan has also said, we will have for the first time an enforcement mechanism in a plurilateral trade agreement for the environment and social standards. We will establish a standard that we would not have without the agreement. And that is why the real question is: what if we did not sign the agreement, if we did not agree to it? Of course, trade will then also take place, only without rules, without standards. With this agreement, we are taking the step from unregulated free trade to rules-based fair trade. Do you really want to refuse this progress from the very beginning of the discussion, without knowing the agreement more precisely? We will only have influence in the world if we conclude these agreements. We saw it in the summer: even before it came into force, the agreement had already built up political pressure to fight forest fires in the Amazon, thereby protecting natural areas. You just don't see that! Remember the spectacle you have played in the TTIP and CETA agreements. Even then, you covered us with these horror stories: social dismantling, the erosion of democracy, environmental degradation. None of this has happened. It really would be time for the cheerleaders of these fear campaigns to apologise to European citizens instead of once again stirring up half-truths of sentiment against a new trade agreement. If we want climate protection to go beyond your symbolic policy and declarations of emergency, then we Europeans must not only lead the way, but also ensure that the rest of the world follows our standards. And this agreement is an important step on the way to achieving this.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, as has been said before, Europe is at the doorstep of a new era. With the new Green Deal, we want to ensure a future that is more just, more sustainable and completely climate-proof. At the same time, we also had to face an unsuccessful COP in Madrid last week, let’s be honest, and one of the parties that was part of the negotiating team that led to that disappointing result was Brazil. ‘I won’t protect any part of the rainforest that can be exploited.’ Those are Bolsonaro’s words. Could it be any clearer? And let’s be frank at the beginning of this term. It is unthinkable that our farmers, our manufacturers, have to make a huge effort in the new Green Deal and at the same time trade policies will remain as they stand. We cannot open our markets to these countries that – at the same time – try to profit from social and environmental competition and a race to the bottom.  Let me be clear, and I said this to you, Commissioner, informally. Let me say it formally. I don’t think there is today a majority in Parliament to agree on the FTA with Mercosur. It will not fly as it stands.  And I have no proof of that, but I have some experience in this Parliament. So let me outline what is important for the S&D in the coming year.  First of all, we want the Brazilians – the Mercosur countries, but Brasilia in particular – to take a different attitude with the international states. If they want to be our partners in trade, they need to be our partners as well when it comes to measures on climate change. Secondly, we want pre-ratification conditions. We want to have a change in the policies in Brazil on the Amazon. And last but not least – and I’m looking to the Council in particular, but also to the Commissioner – I want to remind you that we, the Parliament, have a long-standing demand to make the TSD chapters legally much more enforceable, and that includes sanctions, because otherwise the paper on which the TSD chapter is written is useless. We should use less paper and take more action.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, why are we here today discussing the compatibility of the Mercosur Agreement with the European Green Pact and not all trade agreements to be ratified? Because this debate is flawed, it is flawed in origin and is only seeking and intending to seek a new enemy. Some needed a new "Z". They've already found it: Mercosur. And this is what Mr Jadot has shown, and he has made it very clear.  President von der Leyen said in the presentation of the European Green Pact that trade policy can serve to collaborate with our partners in climate and environmental action, with the Paris Agreement being an essential element of any international agreement.  Well, does this Agreement incorporate these principles? Let's see, do you have a specific chapter dedicated to sustainable development and environmental protection? Yes. Does it include compliance with the Paris Agreement as a binding part of the Agreement? Yes. Have the Mercosur countries ratified the Paris Agreement and committed to implementing it? Yes. So, if so, why so many misgivings, criticisms, fears and apocalyptic visions? Because, ladies and gentlemen, for our climate strategy to have a real global impact, we need partners to join it. And we can only achieve that on the basis of agreements. And this is the most modern of those we have signed to achieve these goals. It will not be with opportunistic or populist demagoguery that we will put out the amazon fires, but with commitment, with cooperation and agreement. Because this agreement goes far beyond the strictly commercial. It is a signed agreement between partners and allies who share democracy as a political system, respect for the rule of law and human rights and who believe in a multilateral system linked to rules. Sister countries that want to not only trade with us, but live as and with us. It is also the first block-by-block agreement signed by Mercosur that consolidates existing trade relations, alleducing them to mutually indispensable common commitments, values that this Agreement recognizes, respects and obliges. And for all this, and although this debate has been driven by those who are always against any treaty – with the support of some who want to divert attention from national problems by lying on climate savonarolas, based their criticisms on disrecognisment, prejudice, fake news or lies – we will study this Agreement, its implications, its real benefits. And finally, in the face of the question of whether the Free Trade Agreement between Mercosur and the European Union and the Commission's proposal for a European Green Pact are compatible, we will be able to answer with a resounding yes.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, the Commission has made the Green Deal a key project for the next five years. I very much welcome this, because it is a response to the Commission not only to the devastating climate and environmental crisis, but also to the tens of thousands of young people who have been taking to the streets every week throughout Europe for the past year.  Commission President von der Leyen herself says that the EU will be climate neutral by 2050. In order to achieve this objective, action is needed in all sectors of the economy. But I now ask you directly, Mr Hogan: how does this clear announcement by Mrs von der Leyen fit in with the current trade policy? Yes, let us take the Mercosur Agreement, which undermines all our climate efforts. Mercosur will lead to more imports of meat, dairy products and ethanol. It will make soya imports even cheaper, and all these products must be grown somewhere. 20% of the entire Amazon has already fallen victim to bulldozers and fires. The rate of deforestation in Brazil doubled last year, so that soya, beef and raw material for ethanol can be grown on this large area. We are looking for an ecological crisis. Soon the rainforest has reached the tipping point, and thus one of the most important ecosystems on earth is on the verge of collapse. The EU promotes this with its trade policy, making a pact with Bolsonaro that tramples on human rights and sabotages the entire climate negotiations in Madrid.  In the Green Deal, the Commission promises to change the agricultural industry in Europe, reduce the use of pesticides and fertilisers and protect The European forest. The Mercosur Agreement is doing the opposite abroad – it is schizophrenic. If we are really serious about the Green Deal, then we also need to change our trade policy. Because, as we know, the trade agreements lay down the economic rules for decades, set them in stone, as in a constitution. Ladies and gentlemen, now is the time to take the helm. Now is the time for a different trade policy, for a different agreement with the Mercosur countries. We need sustainable supply chains, and for that the Commission must finally come up with a law. Environmental and social standards must be enforceable and not a toothless tiger, as is the case. Products need to be differentiated according to their carbon footprint and production processes, and we urgently need climate protection to be anchored in all chapters of trade agreements. We certainly do not need a Mercosur agreement that kills the rainforest.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Mercosur agreement could have been a success story. 35% import duties on cars from Europe in Argentina and Brazil have been a huge barrier to trade so far. So it would have been a historic opportunity for this industry, and the initial announcements from the automotive industry to conclude – or conclude the negotiations – were accordingly positive.  Then not only was a new candidate for the Presidency of the Commission conjured up, but also a Green Deal, which completely calls into question the current production matrix of our economy, and also teasingly garnished with the image of a lunar mission. What do we want to export? Neither in terms of infrastructure nor purchasing power are the countries of Mercosur in a position to use electric vehicles, which are now being pressed into European production lines in accordance with ordre du mufti. South America will continue to depend on the incinerator as the engine of individual locomotion. So exactly the type of drive that the Green Deal is now putting an end to. Let us be clear: our companies, with headquarters and production sites within the EU, may be at the mercy of the political mistakes here – as in other capitals such as Berlin – and our trading partners are certainly not, because they can choose new partners. When in doubt, they look for someone who doesn't drive a new ideological sow through the place for a long time.  That is why the picture of the lunar mission that the President of the Commission painted on the Green Deal is perhaps not so wrong. In any case, the men of the Apollo 13 mission had the goal of getting to the moon, and the Green Deal is already reminiscent of that. After the explosion of an oxygen tank, the astronauts were left only to reverse halfway. This is precisely what the Commission is threatening with its Harakiri manoeuvre to squeeze the Green Deal into the globalised world economy, which is about cost advantages and market shares, but certainly not about ideologies.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European Commission wants to be a geopolitical Commission. She wants to create jobs. She wants to create prosperity. It wants to fight climate change and involve our partners around the world. Well, this agreement with Mercosur lives up to these ambitions. We are strengthening ties with Latin America. Our companies are the first to have preferential access to a market that has been closed to date. This will create huge jobs in the European Union, but also in our partner countries. This agreement contains a very strong sustainability agreement. We set the bar high. The Paris agreements are an essential part of it. There are measures against deforestation and agreements on reforestation. The precautionary principle is included. What's more, our partner countries, in turn, must adopt these standards in their trade agreements, which is why the European Union sets global standards. Dispute settlement is a smart, sensible arrangement with dialogue, monitoring and capacity building. That is much better than a negative sanctions regime which the partners will not accept anyway. They are partners of ours with whom we need to engage in dialogue. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, do you think for a moment that we are not concluding this agreement, are we better off? No, we will be worse off, and our partner countries will be worse off.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The agreement between the EU and the Mercosur countries has been under negotiation for 20 years. The result is disappointing! An outdated, very general mandate from the European Council to the Commission – given in the last millennium without any involvement of the European Parliament – became a free pass for neoliberal free trade. The many new weightings of the sustainability chapters in trade agreements, the priority of human rights, environmental protection and employment standards as prerequisites for economic and social development, which have been won in recent years, are ignored. Just a few days after the disappointing COP 25 in Madrid, we are asking, and rightly so, that the agreement is compatible with the Green Deal announced by the President of the Commission? Does it contribute to the implementation of the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals? A very clear no! Just one example – Objective 13: the country with the largest rainforest in the world ignores its responsibilities, just as the Commission and many member governments ignore its responsibilities. The Mercosur Agreement will continue to promote the long-term destruction of the Amazon region in favour of the expansion of agricultural land under the conditions of today's market logic. It thus undermines the Green Deal project to preserve biodiversity. Therefore, it is quite clear that if you, the Commission, want to make climate protection the focus of your work, legally enforceable commitment to environmental and climate protection is part of it. That is missing. Just like the Green Deal's plan to launch sustainable production policies. If the Green Deal and international trade policy are to be brought into coherence, there is only one sensible alternative: stop the current agreement!

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 906 000 hectares of Amazon forest were lost in 2019. It is as if a third of Belgium had burned down in a few months.  I do not know what other evidence it takes to understand that the agreement with latin American countries will have a heavy and negative impact on the environment.
