The fires that we saw in the summer and which continue to this day are arson, aimed at creating new land for cultivation and, above all, pastures, which alone are responsible for 80 % of all the deforestation of the Amazon.  But deforestation is not the only environmental problem in the agreement. We are well aware that there are no limits or specific sanctions for the use of pesticides and fish exploitation, especially in Argentina and Uruguay, or the mismanagement of water resources, as is the case in Paraguay and Uruguay.  And in your opinion, if these are the promises, what effect can an agreement designed to export more meat and agricultural products to Europe have? What is the point of telling our producers to pollute less, to force them to comply with the highest standards, when their competitors in the world do not have to comply with even one of these obligations? What is the point of limiting emissions in Europe, when fires in the Amazon produced 140 million tonnes of CO2 in a single summer?  Ladies and gentlemen, the environment knows no frontiers. The Amazon is our lung, and we, we must be the first to protect it. It is true that world trade is under attack. The European Union is in a hurry to react by concluding new agreements, but on this agreement as it is now we are not convinced, we want to see more guarantees for European farmers, an action plan to protect the Amazon through applicable sanctions aimed at environmental constraints.  I will end, Mr President: trade is important, it is essential. Latin America is a strategic partner for Europe, but it cannot be at the expense of the citizens and the protection of the environment, which is everyone's.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, welcome Commissioner Hogan, with your new title as Trade Commissioner. I wish you well for the future. I’m tempted to say you’ve moved out of the frying pan into the fire, because neither portfolios are particularly easy. I think it’s interesting that we’re talking today in this Chamber about two things which have yet to see a life, if you like. One is an agreement reached but not yet implemented, the other is a three-word title that we’ve yet to see the details of, and we’re panicking already. I remember way back when Peter Mandelson was the Trade Commissioner in your very seat, and at that time Irish farmers were particularly alarmed about any prospect of a trade agreement, so you know exactly the point I want to make. It would be helpful if you could give us some reassurances as to what impact you think this deal will have on European farmers, whether there will be a reduction in meat production within Europe to satisfy the demands of this trade agreement and whether that is a good or bad arrangement.  This morning we voted on a resolution on how to protect pollinators and indeed restore their status, and one of the things that was dealt with was pesticides, plant protection products and a real push to try and use less, and indeed some colleagues would want to ban everything. I don’t think we can do that when it comes to Mercosur. We have no control, and many times when we’ve debated this I’ve been told there is equivalence. Is it better now in this deal, this idea of equivalence? How can we guarantee that the very strong and, I have to say, fine words you spoke in your speech about the depth of this deal around environmental and other issues – how can we be sure that they will actually be implemented in the Mercosur countries?

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The advantage of the debate is that the Mercosur agreement is not yet ready. We expect a signature perhaps in 2021, and that, of course, gives time to develop the agreement further. And I think we need to develop the agreement further, because some things are unresolved. It is true that there is a sustainability chapter calling for the implementation and implementation of the Paris climate agreement, where sustainable forestry is called for and where compliance with the core labour standards of the International Labour Organisation is also required. On the other hand, however, we see that under Bolsonaro there is 60% more illegal clearing of the Amazon forest than before, that 150 pesticides have been re-authorised, which are not permitted in Europe, that the land security of the indigenous population is no longer regulated by law, and above all that two laws have been enacted which clearly contradict ILO standards 98 and 87. , that is, constitute a violation of exactly what was envisaged in the agreement. That is why, in my view, it can only be a matter of really moving three things forward now. The first is that we need a monitoring system. It must be ensured that products from illegally deforested areas cannot enter the European Union. It is not enough for this to be written down without sufficient possibility of verification. Secondly, we must also make the good approaches in the sustainability chapter feasible, concrete steps on how the issue of sustainable forestry should actually be implemented and how to ensure compliance with workers' rights. Thirdly, we really need an enforcement mechanism that works. And, Minister, Korea is showing that the mechanisms that have been put in place are not working. This is a toothless tiger, and we really need a tiger that can bite.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: – Madam President, the fires in the Amazon forest this summer and the sometimes disgraceful rhetoric from the Brazilian leadership about the climate have understandably stirred a lot of concerns about the Mercosur Agreement. But let’s take a deep breath and look at the facts. The Mercosur Agreement already contains binding references to the Paris Agreement. In fact, this deal would make the Paris Agreement more effective, not less, because it would anchor our climate commitment in mutually beneficial trade. I agree with the science that very ambitious measures must be taken to save the climate. Living up to the commitments in the Paris Agreement will be totally impossible if we don’t do it together. The free trade agreement between the EU and Mercosur gives us a unique opportunity to cooperate, to put pressure on and create incentives for all partners to take responsibility. Modern trade deals with binding chapters on sustainability are the most efficient forms of international cooperation, so let us use trade policy as a tool to save the climate instead of treating it like an enemy of the climate. This deal would make trade more sustainable in a better legal framework. This is an opportunity we can’t refuse.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Madam President, is the Europe-Mercosur agreement compatible with the ambitions of the Green Pact for Europe? Yes, the European Commission assures us: all future trade agreements will have to be compatible with the Paris agreement. But how can we achieve a zero-carbon society in 2050 while pursuing free trade treaties as we have for 20 years? The Mercosur agreement will boost CO2 emissions. Did you know that, for the agricultural sector in the case of the agricultural sector, the additional amount of CO2 emissions will be equivalent to the amount of emissions generated annually in Brussels? At the COP in Madrid, Brazil stood out by preventing an ambitious climate agreement. And so, no, the EU-Mercosur agreement does not guarantee that Brazil will be bound by the Paris agreement, contrary to what the Commission claims. The Green Pact provides that all sectors contribute to the ecological and social transition. All sectors, and yet there are two, the agricultural model and trade policy, which will not achieve the objectives of the Green Pact if they are not profoundly reformed. The Europe-Mercosur agreement is a real test of credibility for the Green Pact. To ratify the first is to ruin the chances of success of the second.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Madam President, although the Mercosur deal will result in a significant increase in exports of EU manufactured products, it will not have the same positive effect in the European agriculture sector, which is already facing an unprecedented crisis. And, furthermore, unequal CAP funding also contributes to the agricultural crisis in many countries, like in my own country – Estonia. And then to add to this the new State religion: climate change. Billions of euros will be spent transforming European society in order to achieve so-called carbon neutrality by 2050, and this while countries such as China and India feel no CO2 shame and happily continue to grow their economies. This new Green Deal will come at a terrible cost to the most valuable and treasured members of our society: those who provide us with food, our farmers.  Apart from the effect the Green Deal will have on the agricultural sector, it will also gravely affect countries relying on fossil fuels for energy supply, and as a result the workers that earn their living in these sectors.  And let’s take again Estonia as an example. My country is largely self-sufficient when it comes to energy supply but relies heavily on its domestic oil shale reserves for this. With a new Green Deal, Estonia will be forced to become reliant on other countries for their energy supply. This will in turn jeopardise the country’s competitiveness, but more importantly, its independence and sovereignty. The alternative to fossil fuels was supposedly to be found in biofuels. However, according to recent findings biofuels are not the solution to hunger, environmental disasters or anything else. In fact they will probably make things worse, and the reason for this is simple – physics. The quantities of biofuels needed to generate the necessary energy supply actually increase greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. To put it plainly, wasting energy to produce energy. Furthermore, the crops and land that could have been used for food supply are instead used to produce energy, and instead of worrying about the compatibility of the EU Mercosur FDA and the European Green Deal, the elected representatives of the European citizens should rather be more concerned about the devastating impact both these initiatives will have on farmers in particular and European citizens in general.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, in Europe we have a very nice, very recurring fashion speech on the green deal, which at the first of the change is beginning to fail and shows the hypocrisy of a debate, which shows that, while new environmental obligations are added to our farmers, the requirements of imported products are gradually diminished. The problem is that these products, ours and imported products, compete in a global market, but not with the same rules. While there are increasing environmental standards in the European Union, Mercosur allows, for example, the use of antibiotics with growth hormones and gm soybeans. In this regard, we must recall the strict rules of mandatory compliance for European producers in phytosanitary and animal health, in addition to respect for the environment. The sustainability chapter in the Mercosur Agreement is a simple statement of intent that contrasts with the reality of how Mercosur countries produce their food. Mercosur not only jeopardizes the economic fabric in the punished production areas of the European Union, but also shows the european Union's absolute inconsistency in talking about green deal and the sustainability of agriculture.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, we are being asked the question: 'Is the Green Pact compatible with the Mercosur agreement'? For me, the answer is in the question, it is obviously no. And I am truly astonished, but almost admiring, in front of the right-wing colleagues who enthusiastically explain to us that, thanks to this agreement, Mr Bolsonaro will miraculously become a defender of the environment and indigenous peoples. Colleagues, this will not happen. So no, this agreement is not compatible. Firstly, because the only increase in export quotas for soybeans, ethanol, beef, poultry, sugar is the equivalent of an additional 9 million tonnes of greenhouse gases. No, it is not compatible because President Bolsonaro's friends, the agribusiness representatives, continue to burn down the Amazon - I think it's 93% more fires this year. Because, when we read the text, we see that the precautionary principle is weakened and that this will expose Europe to increasingly dangerous products. Because we saw the result of COP25 in Madrid and Brazil, along with other countries for that matter, has constantly challenged the precautionary principle defended by the Europeans. So, of course, it is not compatible and I beg you, ladies and gentlemen, do not be naïve, or be hypocritical.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the world is changing very and fast, and all policies based on violence can hardly succeed. Climate extremes, which we have heard about recently, at least we who are members of the Environment Committee, by the IPCC, we are told therefore, the climate extremes that could have been expected once every 100 years, can now be expected every year. Shocking fact, by scientists.  According to WWF, in the 50 years, from 1970 until today, we as humans, as a human species, have killed 60% of all animals, mammals, birds, fish, amphibians, reptiles. And we're doing very well with bees and other insects, which we discussed yesterday. How long before this arrogance of the human race and when will it be replaced by humility and respect for our environment and nature?  In seeking solutions for the future, for the 21st century, we must not limit ourselves to the ideologies of the 20th and even 19th centuries, economic, legal, political, from left to right and everyone else. We as a species, if we are to survive, we must not only protect the Amazon rainforest, we must reject hedonism, materialism, violence, exploitation of each other, we must reject war. So many trillions of dollars or euros, so many millions of scientists' work hours go to wartime purposes. Let's use it to build peace. Let's throw away debt, debt bondage, endless borrowing of states.  The European Green Deal is not an adequate policy and we need to look much deeper and further. Any policy based on violence and aggression cannot survive in the long run.

name: José Manuel GARCÍA-MARGALLO Y MARFIL
text: – Mr President, it seems that we are facing a dilemma: either free trade or environmental protection. And, in my opinion, this dilemma is false. The ultra-liberals believe that climate change is not true, or that climate change is not due to human action, so any free trade agreement, whether or not it takes precautions, is welcome. The manual greens believe that any trade agreement is a Corsican patent for one to do as he sees fit, without prejudice to what happens to the environment, and Bolsonaro is cited as an obvious example. In my opinion, the dilemma, I insist, is false. What we need to do is harmonize environmental protection with the opening of borders. That is, going to sustainable development. And, in my opinion, the Agreement does well. The Agreement says that all environmental agreements, which must be implemented by the Paris Agreement, condemn illegal deforestation and force member countries to major reforestation are respected. It obliges corporate social responsibility of private companies. Establishes a specific dispute resolution procedure. And it lays down very clear rules on food safety. Therefore, I stress, my group is in favour of the Agreement with Mercosur, believing that the Agreement with Mercosur respects the commitment we have to honour in the European Green Pact on environmental protection.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The European Green Deal means that the European Commission is finally taking a holistic approach and proposing a strategy for structural change that we need so very well. Green Deal is really a "game changer", and it feels. And that's why I ran to this debate. Because I really didn't want to miss this. I would also like to say that, although I had very high expectations, i really feel with all my heart that the European Commission did everything to show that it is broad and that we will take action for the whole of politics, with new proposals, but also put very massive weight on existing legislation.  This is a great victory for us Social Democrats who really want to see this change for Europe. It gives hope to a young generation that has been out on our streets, pushed this Parliament and shown that we want change for the whole of Europe. The Green Deal means that we show that we are serious about a sustainable future. However, with all these praises to the Commission, I would also like to declare that the Green Deal is, of course, also binding. It will not be a clear red carpet that is rolled out, or green carpet for that matter, but it will be a constant dialogue with Parliament.  From our point of side, there are several parts that we need to consider as we gear up. The world is following our work very closely and that is why it is so important that it is right. With a successful green transition, we must show that we will take the lead responsibility for Glasgow becoming the success we need for the world. Europe will not be able to do this with the Green Deal on its own. And that is why it is important that we also build relationships up to Glasgow, which means that all countries are now stepping up their efforts. Here, our trade agreements are very crucial. We need to use them much more strategically.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, recent developments in the WTO have shown us how valuable it is that Europe has a growing network of partnerships with third countries. Mr Commissioner , you do not need to be a genius to see how good it is to have comprehensive trade relations with Canada, Japan, Singapore and many others – as others are bringing down what has been built in decades. And let us now make these agreements the best they can be, based on our values and with respect for the environment. How will the Commission ensure that Mercosur countries will respect the Paris Agreement, and if they don’t, what will be the consequences? Europe has been at its best when it leverages its economic power for good in the world. With further tools and more effective enforcement, as highlighted in the Green Deal, we can make steps in the right direction. And that is why I call upon the Commission to effectively enforce the timber regulation to save the Amazon, which is a crucial part of our global ecosystem and home to indigenous people, whose fundamental rights are on the line.

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: – Madam President, the central question here is consistency. Is our trade policy consistent with our climate goals? With regard to the EU—Mercosur deal, the answer is clearly ‘no’. It is, of course, true that trade can be beneficial for both parties. Any child can tell you that, exchanging cards in the playground. But not all trade is good trade, and so—called free trade has hidden social and ecological costs. We all pay the price for destruction of forests and for climate change. Exporting more fossil-fuelled cars from Europe in exchange for more beef grown on land that was previously the Amazon is making no sense at all. Minister Tuppurainen, Commissioner Hogan, you both mentioned the Trade and Sustainable Development (TSD) chapter. Minister, you called it ‘robust’. I actually initially heard the word ‘rubbish’, and I had to step back and question myself for a bit. It’s not rubbish, but let’s be perfectly honest about it: there is nothing in that chapter that will put a brake on Bolsonaro. Commissioner Hogan, you also referred to the commitment on Article 5, but it could not be clearer that President Bolsonaro frankly does not give a toss about the Amazon or about the climate. His obstructiveness at COP 25 last week was yet more evidence of that. Some of my colleagues elsewhere in this House have claimed that we will have more leverage if we sign this agreement. There is no evidence whatsoever that this will happen. The point of leverage is before signing. We need evidence of concrete change and improvement and also evidence from our side that trade policy is compatible with our climate and biodiversity goals. I call on you to ensure that.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EU-Mercosur Free Trade Treaty is the largest trade agreement that the European Union could conclude, with the creation of a market of 780 million people.  In spite of this premise, we are here today to ask ourselves whether trade agreements, as well as trade agreements with Vietnam, are compatible with our environmental, social and labour standards.  In the negotiations, only specific interests are criminally protected, without demanding effective reciprocity, often sacrificing the human rights side and favouring certain production sectors to the detriment of others, almost always agri-food and the environment.  Despite the reassurances from the Commission that it has spoken of rigorous monitoring, there are still many concerns, linked not only to the recent spoiled meat scandal, but in general to the fact that the mercosur countries' production and processing industry does not comply with the same rules that the EU imposes on its producers.  In these countries, pesticides with substances banned in the EU are used and products such as chilled beef and poultry are at the top of the list of food alarms taken in 2018 in Italy. In addition, there are the quotas granted for sugar, rice and, above all, citrus fruits, for which there are fears of plant health problems linked to certain parasites in South America.  The necessary battle against wildfires and deforestation at the moment seems to have served more for political controversy with the Government of Brazil, rather than for a real "green" turn. It is precisely on the side of environmental sustainability that these agreements seem to be most deficient.  These treaties do nothing concrete to strengthen or improve the environmental standards of the partner countries. If the EU really wants to be consistent with its much-vaunted principles of protecting the environment, the seas and the oceans, why is the ban on the use of single-use plastic not just a binding condition for the countries with which we conclude these free trade treaties? Why do European citizens and businesses always have to foot the bill?

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, farmers are again taking place in the Netherlands today. I understand that very well, because farmers are caught between an accumulation of rules and very small margins. Moreover, they are constantly portrayed as people who stick to outdated concepts, again yesterday by your colleague, Commissioner Timmermans. What do you mean, out of date? Europe is leading the way. That should be what the Commission should be saying. When I look at the Green Deal, I see very high ambitions, but no realism. I see very high goals, but no tools to achieve these goals. Why, for example, does the authorisation of new, green plant protection products take so long? And now there are those looming extra cheap imports from Mercosur, where very different standards apply. As far as we are concerned, that really has to be different. What I advocate is appropriate pride in what has already been achieved, realism and a level playing field. This is the only way we can work together on sustainability.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, Bolsonaro announced that Brazil will withdraw from the Paris Agreement on climate change and that it will continue to deforest the Amazon. The European Union announced that it would not sign trade agreements with countries that did not ratify the Paris Agreement. A few weeks ago this Parliament declared the climate emergency, and a few days ago the Commission presented a pompous green new deal, but all this is wet paper when we talk about trade in the service of multinationals. The European Union continues to negotiate with bolsonaro's denialist, misogynistic and far-right government, a trade agreement with Mercosur, one more case of the hypocrisy governing European economic policy. Declaring the climate emergency is incompatible with an agreement that favors intensive agribusiness, extractivism and deforestation, and which will also increase the persecution of human rights defenders in Brazil, as the finalists of the Sakharov Prize have denounced in this House today. If the question is whether this Mercosur Agreement is compatible with the new green deal, the answer is 'no'. We are in time to change and lower this Agreement.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, trade agreements are necessary for any serious economic activity. From the farmers' point of view, however, talking today about the compatibility between the Mercosur Agreement and the Ecological Pact is quite difficult.  The agreement with Mercosur raises standard issues in three major areas where we need strong answers. With regard to combating climate change, it is complicated for us to discuss the sustainability of forests within the European Union, to allocate serious financial resources in this direction, while the mercosur countries are intentionally burning their forests to make way for the production of beef or soybeans.  We are discussing the farm-to-fork strategy as part of climate change and imposing high quality standards on food produced by farmers in the European Union. In the Mercosur countries, however, we do not have nearly the same standards. Moreover, we had from Brazil imports of rotten meat that the specialist services inside the European Union could not detect. Commissioner, do we have a guarantee today that the same thing will not happen again in the future? Farmers in the European Union rightly have a number of restrictions on the use of pesticides, antibiotics and growth hormones, but farmers in Mercosur do not have these obligations. That is why we must ensure that this agreement will provide us with firm answers to our concerns, so that we can strike a balance between farmers in Mercosur and those in the European Union.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hogan, ladies and gentlemen, with the Green Deal, the European Union wants to make a new pact with its citizens and consumers. A pact that, thanks to the "from field to table" strategy, can be further strengthened and directed towards the quality of food, understood both as product quality, nutritious and healthy, and by the production process, fair, sustainable and transparent. European farmers and producers are ready to take up this challenge, further strengthening our production standards, which are already among the most advanced globally. We cannot afford to leave them alone, but we must make the most of their efforts and protect them from all situations of unfair competition with third-country producers.  This objective can no longer be postponed, Commissioner, but it cannot be limited to agreement with the Mercosur Pact alone. Indeed, only through an ambitious new European food diplomacy, based on reciprocity of production standards between the Union and all our trading partners, will we be able to become real global reference points in the definition of agricultural and food production standards.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Madam President! The Mercosur agreement will undoubtedly benefit us all. I think we all agree on that. The agreement is thus an end in itself. And it must not end up being a means of something else. For the same reason, what is happening in Brazil is, of course, deeply worrying. The burning of the Amazon is in every way absurd when we jointly try to solve these climate challenges. That is why, of course, pressure must also be exerted on the Brazilian Government. President Bolsonaro needs the Mercosur Agreement more than anyone else. That, of course, is what matters here. He needs it more than us. He may not be interested in climate, but he is at least interested in economics. Therefore, it would also be an unforgivable political blunder if, after 20 years of hard work, the deal ends up on the floor as a bargaining chip because it has not taken care of itself and done this properly. Indeed, the best way to promote both growth and the green transition is for the Mercosur agreement to be implemented and effectively enforced, not only because it obliges Brazil to comply with the Paris Agreement, but also because more trade means fewer barriers. Spreading concrete green European solutions to the whole world is the very key to prosperity. Therefore, use it wisely and do not use it as a bargaining chip.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, European negotiators at the Madrid climate talks like to position themselves as leaders on climate change, but we are still ignoring the science and failing to tell the truth on climate. The truth is that we need to achieve net zero carbon by 2030, and this means a radical transformation of the way we live across the European continent. We are also hypocrites, as we focus attention narrowly on our direct carbon emissions whilst ignoring the CO2 embodied in the goods we consume that have been imported. The European Green Deal is pointless if we do not combine it with an enlightened trade policy. Brazil’s President Bolsonaro saw the provisional Mercosur agreement as a green light to invite ranchers to destroy the Amazon and murder its indigenous people. A genuine green deal means a radical shift towards low—energy lifestyles in our continent and an enlightened trade policy embedded in the protection of our precious climate, which we must respect as a common good for all humanity.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, this issue is also on the table at the initiative of the Greens. They have a serious obsession with the climate – incidentally, the Greens are the most damaging group of the moment. There's nothing in their illusion world that has nothing to do with the climate. The EU has set over-the-top and unsanitary emission targets that will at most tax ourselves to death and distribute the money wherever it hurts without a goal. The Green Deal is voluntary, but it is a short step towards coercion if climate hysterics get their way.  Are mercosur countries complying with the agreements? That culture doesn't necessarily include the mocking study of the articles. And these excessive objectives set out by the EU cannot be achieved by any entity. Cato always ended his speech in the same sentence: by the way, I believe that Carthago must be destroyed. And it was eventually destroyed. And it is likely that the same will happen to Europe. It's ourselves we're destroying. Personally, I believe that power from the EU must be restored to the nation states. It is best known and knows its own circumstances. Britain will soon be shackled. I'm jealous, but good luck with my lap full.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, unfortunately, the debate on trade agreements and trade in general is increasingly ideologising and politicising us. I witnessed this in the last Parliament, but now the situation has gotten worse. Recently, we have faced an attempt to postpone or even torpedo the consensus on a trade agreement with Vietnam on the basis of the allegations that have been made. Now there's a contract with Mercosur on the wallpaper just because the European left doesn't like bolsonaro ruling Brazil. Instead of talking about tariffs, quotas, geographical indications, all things related to trade policy, we are increasingly dealing with human rights, labour legislation, environmental standards. These are all topics that belong to bodies of the European Parliament other than the Committee on International Trade. If we have imposed a Green Deal on ourselves, I respect that, but let us also respect that other countries in the world have chosen a different path. If we do not want to do business with them, we will find that we are slowly closing our trade borders with almost everyone, and I think that is not possible. Let us therefore really bring the trade debate back to trade issues.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, it is extraordinary how this Parliament, this sitting, which this morning welcomed The Chief Raoni and Claudelice Silva dos Santos as finalists for the Sakharov Prize, defenders of the Amazon forest, is in the afternoon asking whether the European Union-Mercosur Agreement is compatible with the Green Deal. No, it's not, and we have to choose the side. Either we choose the side of those who defend the Amazon and the forest or we choose the agribusiness side. This question is just a mere justification for finding excuses and putting us on the side of agribusiness. There is no compatibility possible. This agreement is a death sentence for the Amazon. This agreement is a prize to Bolsonaro, yes, and when we say no to the agreement we are also saying no to Bolsonaro. This agreement is an offense to indigenous peoples, defenders and human rights defenders. This agreement is to throw away the Paris Agreement and, if there are any questions, ask Bolsonaro. He's already said he's going to retire, and I heard here today that even without an agreement the Paris Agreement is going to be left. So I don't know, they're too gullible or very hypocritical and I'd rather side with amazonian defenders than on the side of hypocrites.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the trade relationship between Mercosur and the European Union today exceeds EUR 120 billion, as you know, between goods and services. It is an important and valuable package which, as Mr Simon said a moment ago, is now lying within the commercial sphere outside specific rules that can safeguard the expectations that so many colleagues have mentioned, including, for example, expectations regarding the Green Deal. Well, it is particularly important to me that the Green Party has decided to react so decomposedly to the fact that there is a President of the European People's Commission who has taken the Green Deal as a priority. The reaction is broken down. They decided, having been snatched of the topic that interests the most, to play the most dangerous game that there is in politics, that of the biggest shooter to recover some space in that area that they normally managed. That's not the case, Green Deal is two words. Green and Deal, "deal" means deal, sit down and reason, it's a challenge for everyone or take responsibility for what you say.  Do you want to block all trade agreements? The proposal is that all trade agreements, using the Green Deal lock-in, must be blocked at this time, that is to say, do you want to turn the Green Deal not into a challenge for everyone, but into the grave of this continent? Do you want to turn Europe into a closed and unavailable continent? Well, for us, the Green Deal is a different thing. We have decided to work for the citizens, not for four votes as you are doing.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. You inherited a cu cukual egg. They have tossed to you an agreement written in a completely foreign language which, as you see after this debate, few of us understand because we cannot understand. Today, Europe and the world speak a completely different language, with completely different values than before. This agreement, written for twenty years, glorifies a religion that no longer functions in the world today. A religion that puts money above human rights and climate protection, a religion that has led to the Amazon burning today and human rights being violated in Brazil.  Unfortunately, this hypocrisy cannot be supported by many of my colleagues here in this House, and it is not supported by the societies of our countries, the societies that take to the streets, protesting against such an agreement. That is why we must do everything to ensure that this agreement is written in the language of the modern world, of people who take to the streets in defence of human rights, in defence of the climate. Because how do we look into the eyes of the people who, on the one hand, we are awarding here for defending human rights in Brazil or climate protection, and on the other hand we are selling these human rights and climate protection for more cars or mobile phones? That cannot be the case.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the European Green Compact devotes its third point to making our Union a world leader in ecological transition. One of the tools to achieve this is trade policy. The Agreement with Mercosur passes, in this area, from words to deeds. Complying with the Paris Agreement is already a requirement in it, and will be incorporated into those who sign in the future. That clause has already paid off. I think he pushed the Leticia Pact through the Amazon, in response to the Amazon fires. That is why I trust, welcome and welcome the commitment on trade policy contained in the European Green Pact. We will have a high responsibility for trade policy focused on its sustainability. Finally, I have a lot of hope in people's prominence. The debate we are having today is undoubtedly the result of a concern. The three axes of citizen integration envisaged in the Covenant offer avenues to transform concern into individual and collective commitments that mobilize, conceit, control and, ultimately, add to the exciting mission proposed by the European Green Pact.

name: Tilly METZ
text: – Madam President, by agreeing to such trade deals, we are directly contributing to an increase and speed of consumption around the world. We are being told the narrative that this kind of trade is delivering development, but this is a lie. It is benefiting very few people while depleting global resources and contributing to human rights violations. In the case of the Mercosur agreement, let’s take the following absurdity: the swapping of immense volumes of meat. Trade should be about exchanging things the other party doesn’t have. It shouldn’t be about commodities that both parties have plenty of, and they are shipped around the world for no reason other than financial gain. This is a complete waste of resources, especially in the case of resource-intensive products such as beef. How is this compatible with the Green Deal? We should be fighting the ecocide, not pouring gasoline on top of it by boosting bigger trade flows.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the green pact presented by the Commission is very ambitious, with a carbon neutrality target for 2050. The European Union thus proclaims its desire to be exemplary in the implementation of the Paris climate agreements. The intention is laudable, but the reality is very different from the display thus realized. By passing free trade treaties with the whole world, the Union is betraying the environmental objectives it has set itself. The best way to combat air pollution is to promote short circuits to limit the movement of goods over long distances, which requires the massive use of kerosene and heavy fuel oil. However, free trade treaties do exactly the opposite. From this point of view, the free trade agreement with Mercosur is emblematic since it is, by Jean-Claude Juncker's own admission, the largest trade agreement ever concluded by the European Union. With more than 770 million consumers and 18 trillion euros of GDP concerned, it is indeed the largest, and this is all the more serious for the environment as Latin America is a continent far removed from Europe. This new partnership will therefore increase the number of particularly polluting exchanges. Secondly, the content of free trade treaties always sacrifices environmental protection to the almost obsessive concern of exporting our industrial production at all costs. The agreement with Mercosur is no exception to this rule. Certainly, there is a chapter that purports to ensure forest conservation and sustainable development. But, in reality, Brazil is destroying the Amazon rainforest more than ever, which speaks volumes about the effectiveness of this guarantee. In conclusion, true to its ultra-liberal DNA, the European Union is deliberately sacrificing environmental protection to business and the short-term interests of the automotive, chemical, pharmaceutical, telecommunications, transport and financial services lobbies. By claiming otherwise by its green pact, it is once again deceiving the Europeans.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is very interesting because it shows us two faces. There is the environmental face of those who are orphans of communist ideology and are looking for a new ideology to make sense of their political activity and end up hitting the economy and those workers of whom he professed to be a defender in the last century.  The second face is that of those who fill their mouths with evocative formulas such as the Green New Deal, but then care about the protection of the environment, because the only green for which they feel interest is the color of money. I am referring to those European states which, thanks to the Treaty with Mercosur, will be able to sell large cars more easily, to the detriment of the European agri-food sector, which will be seriously damaged. To keep the two faces together, as in a painting by Pablo Picasso, there is only your hypocrisy.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, last week you presented in this Parliament your proposal for a European Green Pact. In it we have encountered many questions and contradictions. One of the main issues is free trade agreements, such as the one they intend to ratify now with Mercosur and which marks the European Union's trade policy. There are many well-founded criticisms that environmental organizations, agricultural unions and human rights defenders in Europe and Latin America make of this Agreement; an agreement which, inter alia, envisages moving goods between the two continents worth EUR 88 billion, with their corresponding CO2 emissions; intensification of meat production, associated with Deforestation of the Amazon; the use of pesticides banned in the European Union for agricultural production. And, of course, this Agreement inevitably serves to normalize the human rights violations of fascist Bolsonaro. We doubt that this will fit into policies that seek sustainability and emissions reduction. They say that their European Green Pact is for no one to be left behind, but we wonder if what they want is not to leave behind any of the big companies that are destroying the planet.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last week's European Green Deal launched the most ambitious European Commission ever. We resolutely opt for the transition to a sustainable economy and a sustainable world for our children. In addition, we must also consider the ecological effects of our trade policy. Here too, the taboos must be broken. Agriculture is such a taboo. Our agriculture is the cornerstone of our climate policy, and we are right to do so. But our European farmers do achieve the highest environmental standards in the world. For example, we all know that imported beef is more polluting than locally produced beef, but all too often the farmer is a currency for trade treaties, and that is also the case with regard to Mercosur trade treaties. I dare to ask myself questions in the agriculture chapter of this trade treaty. This allows the import duties for highly qualified and quality beef to be reduced from 99 000 tonnes to 7.5 % while the carbon footprint of Brazilian beef is twice as high as that of Belgian white-blue. Should we import beef at all costs while supporting the sector with subsidies here, or should we put more emphasis on the ecological aspect of trade?

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, today we are talking about an agreement, the Agreement between the European Union and Mercosur, which demands and deserves in-depth debate, thorough scrutiny by this House, and we will do so over the next few years. An agreement that means the opportunity for a true bi-regional partnership between Latin America and Europe. I would like to recall that such an agreement would link 85% of the Latin American population to the largest market in the world, which is the European market. And I say this now that the world is moving and we are looking for allies in the defense of multilateralism and a just, inclusive globalization: with Latin America we have a region to be able to defend all that. It deserves to be debated and deserves the Agreement to serve, this and any other, not to export products, but to export standards and standards. And trade agreements are good for that. Now we're discussing what's going on in Brazil and About Bolsonaro. I am disgusted by the president of Brazil. In fact, I have views similar to those of some European politicians. But I would like to remind you that this agreement has been being negotiated for twenty years. There have been other presidents in Brazil who have negotiated this Agreement. And what a trade agreement can allow us, what is it? Have demanding standards and a stable framework to fight climate change and protect our biodiversity, especially when we talk about the planet's lung. But for that you don't have to act alone. We have to agree, demand, export, but not products, but rules, and that's what agreements and associations of this kind are for.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, I do not think that, in essence, the agreement with Mercosur is antithetical to our climate ambitions, to paraphrase one of the previous speakers. What I believe, however, is that there are more than a few details to be worked out before the European Parliament can give the go-ahead, and my colleague Bernd Lange is right to point out that we are going to need this time. Only two points in the minute I am given. Our farmers need to be better protected and, more generally, it is our agricultural model that needs to be protected at all. As it stands, the agreement destabilizes the beef and sugar sectors, whose prices are already low. On the "climate" side, it is a question of raising the tone with Jair Bolsonaro's Brazil. As a source of deforestation, the Amazon, currently a carbon sink, could tip over and become a source of emissions. And the Amazon is ten years of global CO2 emissions. Without it, our wind turbines are rupeeless. So what to do in practice, Mr. Hogan? What do we say to the people who are trampling on the Paris agreement? We saw it in Madrid, business as usual, it is no longer possible.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If we want a green deal, we cannot conclude this agreement – that is not possible. The mandate comes from the last century, and all this no longer fits in with the times. Basically, it is the old agreement: beef, soya versus machines, cars and now services. So we would at least have to start renegotiating. Then we have now put on top: wonderful sustainability chapters and chapters on environmental protection. But if all this is not sanctioned, all this is no good. We can see what Mr Bolsonaro is for a politician. We are making this neo-fascist fit for court with this agreement. He makes no secret of the fact that he would soon prefer to abroden the Amazon. He makes no secret of the fact that he would prefer to throw the Paris climate agreement into the ton, and with that we are making such deals? One has to ask whether the European Union is actually taking its human rights approaches seriously at all.  Commissioner, you once said that the same standards were the same. We cannot have the same standards if we impose conditions on our farmers – rightly imposing more conditions – and at the same time importing them from a country where environmental standards are of no use, especially in the agricultural sector. 150 pesticides are authorised and European farmers are banned. This is not a deal on an equal footing with our farmers.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the title of this debate should be: are the dogmas of the European Union compatible with the environment it claims to defend? And the answer is obviously no. For this is the great paradox, the great inconsistency of the European Union. On the one hand, the desire to impose ever higher, ever more stringent and therefore ever more expensive environmental standards on European industries and farmers. And on the other hand, to go further and faster in a logic of free trade, lowering tariffs, deregulation and the removal of protections. Behind this paradox, there is a great illusion, both ideological and naïve, that which the other powers will imitate us, will gently align with our standards and our norms. This will obviously not be the case, they will take advantage of it to conduct unfair competition with all the more ardour. By imposing ever-increasing standards, you are undermining the competitiveness of our businesses, our farmers. By refusing to protect them at the same time, well, you're killing them. Europe is now the best student of ecology, minus 16% in the last twenty years of CO2 emissions. At the same time, China is 208% more. Gretha Thunberg is here to make Westerners feel guilty. We need to get out of the free trade model, we need to relocate human activities, protect the environment and defend our economy.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Of course, we voted in favour of the trade agreement with Mercosur. But now "The European Green Deal" is on everyone's lips. There should be investments, laws and changes in behaviour. Everyone is happy to spread the message that Europe will become the world's first climate-neutral continent, a world leader, and then the rest of the world will follow suit. I wouldn't have a problem with that if it weren't for never talking about consequences, or with facts. You stop at the benefits.  The conversion will cost an unimaginable amount of money, cause higher electricity prices, reduced investment in welfare and reduced competitiveness. And to fund this gigantic project, it wants, among other things, to introduce a carbon border tax, a barrier to trade, even though we know that it will almost certainly lead to trade conflicts and, by extension, lower global trade and reduced prosperity – a prosperity that is actually the very basis for coping with a climate change change for real. Trade barriers do not solve anything. Instead, invest in innovation, smart construction, technological development and carbon dioxide, nuclear power.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, this Mercosur Agreement prioritises profit for transnational companies and investors, while lowering social and environmental standards for workers, farmers and citizens. European farmers – especially meat and crop producers – will be forced to compete with imports from huge agribusiness companies in  Mercosur countries that cut costs by using pesticides, antibiotics and hormones – many of which are banned in the EU.  The Green Deal claims that European farmers are key to managing the transition and that the Farm to Fork strategy will strengthen farmers’ efforts to tackle climate change and preserve biodiversity, and it talks of ensuring a decent living for farmers and their families. Tell me, Commissioner, what in God’s name has the Mercosur deal got to do with that? What is there to make of the EU’s climate diplomacy, when Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay blocked progress at COP25? You admit that the current illegal and unsustainable forestry activities shouldn’t continue. I had an argument with Ricardo Salles – Brazil’s Environment Minister – in Madrid, and he said that not a single tree in the rainforest has been cut down for soya or beef production. And you’re going to believe what these fellas tell you? Come on, give us a break.

name: Simone SCHMIEDTBAUER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Modern, climate-friendly agriculture needs standards that enable sustainable food production on our family farms in Europe. This must be taken into account in the Green Deal. With regard to free trade agreements, I wonder whether Green Deal diplomacy will now also apply to our trading partners. How will the Commission ensure that double standards are not applied here? Where are the red, really needed lines drawn? If we take the Green Deal seriously, imports from third countries must meet equally high environmental and climate standards. However, with regard to the Mercosur deal, there is a legitimate doubt about production standards, sustainable production requirements and animal welfare. In relation to imports from third countries, we apply double standards. For example, I do not have the approach to a realistic ally of a protein strategy. Will such be enshrined in the Green Deal? Keyword soy imports: Do food and feed have to fly across the Atlantic? What will the Commission emphasise in the Green Deal on food origin labelling? Every consumer should be able to opt for climate protection when purchasing by using domestic products. We landands and foresters attach great importance to environmental and climate protection, which is our livelihood. We are already making a significant contribution. However, as a farmer, as a practitioner from Austria, and Commissioner, we need framework conditions for this. We need stability, predictability, practical measures and compensation for our services to the general public. This is about maintaining a professional group!

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am astonished that the Greens have today proposed not a general debate on the compatibility of the new European New Deal with trade treaties, but a specific debate on Mercosur.  Here I would like to quote a couple of figures. The first, Europe accounts for 9 % of emissions into the atmosphere, the four Mercosur countries 3.5 %, and these emissions are, I believe, largely offset by a large wooded area and one of the lowest population densities on the planet.  Furthermore, on the chapter on sustainable development, which is an essential chapter of this agreement, I believe that this chapter is the best guarantee for the protection of biodiversity, for the protection of deforestation and for the maintenance of the commitments that these governments have made with the agreement of the Paris Conference, and it is also the best guarantee on President Bolsonaro's unholy policies in order to prevent it from continuing in what he has done. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we may have doubts about this Treaty, we all have doubts about it, but I believe that the explanatory statement adopted by our Colleagues from the Greens is totally inconsistent.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I would like to wish you well, Commissioner Hogan, on your reappointment as Commissioner and wish you well in the trade portfolio and to say at the outset, I mean this is going to be a very big challenge for Europe in the context of promoting global greening, ensuring that we protect not only our own climate agenda here but that we foster it across the globe. And at the same time, we are encouraging a trade deal with Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina which will effectively destroy much of the Amazonian rainforest that is left – the lungs of the world – upend biodiversity and send out a message across the globe that Europe is not as serious as it should be about climate change. So we publish a great agenda last week and we undermine it by the very fact that we’re trying to promote a Mercosur trade deal that undermines everything that we stand for in the context of the green agenda. So let’s be very clear – we have to be honest: this particular deal does not stack up on many fronts. It undermines the basic principles that we in Europe are promoting in terms of the environment, and secondly and as importantly, it undermines our agricultural industry as well.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Yesterday, at home in Sweden, the government stated – thanks largely to the Swedish Green Party – that all policies in all policy areas should now be in line with climate goals. That should be a matter of course here in europe too. Not least with regard to trade agreements, we have a great opportunity to influence climate policy, and other policies too, in other countries. That is most likely the best way, it may even be the only way we can really influence it.  Perhaps the EU should not even trade with countries that do not sign up to and support the Paris Agreement and are working for the transition in full. I am pleased to hear many other politicians from other groups talking about us being leaders in the climate change transition. Then we must be in all areas. Otherwise, this will be nothing but empty words. There is a great risk that this term of office, this five years, will be the last term of office we have if we are to succeed in the transition.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, last week Mr Timmermans presented his European Green Deal. It incorporates the "farm-to-board" strategy. Already, battery cages and various pesticides are banned in the EU. Soon our farmers will have to invest billions of euros to comply with much stricter and unnecessary rules. But under the Mercosur agreement, we will soon also get food on our plates from countries where those rules do not apply. Totally contradictory. The Mercosur Treaty is a "cars-for-cows" strategy that benefits a number of eu car-producing countries. At the same time, however, all farmers in the Member States, including the Netherlands, are being hit by unfair competition. Nor does it benefit nature and consumers. We really need to rethink this inconsistent policy.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Today we face a serious dilemma. On the one hand, it is estimated that the trade agreement with mercosur countries is expected to contribute to EUR 19 trillion of GDP. It is expected to generate €88 billion in trade in goods, €34 billion in services. On the other hand, we are aware that the agreement can contribute to the deforestation of perhaps the world's most valuable forest resources, the biodiversity reservoir, that is, the Amazon forests that are cut down, fall victim to fires, mostly premeditated, in order to gain a place for crops, also for feed.  It is proposed that the trade agreement with mercosur countries be used to enforce their compliance with the Paris Agreement and to halt amazon deforestation. However, it may also result in an increase in CO2 emissions due to transport. Will the Mercosur agreement allow us to enforce from our partners the level of reduction in the use of pesticides, plant protection products, fertilisers proposed by the new green deal and thus the fulfilment of the animal welfare, food safety and food safety criteria to be met by a French, German or Polish farmer?  The EU-Mercosur agreement is not the only form of pressure we have. We know, for example, that European banks are investing millions in South American agriculture that does not meet the equivalence criteria. Therefore, it may be worth taking a different approach. First the standards, then the agreement, as is the case with the accession of the new candidate countries to the European Union. Perhaps it is worth considering here the period during which we will check whether the standards have been effectively... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... after which they will be recognised.

name: Günther SIDL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done A free trade agreement with Mercosur would further open up the European market for agricultural products from South America.  Meat producers, such as those from Brazil, who can produce large quantities at low cost, could continue to significantly increase their exports and production, with fatal consequences for the environment and the European internal market. The poisoning of man and nature by the large-scale massive use of pesticides in Mercosur farming is a well-known problem, including with environmental toxins, which are banned in Europe. The standards of animal welfare and plant protection produced in South America have nothing in common with EU standards. In addition, practices such as slash-and-burn, some of them rainforests, are used to extract agricultural land.  We must ensure that trade agreements do not jeopardise or dilute EU achievements, and I do not see that as being the case here at the moment.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Madam President, this Parliament was promised a radical green deal. European citizens and young people around the world who look to European leadership on the environment were promised a radical green deal. But if it is to mean anything at all, this green deal must cover all aspects of legislation, including every single trade deal negotiated here – not just Mercosur. Commissioner, our leverage is strongest before we sign any deal, and the Paris climate targets have to be more important than the prospect of Brazilian beef on our supermarket shelves. Europe exports its values through trade, and we must use new trade agreements to guarantee that strong environmental legislation, democratic safeguards and good law and governance are respected. The Mercosur deal is the best opportunity we will ever have here to win guarantees on protection of the Amazon. If we mean what we say about wanting to prioritise climate targets, then it is high time that we followed words with action. Trade can be a force for good, but in the time it’s taken to negotiate this deal, the climate emergency has become urgent, and that must now be our priority.

name: Sarah WIENER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If you have listened to the speakers here, you must say that, obviously, Europe does not want a Mercosur agreement, and for good reasons. The moral necessity and the obligation that you should now feel as Europe's voice to put this Mercosur Agreement on its act is clear. If you read the headline today, namely compatibility between the European Green Deal and Mercosur, there are no such things for many different reasons. This starts with climate protection, environmental protection, the strengthening of small farmers, the protection of biodiversity, the import of soya, and the exchange of food for machinery. So what are we here for? Are we there for the people? Are we there for small farmers? Or do we continue to support large corporations?

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our trade and imports must not be a hindrance to our collective fight against climate change. However, the Mercosur agreement is to open up our market by removing import tariffs on 92% of Mercosur's goods exported to the European Union. And that is the question of fairness. To achieve the carbon neutrality target by 2050, we are imposing additional efforts on our European companies to reduce their CO2 emissions. We cannot penalize them by favouring imports that do not have the same constraints. The carbon adjustment mechanism at the borders, provided for in the Green Pact, must be put in place quickly, with simple rules, understandable and applicable to all. Of course, we must refuse any unfair competition. How can we justify imposing ever more standards on our farmers, while opening our doors to agricultural production that does not respect them? We must ensure that European consumers comply with our health standards - it is a public health issue - while ensuring that our industrialists and farmers have a fair market. Finally, and this is not the case in this agreement, we must impose sustainable resource management by introducing binding clauses in our trade, in accordance with the Paris agreements on climate and forest protection, as we said during the debates on forest fires in the Amazon. It is not possible for me to support an agreement that would not meet the demands and constraints announced only a few days ago by President Ursula von der Leyen, as part of the Green Pact, which must be our guideline.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, the Commission has presented us with its climate ambition with the Green Pact, and I congratulate it. But how, at the same time, can this same Commission justify the signing of an agreement such as this, which is finally an old-generation agreement, which was negotiated twenty years ago, business as usual? What is the coherence of policies when we know the impact of this agreement, not only on climate and deforestation, but also on indigenous peoples, biodiversity and human rights? Stop selling us that this chapter "sustainable development" is a guarantee for sustainable development; that is not true and you know it. Be consistent, be sincere! Why is this chapter excluded from the settlement mechanisms of individual states, states that are now included in the entire trade agreement? And, coincidentally, when it comes to human rights or sustainable development rights, there is no possibility of using this dispute resolution mechanism. So, to be consistent, I advise you to read the boss of Davos, the boss of Davos who is not a leftist and who says "a company must be accountable for environmental and social responsibility". So, Commissioner and the representative of the Council, I urge you to be less ideologues with regard to trade agreements and to respect what companies themselves are doing today in terms of respect for the environment.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, in the current times of geopolitical changes, trade wars and the growing threat to the multilateral world order, I see that the EU—Mercosur Agreement shows the commitment of both sides to a rules-based international trade. Moreover, it will give European businesses an opportunity into a market with vast economic potential. At the same time, we are facing the challenges of climate change and environmental degradation, which require a global response. With every new trade agreement, the European Union is stepping up efforts to implement and enforce sustainable development commitments, and the EU-Mercosur trade agreement is no exception. With a strong, sustainable development chapter in the trade agreement, we are on the right track with Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay in committing to the implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Madam President, welcome Commissioner Hogan. I’m very glad to see this debate happening here today, initiated by my own Green Group. Too often we fall short of the aim of improving the world through our trade policy, instead compromising ourselves and our ideals in the interest of corporate profits and unsustainably cheap products. It is unclear how the proposed Mercosur deal can in any way be compatible with the Green Deal. How can a deal that ships goods needlessly around the world, imports beef produced on cleared rainforest, that suits the interest of car manufacturers but not the climate, be compatible with the safe, clean future for all? We risk talking out of both sides of our mouth here, talking of a circular economy and sustainable agriculture and then importing climate-destroying agricultural produce. Any deal needs to comply with our Paris obligation, needs to protect workers’ rights in the EU and in South America and needs to maintain the key elements of the Green Deal. It also avoids causing chaos to European farming, where Irish beef farmers are already facing unacceptably low prices.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, we are now debating how compatible the Mercosur agreement is with the Green Deal. I agree with Commissioner Hogan that it is not only compatible, but, if implemented correctly and well, it is a key element of the Green Deal. The Green Deal quite understandably focuses a great deal on climate policy and how we move towards a carbon-neutral Europe. But it is important to remember that the pursuit of sustainable development includes sustainable development, both economically, socially and environmentally. And when we are pursuing all three, including an economically and socially sustainable Europe and the world, trade policy is really important.  It is not enough just for the European Union to achieve carbon neutrality; Our own share of global emissions is only 10%. Trade policy plays a very important role in getting other regions of the world involved. At Madrid, we did not make as much progress as we would have liked, and it is now important that the United States, China and India in particular are committed to climate work through international agreements over the next year. It is important that all new EU trade agreements, including the Mercosur Agreement, have sustainable development chapters, which are monitored by a separate committee. It is precisely the effective implementation and monitoring of these sustainable development chapters that is essential.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: – Madam President, in a time of complex interdependencies, the European Union's relations with the world are certainly not through protectionist and closing equations in itself.  Trade agreements in this regard should be seen as opportunities, both for increasing our exports of goods and services and for job creation. But these agreements also represent spaces for dialogue and understanding with the world, important in promoting values and practices for sustainable development, human and labour rights, environmental rights, animal welfare rules, health and food safety, fair trade, thus bringing countries and latitudes closer to objectives that must be absolutely global.  That is why the political commitments included in the Mercosur Agreement, namely the mutual commitment to implement the Paris Agreement or compliance with environmental agreements, such as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, are very important signs, but cannot be seen as mere rhetorical exercises.  It is essential here that the European Union does not waver in the application of all control instruments that allow us to act uncompromisingly against any kind of rule-out of compliance and any attempt to boycott the fulfilment of ambitions that are compatible with the ecological pact.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Madam President, Mr Hogan, I would like to thank mr Hogan for his work In the ecological crisis that humanity is currently facing, should we, as the EU, agree to an agreement whose explicit aim is to further boost trade in beef and soya? It is only logical that the destruction of the rainforest should be accelerated even further in favour of the expansion of agricultural land.  Mr Bolsonaro himself said at COP 25: what interests him about climate protection? He wants opportunities of business – dramatic enough. What is still at stake, however, is a dramatic loss of biodiversity. The Amazon is the largest biodiversity refuge on the planet – with over 40,000 plant species, 16,000 tree species, 4,500 species of fish, birds and mammals that exist only there. One in ten known animal and plant species in the world lives in the Ecosystem of the Amazon. As Europeans, it is our duty to work for global forest protection. The EU-Mercosur Agreement, as it stands, counteracts the need for environmental change.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Madam President, there are political inconsistencies that the peoples of Europe are right to no longer want to bear. Our agreement with our partners in Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay is unfortunately a clear demonstration of this. At a time when Europe promises to innovate with an ecological barrier, preventing imports from countries that do not comply with our environmental standards, how can we imagine that some, in total opacity and on our behalf, could allow South American countries to flood the European market with food products containing substances that are forbidden to our own breeders? To this ecological absurdity would be added a large-scale social plan which the European Parliament must refuse to be complicit in. As elected representatives of the people, how do you expect us to tell cattle producers, already plunged into crisis, that they should also suffer the arrival of nearly 100,000 tonnes of South American meat trafficked with antibiotics every year? Who can believe that we would allow the mass arrival of mediocre products in supermarkets, posing real risks to public health and our children, in defiance of family farms that fight every day to survive and guarantee food security? In the face of disastrous corridor agreements, we must respond with firmness, a spirit of responsibility and common sense. I am telling you, we must stop being the naïve of globalization. My message is clear: it is time for us European peoples to regain control of our destiny.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, the question in front of us is whether the Green Deal and the Mercosur Free Trade Agreement can be compatible. The EU—Mercosur Agreement includes a binding commitment for the parties to effectively implement the Paris Agreement, but this commitment is made in the sustainable development chapter and, as such, is not subject to trade sanctions. If the agreement were ratified as it is and Brazil backtracks on its Paris commitments, including the goal of zero illegal deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon by 2030, the EU cannot sanction Brazil’s behaviour by taking away its trade preferences. Brazil is now a challenging partner for the EU, as we learned last week in the Madrid COP25 meeting.  But in the European Green Deal, the Commission proposed to make respect of the Paris Agreement an essential element for all future comprehensive trade agreements. The disrespect of an essential element of an agreement would give grounds for trade sanctions. So I propose the solution that Parliament should now demand that, as a condition for ratifying the trade deal, the Paris climate pledge should be made an essential element of the Mercosur Agreement. I’m the one looking for a solution to make this agreement a progressive tool to fight climate change.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I recognise that the debate also shows a number of bottleneces in this international agreement that we are negotiating, but I think that we should also stick to the facts above all. Firstly, it is important that the Mercosur countries and, of course, the European Union have signed the Paris Climate Treaty and that Brazil is the key country for tackling our deforestation problem. What happens when we are unable to make a deal with Brazil if we dump it so-called? I am the rapporteur for the Commission Communication on strengthening the European Union's action to protect and restore the world's forests. I would also like to call on my Green colleagues to participate constructively on this subject and to find a solution to positively bring Brazil into the solution to deforestation. Secondly, the agreement between the European Union and Mercosur also included a chapter on trade and sustainable development in strengthening investment and trade relations and said that the environment would be fully respected and issues such as sustainable management and forest protection would be addressed. Please, let us stick to the facts, that is important, this is in the agreement.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, congratulations, Commissioner Hogan. The European Union emits almost three times as many greenhouse gases as Mercosur, but we are global leaders in the fight against climate change. The Green Pact and the commitment to become the first climate neutral region in 2050 is good evidence of this, but it is certainly not enough. The commitment and involvement of all is necessary. The atmosphere has no borders. The EU-Mercosur Agreement is therefore of particular importance, with an ambitious, legally binding sustainable development chapter and an effective commitment to implement the Paris Agreement on climate change and to rewind and bring down trade preferences if it is breached. It should be remembered that, thanks to the Agreement, Brazil is committed to stopping illegal deforestation and reducing its net greenhouse gas emissions by 43% by 2030 from 2005 levels, the only one of the largest developing countries to take it on. And this is possible because there is an agreement. There is a way to go, we have to improve, we have to ensure compliance and be truly vigilant. And in that this Parliament will have an important role to assume.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hogan, the European Union-Mercosur agreement is undoubtedly important and economically beneficial, since it concerns 770 million consumers, preserves protected indications and reduces tariffs. But it is above all an extremely provocative agreement and the main reason why this agreement is extremely provocative is none other than the environmental certification of products entering the European Union. It is necessary today, Commissioner Hogan, to assure our citizens, to assure the farmers of the European Union, the farmers of Greece, that the products coming to the European Union from the Mercosur countries will be environmentally certified. That they will have the same rules as the rules that the European Union has. Mercosur can also be a powerful lever for pressure so that these countries can follow us towards the high target of the Green Agreement for 2050. But above all we have to be realistic. We have listened to the announcements made by the President of Brazil. This means that Mercosur can be undermined in practice, that Brazil may eventually withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, be the cause of its shipwreck ...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, with a Donald Trump paralysing the WTO, with a Xi Jinping watching, and with a Boris Johnson who seems to be looking for a hard Brexit, Europe must be leading. We are the largest consumer market in the world. This brings with it a great responsibility, but also an opportunity to make global trade more sustainable. We can and must take the lead in this. The Green Deal also calls for action. We can and must establish in the future trade agreements that the Paris agreements will also be respected. And sanctions must be imposed. Because compliance is important, not only by Trump, Xi and Johnson, but also by Bolsonaro, because a climate sceptic who is obstructing madrid and rapidly deforesting the Amazon is not a good trading partner for the EU.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, it is clear that we need to look at both previous and all future trade agreements, above all this Mercosur Free Trade Agreement, which is now on the table, in the light of the SDOs and crises.
