But, Mr Borrell, we need more courage, so far the Community institutions, with the exception of the European Parliament, have not had the courage to send Mr Maduro home, to take firm action against a dictator who continues to massacre his people and starve him to death. That is why we need courageous action on your part, on the part of the Commission and on the part of the Community institutions.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Mr High Representative, the situation in Venezuela is the biggest migration crisis of today. If nothing changes, the number of Venezuelan migrant refugees is expected to increase from 4.5 million to 6.5 million in December 2020. This crisis affects the region and its neighbours, especially Colombia and even Europe. In 2018, the tiny Island of Madeira in Portugal had already received and integrated about 4,000 migrants from Venezuela. However, if this is the biggest migration crisis it is also the least financially supported. Only 48% of the financial commitments made by donors were fulfilled in 2019. It is therefore important that the European Union continues its work, political and diplomatic, that financial commitments are respected and also that the impact of economic sanctions be assessed by studying possible alternatives with creativity, such as the one that the High Representative once advocated, a programme such as Oil for Food.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: – Madam President, Venezuela is in a genuine humanitarian situation. 4.5 million people have had to go into exile from their country, 6 million may end up in exile from Venezuela in 2020, 5,000 people a day leave their country. And this situation is not caused by a war situation, nor by a natural and unexpected event. He has a manager with first and last names: his name is Nicolás Maduro and a regime that edes him. And a regimen. And, in the face of that situation, what can we do? Something as simple as returning democracy to Venezuela. Yes, I say so simple. Because everything else, simply, what it will do is chronicle this situation. And the citizens of Venezuela what they have to hear is a clear and clear voice from the Commission and from this Parliament telling them: we are going to be able to bring democracy back to Venezuela. Because in Venezuela there are extrajudicial executions, in Venezuela politicians are persecuted, there are political prisoners, it is murdered, indigenous communities are murdered. Those who defend human rights so much... do you know what's going on? That while some here, on this bench, look the other way, most of us will look at the dictator head-on and tell him: we'll take you down.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on Venezuela, for the umpteenth time, we have understood the total futility of the European Union.  On Maduro, Europe has had frankly disappointing positions. There has been no clear attack on the socialist and communist model. The model that was embodied first by Chávez and then by Maduro is a model that has led Venezuela, an oil-rich country, to starvation. Almost a third of the population decided to migrate. The shops are empty. Inflation is four-digit. There are many diseases, there are no medicines. There is widespread malnutrition, they even started eating pets.  Well, perhaps some MePs here should finally understand what the socialist model is, what real socialism is, what communism is. It's something that only brings poverty and death. The protest was faced by erasing opponents by repressive methods, there is a lack of freedom of the press and elections have often been rigged. Europe must wake up.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Indeed, Venezuela is the country with the most proven oil reserves. And theoretically it should be a country where people are happy, live in a rich country and realize their plans and dreams. Unfortunately, this is not the case. We know what has been happening in Venezuela for many years. There have already been a few debates on this subject, many spoken words. I am convinced that we are simply powerless in this subject.  More than five thousand people have left Venezuela. Nearly 7,000 extrajudicial killings have been carried out in the country. And It seems to me that this is the moment to send a very clear signal to the authorities of this country that there simply will simply not be any further such behaviour and behaviour by the European Community.  And here is a great request to Mr. Borrell to show, to send this signal, so that this is one of the most important missions for the Lord that you will carry out in the coming years. And for us to start by leting us know whether we will introduce and extend sanctions to the most important representatives of the regime. And then we will consistently demand the restoration of democracy in this country. Without this kind of action, without a strong position from Parliament and the European Community, we will simply debate again today and the situation will not change.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, this Parliament regularly invests, and under the pretext of occasion, on the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. Once again we repeat: this is a hypocritical exercise of interference. After commending with multiple actions of destabilization, coup attempts, terrorism, sabotage, increasingly intense sanctions, it is hypocritical to decontextualize migratory phenomena by hiding and manipulating their objective causes. As in any global context, peace, employment, social protection, health care, combating poverty and exclusion, a policy of development and cooperation are essential factors for fixing and attracting populations. Of course, when promoting otherwise the result is reversed. The interests of the Venezuelan people, and in particular the Portuguese community in that country, are incompatible with this destabilization. We reject the instrumentalization of the legitimate aspirations and suffering of those who, in order to protect themselves from instability, seek other places to live. We demand an immediate end to all sanctions that harm the Venezuelan people and aim at the isolation of Venezuela.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, we are having another debate which, in my view, is highly hypocritical and hypocritical because, according to all the facts, the European Parliament and the European Union will be unable to do anything to stop what is happening in Venezuela. Just as it has not been able to stop it for many years that such discussions have taken place before, just as it has not been able to stop it in other states, where human rights have been proven to be in violation. So, let's see and agree what? That the Venezuelan regime has created an unacceptable attitude and unacceptable situation for the inhabitants of the country? Course. But what regime is there? Let us not forget that it is the communist regime. It is the communist regime that, where it has prevailed, where it has taken the reins in its own hands, has really flattened people, has flattened the very citizens of its countries. So let's start there and see what else happens. Can we see if the European Union has the capacity to stop this? Turns out we're not, and we're just talking, just to do them. We're talking about talking. And how could the opinion and opinion of the European Union be imposed on Venezuela or on something that is so far away from us, when here next to us, on the borders of Europe, on the border with my country Greece, Turkey does what it wants. A brutal dictator is, in my view, Erdoğan, doing what he really wants there, opening the borders and passing illegal immigrants to the European Union, threatening and constantly winning. It does what it wants, it even wants fat funds from Europe in order to do all this. So here's how you're going to stop all the people next door in our neighborhood, and then, slowly, we can stop the others, who are further away from us.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, I would like, first of all, to say that I categorically reject all the statements of Mrs Sandra Pereira of the Portuguese Communist Party, which seeks to whiten a totalitarian regime, oppressive of the Venezuelan people, as is the Maduro regime. It is a shame that we have come to this stage and there are still Members in this House who are here defending Maduro's policies, which have led to the largest displacement of people ever on the American continent and who are now in the safe house of 4.7 million people and could be in the 6 million people. I was in Cúcuta, Colombia. I know what situation are venezuelan refugees who are in Ecuador, Peru, Colombia, who are in Brazil, who are in Chile. I know that you are in a desperate humanitarian situation and I must say that the European Union can do more and it must do more and that European states have responsibilities to end the Maduro regime and restore democratic legitimacy in Venezuela, returning dignity and prosperity to the people of this country.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, four and a half million people have already left Venezuela, and the number is expected to rise by another two million by the end of next year.  It is by far the largest number of refugees from one country in the world today. This tragedy is also accompanied by a proportionately least funded donor community assistance programme, as less than half of the promised funds have been disbursed. Since 2016, the European Union has paid out EUR 320 million in humanitarian aid. But it should continue to be provided not only to Venezuela, but also to Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. These countries have shown great solidarity towards refugees from Venezuela. As many as 85% of refugees are in neighbouring countries.  I support the approach of the High Representative of the United Nations. We must prevent the cost of our political actions from being paid by citizens. The crisis in Venezuela must be ended by negotiations. The best political and democratic solution is free, fair elections with the presence of international observation missions. Only in such elections can Venezuelan citizens decide their future.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: Mr President, it has been almost six months since I first stood here, and then it was also about Venezuela. The numbers don't lie. About 4.5 million people have left Venezuela. About one and a half million of them are taken care of in Colombia. Thousands of Venezuelans are located on the islands of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in the Caribbean. What's happened since I last talked about this? In any case, the figures have not improved. In Aruba, Curaçao and Bonaire, they cannot yet deal with this crisis to a sufficient extent. I therefore call on the Commission to better support the overseas countries and territories of the Union. As the Commission has made clear to me, the asylum, migration and integration emergency fund can be used for this purpose, as can the development fund. I therefore call on the Commission to provide these islands with the necessary support in this fragile situation and to help them with the submission of applications for this.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Mr Borrell, the Commissioner, is a Spaniard, a representative of a country that has a special understanding and understanding of Latin America. So I think he will be able to help solve this problem. But let us also have no illusions: dictatorships do not give way to themselves.  The demand for free elections is absolutely right, justified and substantive, but power in Venezuela is a power based on physical violence, and therefore only very strong international pressure, including the European Union, including the European Parliament – which can say more than EU diplomacy – can finally make it possible for Venezuelans to decide for themselves: themselves, who they will want as the leader of that country.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if four and a half million people escape their country, if parents can no longer feed their children, if Venezuela's annual inflation rate is around 10 000%, then we are facing a very serious problem. Estimates show how next year the number of Venezuelans emigrated will surpass the Syrian exodus, with six and a half million people displaced by 2020. There are almost a million and a half Venezuelans in Colombia, a country that has maintained a generous open-door policy and is now paying dearly for the consequences of welcoming such a large number of people. The United Nations estimates humanitarian needs at $1.35 billion, only to provide basic humanitarian services to migrants and to support host countries. However, the reality is that although many express solidarity, in the end very few contribute. That is why I invite the new Commission to make a greater effort to support these desperate people and to ask the United States to review its sanctions policy, which further paralyzes a already collapsing economy. Ladies and gentlemen, I know that Venezuela is much further away than Syria and that many think that this serious crisis does not affect us directly, but I think the time has come to show our Latin American friends that we are there for them when they need us most.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr. Borrell, more than 4.5 million Venezuelans have fled the country since the beginning of the crisis that led to the communist regime of Chavez and Maduro. Unlike other mass migrations in history, however, this was not caused by military conflict, but by a corrupt, tyrannical government desperately trying to impose a bankrupt ideology of socialism and communism in one of Latin America's richest countries.  For those of us who have had the misfortune of living on the wrong side of the Iron Curtain in a social experiment called a socialist building, or more precisely a socialist camp – very close to a concentration camp, this situation is to pain familiar. Lack and queues for essentials, a disastrous economy, repression and persecution of the opposition, closed borders and attempts to flee.  At the cost of many efforts and sacrifices, we in Europe have been able to reject oppression and dictatorship. Therefore, we cannot now be idly by what is happening to the human tragedy of the people of Venezuela, who are trying to restore democracy, the rule of law and fundamental human rights. Mr Borrell, let us redouble and triple our Efforts of the European Union to restore democracy quickly, to fair and democratic elections, to restore good life opportunities in Venezuela.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As a Social Democrat, I am convinced that true equal societies where people live in peace and freedom require access to democratic rights, as well as social rights. At the moment, unfortunately, we are seeing a Venezuela where the population is fleeing due to a lack of the former, the latter or a combination. More than four and a half million Venezuelans have fled the country and more are doing so every day. According to the UN refugee agency UNHCR, it is currently one of the world's worst refugee disasters.  It is time for the people of Venezuela to have their rights. We must ensure that we continue to demand free and democratic elections. We must demand fundamental rights. We must demand social security and access to fundamental rights for everyone in the country, and we must also ensure that we increase our humanitarian aid.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the International Solidarity Conference on the Crisis of Refugees and Migrants in Venezuela held in Brussels put numbers at the cost of the Maduro dictatorship on Venezuelans. More than four and a half million people have already fled misery and insecurity. By 2020 the figure can exceed six million. 80% take refuge in neighbouring countries, which are setting an example of welcome. However, the first xenophobic discourses emerge, adding pressure to a crisis that is being tackled with more commitments than funds. That is why it is urgent to recalculate the funds that must serve the victims of this drama, detail and fulfill donation commitments and address this external dimension of the Venezuelan crisis. But I encourage the high representative, as he himself stated at the Brussels Conference, to test more committed solutions, focused on assisting Venezuelans in their own country, and we must end the political blockade proposed by a regime that will undoubtedly fall if the free elections claimed by citizens in opposition are given way and our Union supports

name: David LEGA
text: – Mr President, when addressing the Venezuela crisis in July, I reminded this House that Venezuelans are starving to death in their previously so-wealthy country, and that is still a fact. And it’s still a fact that Venezuelans are being gunned down by President Maduro’s forces. And it’s still a fact that those who manage to leave Venezuela must make perilous journeys, they often lack the necessary documents and therefore they also lack access to basic rights. This makes them especially vulnerable to labour exploitation, sexual exploitation, to violence, and therefore they also lack access to basic rights. Maduro has truly created one of the worst migration crises of our time and therefore I strongly support the extension of all EU measures targeting Maduro, including the arms embargo, the travel ban and the freezing of assets. To those Members in this House who continue supporting Maduro and continue opposing our actions to help the people of Venezuela, I am sure that there is a special place in hell for them as well.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, over 4.5 million people have been forced to flee Venezuela because of the desperate situation in the country. According to unhcr data, this number could rise rapidly to 6.5 million by the end of 2020. This is one of the largest population movements in our time. This situation does not allow for the imposition of general economic sanctions, because the humanitarian crisis can get even worse. Any sanctions must be targeted at persons responsible for today's tragedy. The European Parliament must favour a political solution leading to free democratic elections, in the presence of international observers, as the first step towards normalisation. The authoritarianism, torture and impoverishment of a people, whatever wrapper they may be presented to the European Parliament, is inconceivable to find supporters among us.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: blue-card question. – I’m glad that I finally heard somebody from the left side of this Parliament saying something about the actual causes of what happened. So my question is, are the regimes of Chávez and Maduro who caused poverty, hunger and everything that’s happening in Venezuela, the ones to blame for this crisis?

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: answer a question with a "blue card". – The humanitarian crisis in Venezuela and other countries makes us condemn such phenomena, whoever is responsible. We neither put on the scale nor paint the pain of people and all these tragedies. I would like to emphasise that Mr Maduro's responsibilities for how the Venezuelan people have been led into this tragic situation today are obvious.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, two years ago we awarded the Sakharov Prize to the democratic opposition in Venezuela and sent a strong warning for the leaders of this country to change in order to allow real democracy to take place. Unfortunately, nothing has improved by now and we are witnessing a human catastrophe. Six million Venezuelans have fled the country since 2015 and if this trend continues, and according to estimations, 6.5 million Venezuelans could have left the country by the end of 2020. The situation in the region cannot be solved without the involvement of the wider international community, therefore I highly support the Commission’s external action efforts towards the negotiating of a transition leading to transparent and internationally monitored presidential elections, and the restitution of the public powers. Democracy has to be restored and a decent system of checks and balances needs to be in place.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the Venezuelan refugee crisis is set to be the world’s worst refugee crisis in 2020 and the most underfunded in modern history, and yet it hardly merits a headline in the newspapers. Venezuela is now second only to Syria in terms of how many displaced people are living outside their country of origin, with the United Nations refugee agency predicting that approximately 6.5 million Venezuelans will be living outside their country by 2020, outpacing the speed of displacement seen in Syria. Yet funding to aid this crisis affecting millions of Venezuelans and at least 17 host nations, has been seriously lagging. As ever, it’s women and children, the elderly and disabled who suffer the greatest deprivation – hungry, sick and often separated from family members. Women and children are also at risk of sexual abuse, forced prostitution, physical violence and human trafficking when on the move. Fearing discrimination in exile, they are reluctant to report incidents. It’s essential, therefore, that women, young people and minorities be included in sustainable solutions for peace and stability. And we, as Europeans, must withstand any calls for a military intervention.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, it is incredible to me that in the debate in this high house on the left side of the hall, we mostly just listened to justifications, relativization or simply not lying about who is to blame and who is the main cause of this crisis.  And this culprit should be named: it is a criminal, communist regime, first Hugo Chávez, and then now Maduro. And that's a fact. British Prime Minister Winston Churchill said socialism and communism produce misery, only it is equally divided. And we see it now and here. In Venezuela, we have witnessed the nationalisation of private industry, currency and price controls and the fiscally irresponsible expansion of welfare programmes. The result is that food production has decreased by 75% in Venezuela over the past two decades. This is what happens when the state manages everything, when socialist methods are used that have proven unsuccessful, that have failed here in Europe, and now we have it here.  Four and a half million people unfortunately had to leave Venezuela, and there will be more. In other words, let's name the causative agents, name the culprits, condemn communism, condemn the criminal regime, and may such things never happen again.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr High Representative, i would like to thank you for your comments. In fact, this was not difficult to predict a few years ago, when this new adventure began in Venezuela, where it was ruled on the basis of a populist hand-out, as long as there are enough resources, these resources readily available, instead of organizing society and the economy. Now we have these two aspects that we are talking about here. On the one hand, the wickedness of the government and, on the other hand, the mischievity, poverty, poverty, misery, simply society. And the dilemma that is facing us, namely, firstly, whether to consider sanctions or – and Here I am with you, Mr High Representative Borrell – simply to propose a deal. Oil for food – yes. Oil for drugs – yes. Oil for clothing – yes. Because we're just going to help these people. No, we will not change government by force, but we can help people.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian situation in Venezuela has long reached absolutely dramatic proportions. The figures are overwhelming: 90% of the population lives below the poverty line, more than 50% of children do not go to school. To date, we have more than 4.5 million displaced people and this figure, if this crisis situation is not resolved, is expected to reach 10 million displaced by 2023. Imagine a total comparable to the Portuguese population, almost comparable to the Portuguese population. The international financial programme to support refugees is delightfully completed and is inefficient in view of the seriousness of the situation and the pressing needs presented by this displaced population. But the truth is that all support is not enough, it will not be enough. It is necessary to find a definitive solution, a solution that allows the country to find stability. This is only possible if we force political actors to place the country's interest above individual interests and accept free and democratic elections.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Madam President, admired high representative, as has been said here, Venezuela and the region are experiencing one of the greatest humanitarian crises of our time. Of course, this is only expected to get worse over the months if a political solution is not found in the end. I think there are two analyses: firstly, of course, the international community has to be much more involved, many more resources are needed, because we are also talking about a crisis that is already being leveled up, in terms of the number of displaced persons, of the crisis, for example, that is being lived in Syria; but, on the other hand, as has been said here too — and I believe that all the parties who have intervened here have acknowledged – we will have to fix the situation politically if we want to stop the humanitarian drama itself. And I believe that there is no other way to find a negotiated solution and a peaceful solution to a free election that, in the end, recognize that there are two sides, and recognize the other side. And, in that sense, it's not about walking what we've walked, but it's about looking for alternative scenarios. And this is not fixed by taking many blows to the chest; it's not fixed with a lot of bravado; it's not settled with more sanctions probably. It's bravely arranged. Yes, courage has been asked here, and I, Mr. High Representative, ask for courage. I know that you are brave, and I also ask this institution for courage so that we can finally get out of this deadlock that Venezuela is in and help people.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, Mr Solana, ladies and gentlemen, five months ago there was a debate in this very House on the dramatic situation facing Venezuela, and today we are once again debating the same issue, but unfortunately, that the humanitarian emergency in the country has deteriorated over this period.  The number of refugees, including children, forced to migrate to other countries in the region is constantly increasing and for those who remain in Venezuela, living conditions are becoming increasingly difficult with deprivation of all kinds, human rights violations and violence.  In this increasingly untenable context for the Venezuelan people, the European Union must make its voice heard and step up its efforts to implement all diplomatic action in support of a peaceful solution to the crisis leading to free elections, but at the same time we must provide the country with the humanitarian aid it needs to make the situation of a people that has been suffering for too long less burdensome.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Venezuela is dramatic. We have millions of real refugees, perhaps too uncomfortable and unseeded, which is too little talked about.  A small step has been taken in Italy, where thanks to our initiative the right of Venezuelans of Italian origin, who have long been applying for citizenship and are waiting for feedback, to rejoin their motherland has been recognized. Therefore, pending free elections, Europe and its Member States should do more, for example to think of a facilitated path of socio-economic reintegration for the descendants of Italians, Spaniards, French or others who decide to return to live in the land of their fathers.  Instead, we are witnessing fearless and powerless, as usual, the uncontrolled arrival on our coasts of economic migrants largely from Africa and largely muslim religion, while we are disinterested in those Christians, often of European origin, who are actually forced to flee their land and have a bloody anarcho-communist regime that has persecuted political opponents, reducing its people to hunger.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, High Representative, Mr Borrell, once again, Venezuela. You will not come to a plenary session in Strasbourg where there is no debate on Venezuela. And many interventions combine chilling data with personal emotions, and I don't hide mine. Much of my dearest family lives in Venezuela: descendants of canaries who fled the terrible conditions of our land after the Civil War sought refuge in Venezuela. But, precisely, we are talking about refuge and it must be said that, of those four and a half million who have fled Venezuela seeking refuge, most have knocked on the door of Spain. The numbers are eloquent. Demands for Venezuelan asylum or refuge in Spain have increased between 2014 and 2019 in the environment of at least 400% and at least 100% year-on-year. Just the last week of November, four thousand. One hundred and twenty thousand so far this year. And therefore, since we are talking about solidarity, I believe that solidarity in the management of asylum seekers and refugees among the members of the European Union must also be called, starting with these Venezuelans who are so concerned and who we love so much.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela is real and it’s worsening, but of course it’s not accidental and it’s not just unfortunate. It was created by decades of efforts by the US to isolate and suffocate this country, to make it impossible for the people of Venezuela to determine their own future, and to make the economy bleed and the people starve. So we shouldn’t be surprised that there’s a humanitarian crisis, or that people have been forced to flee.  The fact that this Parliament threw its weight behind the unelected, self-appointed Guaidó brings shame to this House. It’s obvious now that you backed the wrong horse. This person has no authority, and has even being embezzling the very funds that you said are necessary in increasing humanitarian aid. But increasing humanitarian aid is really a bit like offering somebody bread while you stand by and see their bakery being stolen. Sanctions are denying people a decent future; they’re denying them medicine and access. You, High Commissioner, correctly said that millions of assets belonging to Venezuelans are around the world. Please help the Attorney—General; help the legal minds who are working with Venezuela to try to get their money back to enable the citizens to live a decent life in that State.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell said that the EU had organised USD 320 million to help the refugees from Venezuela and we’re ready to do more. The EU and US banking sector have stolen tens of billions and billions of dollars from Venezuela. If you want to do more, you should help them to get their money back. You should help the sanctions to be lifted. Why in God’s name is Europe supporting the illegal US sanctions? There is no logic to it. They are destroying the country. Maduro is probably no great president, no great leader, but I don’t know a whole lot of great leaders at the moment around the world. But you know what? The situation in Venezuela today has been caused by US sanctions. There’s a legal firm called Dentons Europe, one of Europe’s most reputable law firms based in Paris, and they are challenging the total illegal nature and the breach of international law that has taken place in relation to Venezuela, and are trying to retrieve some of that money. Please, Mr Borrell, play an active role in lifting the sanctions and honouring international law.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, although media attention has shifted to other Latin American countries where the social situation has deteriorated to violent clashes between the population and the security forces, the situation in Venezuela has not improved and is, to this day, undoubtedly the most worrying of these crises. Venezuelans continue to suffer the consequences of an economic crisis unprecedented in the history of the country, nor in that of Latin America. A chronic crisis, the end of which is difficult to see and to which has been added another very serious political crisis. Ladies and gentlemen, the time has come to overcome ambiguity and opportunism and work together to bring relief and immediate help to the Venezuelan population, who are experiencing an emergency crisis on a daily basis due to the collapse of public services, food and medicine shortages. It is a priority to coordinate to support the sixteen countries that are affected by venezuela's migration crisis and that have welcomed the 4.5 million Venezuelans who have been forced to emigrate. The international solidarity conference held in Brussels at the end of October is an important step forward alongside the Quito Process and demonstrates the potential that the EU has when acting in a cohesive and coherent manner. With a view to a second conference, we are making our voice heard.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: vice-président de la Commission et haut représentant de l'Union pour les affaires étrang.res et la politique sécurité. – Monsieur le Président, chers Membres du Parlement européen, merci beaucoup. L'un aprs l'autre, vous avez évoqué une situation qui est bien connue. Il est évident que nous avons un problame politique, vous n'avez pas ' me convaincre. Mais, personnellement, j'ai un problame de conscience et j'imagine que beaucoup d'entre vous pouvez l'avoir aussi. Parce que, c'est évident, malgré tout ce que nous pouvons dire du régime de Maduro, ce pays est privé de la possibilité de faire valoir ses ressources économiques. Depuis 2017, en raison des sanctions imposées, le Venezuela a été emp'ché d'exporter 400 000 barils par jour de son pétrole, soit l'équivalent de 8 milliards de dollars, quatre fois le montant des importations de nourriture. Et si cela continue, et si le revenu du pétrole tombe encore de 60 % comme cela est prévu, il y aura 300 000 personnes de plus qui ne vont pas avoir accs ' la nourriture, ni aux médicaments. Il faut 'tre aveugle pour ne pas s'en rendre compte. It is named after migrants, from gens qui s'en vont, to une cause: c'est que le pays ne peut pas utiliser ses ressources. This does not excuse political criticism of Maduro's regime at all. This does not excuse anything, but it is clear that, however communist the dictator is, the impact of sanctions cannot be denied, and that the political crisis is joined by a humanitarian crisis, to which we cannot expect to make a solution with the international community charitably providing resources. Because it's not possible to feed tens of millions of people every day. It is not possible to get humanitarian resources for that. The political problem is one, and you have no one to convince me that every effort is needed for elections to take place in Venezuela. I don't need any lessons on that. But we shouldn't deny a reality either. And many of you have said this: solutions must be sought to deal with a gigantic humanitarian crisis as a result of economic asphyxiation. And this Parliament has said so. You have voted on resolutions here where you say that no sanction can be applied to harm the people of Venezuela. You voted for that. And so the European Union has not applied economic sanctions against the people of Venezuela, but against its leaders. And, if we need more, more. But against the leaders. You cannot expect to resolve the crisis in Venezuela by massively condemning its people to hunger. It is a serious political problem that we must deal with politically, but we cannot close our eyes to the need— and many have said so — to seek solutions that replace humanitarian aid that the international community will not provide. Because we're not going to collect $1.5 billion of donations, which is what it takes for that, when until now the contributions are in the order of ten times less that amount. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that we are talking about a problem of an immense human dimension. The problem is not that the dictator is a communist. The problem is that this country is facing a political situation to which we have to respond as we are doing, and I believe that Europe has mobilized its diplomatic and political energies for this, but we cannot close our eyes to the fact that measures are being taken contrary to what you have voted for. Measures are being taken that dramatically harm the people of Venezuela. And that, believe me, is not going to be the solution. That's not going to be the solution.  The solution must be sought in an attempt to use Europe's diplomatic and political resources, in full cooperation and collaboration with Mrs Bachelet. Nothing I say takes away a gram of responsibility from Venezuela's political regime, but I think it would be a mistake on our part to think that migration flows are going to decrease if we continue to keep the country in a situation of economic asphyxiation.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at a future part-session. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In history, Venezuela, a country that has become Latin America's richest country at a 94% poverty rate and whose capital Caracas is the most dangerous in the world, is undoubtedly a borderline case. Worse, it could eventually empty its people, with Venezuelans making up the world's largest contingent of migrants, ahead of Syrians - the UN estimates that the country could have lost 25 percent of its population by the end of 2020. The fault lies with political orientations inspired by socialism, but also for American sanctions that penalize the civilian population above all. However, let us not be naive enough to see in Juan Guaido something other than the candidate of Atlanticism, which does not detract from all that the authoritarianism of a Nicolas Maduro has more reprehensible.  This crisis also reveals once again the inability of the European Union to impose itself on the international stage, at a time when Russia, China and the United States are making the law. Yet the events in Venezuela should have provided him with an opportunity to have a unique and unique voice in world affairs.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of human rights and democracy in Nicaragua (2019/2978(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, the situation in Nicaragua remains of great concern and is unsustainable. The EU position has been consistent since the beginning of the crisis. Our policy is to support a peaceful, negotiated and, above all, democratic solution. As in the case of Venezuela, only the Nicaraguan people can choose their leaders and representatives in a free and fair election in line with international standards. Here we can say it’s actually the same thing as in Venezuela, and the government must respect and protect the human rights and freedoms of the people. We established this position last January when, just ahead of the visit by the European Parliament to Managua, the Foreign Affairs Council underlined its readiness to use all policy instruments to contribute to a peaceful, negotiated way out of the crisis and to react to the further deterioration of human rights. At the beginning of this year, the Nicaraguan Government accepted to seek a negotiated way out and sign two agreements on the liberation of prisoners and the re—establishment of political freedoms. But it is clear that the government has failed to live up to these commitments. Most prisoners were indeed freed, but many were arrested again immediately afterwards. Political freedoms were not re—established. Reacting to these negative signals, the Foreign Affairs Council adopted a framework for individual targeted sanctions on 14 October. This, concretely, means prohibiting the entry into European Union territory and freezing the assets of people or organisations who have taken a key role in the numerous human rights abuses carried out by the regime. Our sanctions are individual, reversible and, above all, designed not to harm the Nicaraguan population as Parliament asked. There are three main areas in which tangible progress needs to be made in order to create the conditions for a peaceful and democratic exit from the crisis. They have stemmed from the commitments undertaken by the government itself – we are not requiring anything else – that fulfil these agreements. We have consistently repeated these in public and private, including as a part of the Council conclusions last October, and they are in line with the recommendations of the High—Level Commission and of the Organization of American States. First, re—establishment of political freedoms and the legal status of banned civil society organisations, as well as the release of the remaining political prisoners without charges. Second, full cooperation with and the return of international human rights bodies to Nicaragua, including the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. Third, an agreement on electoral reform between the government and the opposition, including the Civic Alliance. This agreement should guarantee fair and transparent elections, according to international standards, and be in line with the European Union electoral observation recommendation. We are ready to support with expertise and eventually with an electoral observation mission. The European Union stands with the Nicaraguan people and recalls that repression needs to stop and respect for the constitutional rights of all Nicaraguans must be re—established, including the right to liberty and the freedoms of expression, assembly, religion and peaceful protest. That’s what I want to again stress today in front of the Members of this Parliament, hoping, I’m sure, that with your support you can apply more pressure in order to fulfil these requirements.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I greet and applaud the words of the High Representative. Nicaragua's crisis began with the high concentration of power held by the Ortega, repression of the opposition, civil society, journalists and society at large. The strangulation of democracy and the rule of law is marked by impunity and exaltation of human rights violations. Let us remember, today, that it is not only nationals who suffer their vexes, there are also Europeans. This House has closely followed the case of Amaya Coppens, a Belgian student arrested in 2018 for participating in peaceful demonstrations against human rights violations committed by that regime. And today he is back in prison for having assisted some women on hunger strike. As we commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and celebrate that Europe is the cradle of respect for them, we must keep in mind the people who defend the foundations of our European way of life and are therefore imprisoned. Parliament cannot forget European citizens who suffer at the hands of cruel dictatorships, accused of sowing our values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and all fundamental rights. Amaya Coppens is unfortunately not the only one, and for her and many others we must raise the voice of Europe until they are liberated.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr Alto Represent, for more than once, this Parliament has expressed its concern about the political situation in Nicaragua, highlighting human rights violations, unjustified arrests, the lack of a genuine right to information. We recently learned that some human rights activists, including Nicaraguan citizen Amaya Coppens, had been detained when they distributed water and medicine to the mothers of imprisoned citizens who were on hunger strike outside St. Michael's church in Masaya.  We have learned that the Nicaraguan government has intensified its persecution of all activists and their families who have been demonstrating against their policy and, therefore, we have once again expressed our solidarity with the people of Nicaragua and we ask the Council to adopt sanctions for the freezing of assets and the prohibition of visas against those responsible for human rights violations. We encourage the Nicaraguan government to resume internal dialogue with the Civic Alliance to find a peaceful, inclusive solution to this conflict, dismantling paramilitary forces, supporting the reform of the electoral system, freeing illegally detained citizens and returning legal personality to the humanitarian associations to which it was withdrawn. We also ask the High Representative for External Relations and the European Union delegation to monitor this situation closely and ask the European Parliament to send a delegation to Nicaragua as soon as possible. Everyone who resists in a difficult situation in Nicaragua must know that we do not ignore their struggle and will not abandon them to their bad luck.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, respected Mr Borrell, I share and support your speech and your judgment, as necessary and as realistic. I would like to recall that in 1979 the people of Nicaragua fought and died for freedom, for democracy, for dignity, against the dictatorship of Somoza. I was there and I remember the absolutely fundamental support of Felipe González's Spanish Socialist Workers' Party. Forty years later it is tragic that this town has to fight again and die for the same thing, and this time against a new liberticide, that of the Ortega-Murillo marriage. Yesterday was the Soochistic National Guard, today it is the political police, the armed gangs that blood the streets of the cities in Nicaragua. The reports of Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, the Organization of American States, the United Nations, the Meseni, are absolutely abracadabrating, they are devastating. Because in Nicaragua there is neither democracy, nor justice, nor human rights, basic principles that cannot be excluded from our conscience and solidarity. That is why the most important groups in this Parliament have agreed on a joint resolution without amendment. Only those who, in the face of universal human rights, put their ideological boundaries before them have been excluded, only self-excluded. We reiterate our solidarity with the detainees, the tortured, the missing, with all the Nicaraguan people. But let's move from the sayings to the facts. The European Union-Central America Association Agreement, now in practical application, is based on democratic behaviour and, therefore, the motion for a Resolution to be voted on tomorrow has several essential points: to promote a democratic solution, through reliable elections, which means a fundamental reform of the system and of supposed justice, now perfectly vicar of presidential marriage; sending a delegation from the European Parliament to Nicaragua — I was already in the first, with Ramón Jáuregui, an exemplary person; the European Commission to establish without delay the list of persons to be sanctioned; Nicaragua to be opened the suspension procedure under Article 355 of the Association Agreement.

name: Tilly METZ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, over the past few months the Nicaraguan population has been facing government repression. There have been numerous violations of human rights and the rule of law. Hundreds of people have been illegally detained for peaceful protest action against the government, among them the Belgian Amaya Coppens. We are dismayed by the human rights violations committed by the authorities, and we call on the Nicaraguan Government to immediately stop the repression against its population. All political detainees should be released and democratic and fair elections should be held as soon as possible. Our diplomats in Nicaragua should continue making efforts to reconcile the different actors in the country and supporting civil society movements, but without taking a dominant position. As our resolution is a compromise between different parties, there are issues which are important for us Greens which weren’t included in the common text. I am thinking, for example, of the responsibility of European companies and their role in stabilising this questionable government. We need transparency about the current activities of European companies in Nicaragua and the due diligence measures taken by them. In the event of complicity in human rights violations, they have to be held accountable. As Chair of the Central America Delegation, I would really like to thank all the colleagues and advisers who have contributed to this resolution. It is an important and strong message of solidarity to the people in Nicaragua facing violations of their fundamental rights.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, the brutality of Daniel Ortega's socialist regime in Nicaragua continues to claim its tragic toll of death and terror. And all the warnings so far, the Resolutions, all the admonitions that have been made from the outside for the regime to stop this spiral of mass violence against human rights, have been useless. I mean, none of the warnings have helped. We continue to have, now we have had in this last crisis, hundreds of dead, massive torture, extrajudicial executions, rapes. In fact, the same scenario that we have had in the great repressions in Venezuela, at the time of Venezuela. Because, in reality, they are two parallel regimes, they are two equal regimes, they are two regimes that are governed by the same cruel and brutal arbitrariness, which is the one that governs and that is directed from Cuba. And you are continually turning your back on this evidence, that it is Cuba, from there and from Venezuela, where Nicaragua is protected and where this criminal arbitrariness that we are seeing in Latin America now is really protected. Thank you very much and I hope you react.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, denouncing the violence and repression against the popular movement by the Ortega-Murillo should never mean playing the game for the representatives of Nicaragua's economic elites. This Parliament must support a political solution that goes through the freedom of political prisoners, the cessation of violence and the recognition of the role of social movements in the negotiations. Make no mistake, when many of the Members of this House criticise Ortega, they do not do so concerned about human rights, but about the economic interests of European multinationals. When we criticize the situation in Nicaragua what we stand for is to stand in solidarity with social demands in the construction of a change, with a constituent vocation, that recovers the spirit of the Sandinista revolution, which generated so much hope among the popular classes of the whole world.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, tomorrow we are going to vote on a resolution in which Members of this House are once again denouncing the serious human rights violations in Nicaragua. Unfortunately, the situation has not evolved for the better, but on the contrary, even jeopardizing the rule of law. Figures that are certainly alarming. More than 80,000 people have been forced to leave Nicaragua; about 300 others have been killed; hundreds have been arbitrarily detained; hundreds of students have been expelled from college; hundreds of journalists have had to leave the country because of the repression to which the Government of Nicaragua is subjecting them. The situation of civil society and democratic opposition in Nicaragua is unsustainable. What else needs to happen for us to set sanctions on human rights and democracy violators in a partner country of the European Union, through an association agreement? Mr High Representative, you are well able to know that the situation in which the Nicaraguan people are located is regrettable and how the conditions of their democracy are increasingly deteriorating. If not, ask the Lord Secretary of State of the Church, who has been denied entry. We do not want to disappoint the people of Nicaragua and that is why we call for the unconditional and immediate release of detainees for political reasons, the cessation of harassment of the opposition and the guarantee of the exercise of fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, High Representative Josep Borrell, today we are here to denounce the very serious situation that is being experienced in Nicaragua and the deterioration in democratic and human rights that the country has experienced in recent months, if not already years. Moreover, this is in the hands of growing hostility on the part of the Nicaraguan Government towards the European Union. We've seen student, social leaders and human rights activist arrests happening in Nicaragua. And it is worth mentioning the case of Amaya Coppens; and people who are tortured in their arrests. For this reason, we make a clear and clear appeal to the release of all these detainees in Nicaragua. We asked for a list of sanctions for some people, for people in the Nicaraguan Government, to press for a way out of the situation in the country; a democratic, peaceful exit that includes all parties to the country; that fundamental rights are guaranteed and that it is ensured, as will be done, surely, that the European Union is at the hands of the democratic transition in Nicaragua.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Nicaragua must channel its crisis through the March 2019 agreements. The end of the crackdown must give way to a clean and credible election, guarded by an impartial arbitrator. It is necessary to clarify the repressive activities led by the Sandinista Government which, according to the latest statistics, have already caused 328 dead. If the blockade continues, I support the imposition of custom sanctions against those responsible for the situation, including President Ortega and his Vice-President Rosario Murillo. This crisis needs politics and needs empathy. That is why I ask Daniel Ortega to compare the photograph that captures his first oath as president, of January 10, 1985, with any of those who portray him now. Today is the image of desolation. Nothing resembles that of the hope that brought to the country the end of the Somoza dictatorship. Many of his compatriots, including the 80,000 who have already fled from there, begin to think that two such different surnames, that two such opposing trajectories are beginning to look too much like each other.

name: Assita KANKO
text: Mr President, my party colleague and N-VA Senator Mark Demesmaeker visited Amaya Coppens earlier this year. This 25-year-old student from Belgium is in a prison in Managua because she participated in protesting against the government of President Ortega. Thousands of people are in jail in Nicaragua for taking to the streets for a free and democratic country that respects human rights and fundamental freedoms. Has Ortega forgotten that he himself was once in prison for protesting against his government? We therefore demand the full implementation of the agreements of 29 March this year. We call on the Nicaraguan Government to start dialogue and put an end to the ongoing repression. Democracy must be able to prevail again. That is, free and fair elections. "I will stay here and continue to fight for human rights here," said Amaya Coppens. All people who are in jail for their protest must be released immediately, including that 25-year-old girl. We have to help them.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, this really is a kind of Groundhog Day, isn’t it? Every month we come in here, we denounce elected governments in Latin America who are battling to raise living standards in the face of vicious interference by the United States, and we recast these victims of the violation of human rights and international law as the perpetuators. I find it horrific because it’s the people in those countries who suffer. This is a country which defeated a violent, right-wing US-backed coup in 2018, a country which is suffering from economic sanctions unilaterally imposed by the US, and the idea that EU sanctions won’t target civilians is, frankly, a pipe dream. We have to join the dots on this about the destabilisation in Latin America. When the US handpicked Guaidó they talked about Nicaragua and Cuba being next. When Morales was overthrown, the White House released a press statement talking about the illegitimate regimes in Venezuela and Nicaragua, and last month they described little Nicaragua as an extraordinary threat to US security. This is a country under siege. The best thing we can do is call things as they are and allow the Nicaraguan people to determine their own fate.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, Nicaragua has been going through a socio-political crisis for more than a year and a half. As we have said, the protests against Daniel Ortega's government, which began in April 2018, have left more than 300 people dead, 2,000 injured and thousands imprisoned, including Amaya Coppens, whose only wrong has been to bring water to hunger strikers. The report published in September 2019 by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Ms Bachelet, highlighted serious violations of fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of expression, assembly, association and demonstration. Civic space has been greatly reduced, some independent media have been shut down, journalists arrested, human rights defenders and indigenous community leaders are being imprisoned and stigmatized, in a context where the judiciary is sorely lacking in independence. So, as we have said, the political dialogue with civil society has, of course, led to the release of 400 people. But others are still incarcerated; we have to keep going. This dialogue has to be resumed. A peaceful exit from the crisis and dialogue is still possible, that is what Mrs Bachelet said. However, restoring trust must involve the fight against impunity. Those responsible for crimes, torture and murder must be held accountable. We therefore call on the authorities to re-open the country to international observers and we welcome, of course, the conclusions of the October Council, allowing the implementation of targeted sanctions. The European Union, and in particular its Parliament, will continue to monitor the situation and support you in your progress.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Mr. President, dear high representative, President Daniel Ortega and his wife and vice president, Rosario Murillo, are leading Nicaragua to a dead end. Political opponents, journalists, social activists are under brutal repression. I have here a letter from relatives of those already known as "waterers", who were kidnapped and arrested for bringing water to eleven mothers of political opponents who locked themselves in the church of San Miguel to claim the freedom of their children. In this letter they say that one of them, Neyma Elizabeth, is seriously ill, 25 years old, has been denied medical assistance and her imprisoned colleagues — let me quote them: Olga Valle, Olama Hurtado, Ivana Alvarez, Amaya Coppens and Wendy Juárez – have started a hunger strike last Sunday to demand health care. Neyma's parents don't know where their daughter is, just as many Nicaraguan parents don't know. But what they do know is that today political prisoners in Nicaragua are in inhumane, isolated prison conditions and suffering violence. That is why this Resolution calls for the immediate release of prisoners and repressive sanctions against the perpetrators, starting with Ortega.

name: Alicia HOMS GINEL
text: – Mr President, nine months after the last resolution adopted by this Parliament on Nicaragua, the situation in the country has not improved, but quite the opposite. The regime's crackdown has increased and citizens' freedoms have continued to be cut.  In the face of this deterioration, the European Parliament must send a clear message. Human rights violations of Nicaraguans must cease immediately. We will all agree that in this resolution we must take it a step further and take a tougher position, as we have sufficiently insisted on the regime in previous Resolutions and now it is our turn to act. The European Union should therefore begin to apply the individual sanctions needed immediately to push the regime more directly.  Still, I don't think it would be smart to break all contact with the Nicaraguan government. Electoral reform, fair and guaranteed elections and an end to repression will only come through dialogue. And, in order to restore dialogue, European diplomacy can play a very important role. Let's push the regime, but let's not close the doors ourselves. Let's be smart and make our action useful.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, High Representative Mr Borrell, as in the case of Venezuela, I make mine all the allegations of repression, arbitrary detention and even extrajudicial executions, which have been made in Nicaragua. But unlike Venezuela, once a long time ago, after the Sandinista revolution, the current President Ortega came out of power and the government for an election and, since then, in every election in Nicaragua there has been an electoral mission of the European Union, accompanying it. The latest report was extremely critical. You mentioned the possibility that the future could be made possible through elections that are again free, equitable, transparent, truly democratic. The European Union will have to be on an electoral mission to ensure this, but first there is a lot of work to be done. The European Union must use all its diplomacy so that, as soon as possible, a credible electoral process can take place in Nicaragua that restores democracy and that, again, we will see President Ortega again, if that is the case, leave the Government and power for truly democratic elections.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, selective hearing can be problematic in here at times. In August this year, hundreds of thousands of people gathered in Managua to celebrate the Sandinista Front’s victory over the US-supported Somoza’s regime in 1979. They were also celebrating the victory of the Sandinista Party and the elected government over a US-backed coup last year only. The protests were led by a far right student movement, trained and funded by the National Endowment for Democracy, a CIA front organisation that has a long history of regime-change meddling. We also know now that US-funded NGOs inflated figures against the government. Some human rights groups became weapons for the US regime-change model. This country, and all South American countries, have suffered so much for a hundred years. US meddling in the place has seen so many people go to the Mexican border. It’s a struggle for an existence after their land was robbed from them. The place is covered in bananas run by US companies. There is no fairness in what the US have got away with down there. Mr Borrell, it’s about time Europe actually stood up and allowed the people of Nicaragua, Venezuela, all these countries, let them decide their own future.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to express my closeness to the Nicaraguan people who, as you know, are going through a dramatic political and humanitarian crisis.  More than 300 dead, perhaps even more, thousands injured, almost all demonstrators. It is the tragic measure of the crisis in Nicaragua for 18 months now. The strategy of depression adopted in the face of peaceful demonstrations, apparently directed at the highest levels of government, has led to a cruel and systematic assault on the right to life, political pluralism and freedom of expression, which are an essential pillar of democracy. The serious and continuing violation of human rights, as well as the abuse of power by President Ortega and his family regime, violates the Constitution, seriously affecting the democratic order of the country. Prisoners live in inhumane and unacceptable living conditions.  We therefore call on the authorities to assume their responsibilities, to guarantee the exercise of fundamental rights, but above all we must, ladies and gentlemen, immediately apply individual sanctions. Only through dialogue between the parties and respect for the agreements reached at the table will it be possible to reach a way out of the dramatic crisis, and we will support you in this, Mr Solana.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you very much to all of you. For sure, a peaceful and democratic way out of the crisis requires meaningful electoral reforms in order to let the Nicaraguan people decide their destiny. On that, I think everybody agrees. But I don’t think the fault really lies with the CIA or the banana company.  We are facing a situation of repression and violation of human rights by the Ortega regime, and the fact that Ortega was for a long time a guerrilla fighting for the freedom of his country doesn’t change anything about the current situation.  Every one of you wishes the best for the Nicaraguan people. Me too. But politics is not just piling up wishes. What can we do? Some have proposed suspending the European Union-Central America trade agreement with Nicaragua. I think the suspension of the trade part of the EU-Central American Association Agreement could create hardship for the Nicaraguan population, not only in Nicaragua but also in the rest of the Central American region. And I do not think this is a good idea.  Why not suspend EU cooperation? We haven’t suspended EU cooperation, once again, to avoid harming the Nicaraguan population. Our cooperation activities have been screened to ensure that they do not benefit the regime directly and our financial instruments have been used to support human rights defenders and the Nicaraguan refugees in Costa Rica. Why has the European Investment Bank not suspended its operation? For the same reason. We are sticking to our contractual obligations.  Should we call for early elections? Well, during the demonstrations in mid-2018 the opposition insisted on bringing forward the elections, a request that President Ortega fiercely rejected. I think that if electoral reforms are not adopted beforehand, then the electoral process would be of no help. Our priority should be the implementation of electoral reforms on the basis of the recommendations made by the European Union in the last observation mission.  Why haven’t we sanctioned Ortega or Vice-President Murillo? Well, the US and Canada have adopted individual sanctions against Vice-President Murillo and members of the Ortega/Murillo family. We haven’t done it yet. This is something the Member States should be reflecting upon. I don’t exclude it, but sanctions are meant to create incentives for a change. That’s why and how we have to calibrate them.  Are we expecting to send an electoral observation mission to Nicaragua? Well, in the current situation of repression and failure of the rule of law, I do not think it would make any sense. What we have to do is put our political and diplomatic pressure in order to release the prisoners, not only the Belgian lady that has been mentioned, there are many others. I have to inform you that our head of delegation in Nicaragua has been visiting the families of these prisoners and in particular, the father of Amaya.  We will continue putting political pressure, because I think that there we really have a systematic violation of human rights and there is no excuse for it. It’s not a matter of multinational injuries, it’s clearly a matter of a regime which doesn’t pass any kind of test about their behaviour with respect to their people’s rights.  I have mentioned the desirability of adding names to the list of individual sanctions. This would require a discussion at the level of the European Union foreign affairs ministers and then agreement by unanimity. We will discuss it and I really ask for your support in order to face the situation in Nicaragua, which is, as I said, as bad as in Venezuela, but we don’t talk about Nicaragua as much. Today is a good occasion to do so.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I have received five motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will be held on Thursday, 19 December 2019.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the violent crackdown on recent protests in Iran (2019/2993(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, you are all aware that Iran is in the midst of an extremely serious economic crisis with shortages of basic supplies, including medicines, a high level of inflation and unemployment leading to protests. I and my service have followed the developments around the recent protests very closely. Since they began on 15 November, one month ago, we have been trying to obtain reliable verified information on the number of deaths, injuries and arrest. We have also seen, as I am sure you have, video of snipers shooting at protesters and seen official confirmation of at least 7 000 people arrested. This underlines the severity and the magnitude of what is occurring, what has occurred, what is still happening.  We have not been silent in response to these developments; on the contrary, we have responded both privately and publicly. Indeed, my first statement as High Representative on behalf of the 28 – still 28 – Member States on 9 December was about the protests in Iran. In that statement we clearly stated that despite repeated calls for restraint, the Iranian security forces’ disproportionate response to the demonstrations led to a high number of deaths and injuries, and once more I want to emphasise that whether in Iran or elsewhere, the widespread use of force against non—violent protesters is unacceptable. We have urged the Iranian authorities to ensure transparent and credible investigations to clarify the number of deaths and arrests and we expect all perpetrators of violence to be held accountable.  I’m aware that this crackdown also extended to access to the internet and that Iranian citizens were prevented from accessing global networks, which severely impacted communication and the free flow of information.  We are committed to pursuing a balanced and comprehensive approach with Iran; a balanced and comprehensive approach with Iran with a view to addressing all issues of concern and this of course includes our long-standing concerns regarding the human rights situation. In the context of the regular EU-Iran high-level political dialogue with Iran – with the adoption of the Iran nuclear deal, the famous JCPOA – we have raised human rights issues and cases. We have also regularly engaged with the authorities to demand progress on several important human rights, including the use of the death penalty, the rights of women and Iran’s practice of detaining dual nationals. This has also extended to demanding such improvements in international fora such as the United Nations Human Rights Council.  I fully understand the severity of the situation with regard to the protests, and we will continue to address this response and urge concrete actions as part of our diplomacy with Iran, which is not limited to the nuclear problems still. We firmly believe that the Iranian authorities must live up to their international obligations, including both the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Rights such as freedom of expression and assembly must always be respected and I am looking forward to working with you to promote better respect for these rights across the world. Today we have analysed several cases of this situation, which require a stronger stance from the European Union.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, protected by the desire of the European Union to have a nuclear agreement at all costs, the Tehran regime has pounced with all force on its own people. Suffocated by enormous military spending, corruption, and US sanctions, the regime of supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has moved on to a brutal crackdown on demonstrations that have broken out across the country.  Iranian citizens in 31 provinces and 140 cities were simply crushed by the disproportionate force with which the regime acted against them. According to Iran's National Council of Resistance, the regime defeated the Citizens' Movement for Freedom with unprecedented violence. About 1,500 dead, 504 of whom are confirmed by this time; about 10 000 people arrested; about 4,000 wounded. Now the regime is looking for and arresting participants in demonstrations, particularly local leaders.  We, the European Union, have an obligation to protest and act. I must acknowledge and recognise that the European Union, in relation to Iran, has become a prisoner of the nuclear treaty. This is the truth, but also the reason why we do not see that, in its ambitions to be a regional power, Iran is involved ...  (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word).

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, welcome to this House and thank you for the time you have devoted today to all these situations of human rights violations. I, on behalf of the Socialist and Democratic Group, make my own, your position, your speech, which has been complete and detailed and also consistent, in condemning and rejecting what has been experienced in Iran since last November. Just, therefore, add a few elements to what the high representative said. First, remember that these demonstrations are surely the largest that have been experienced in four decades of Iran's current regime. Demonstrations that, as has been said, have failed to take place peacefully and in which proven reports from the United Nations and Amnesty International have shown that they have caused at least 300 dead and 7,000 non-fatalities. Many of these protesters, it has also been said, have been arbitrarily detained, face death sentences, and are also denied basic rights, such as informing their relatives of their whereabouts and health status, as well as assisting effective legal defense. The high representative himself spoke of the digital blackout. I believe that the resolution which this Parliament votes on tomorrow is a necessary initiative, which we hope will support and contribute to the work you are doing in this area. The voice of the European Union and this Parliament must be heard. The Iranian government's reaction has been extremely violent and could be the beginning of a more oppressive cycle in the coming days. Let us not lose sight of the view that this is a state of enormous importance and indispensable, with which we need to have an interlocution. We do not doubt that, with you at the helm, the Union's foreign policy will live up to it.

name: Luisa PORRITT
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, following our last resolution in September about the detainment of EU-Iranian dual nationals, including my constituent, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who is facing her fourth Christmas in a jail in Tehran when she should be at home with her family, the Iranian Government has shown a further flagrant disregard for the rights of its own people. Last month saw the biggest protest since the 1979 revolution break out in response to a 50% increase in fuel prices. This peaceful protest was followed by a brutal crackdown by the Iranian authorities, involving the arrest of up to 7 000 individuals, hundreds of people being injured, and according to Amnesty International, at least 304 people, including children, have been killed. Freedom of expression and freedom of assembly are recognised as fundamental rights by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Iran is party. The protestors in Iran had a legitimate reason to be protesting, yet the Iranian authorities responded disproportionately and inflicted harm on them. It is the duty of governments to protect their own people. These actions are a far cry from that. Furthermore, the nationwide shutdown of online communications by the government has made it difficult for Iranians to tell their stories. This is an infringement of their free speech. Such behaviour is set against a backdrop of an increasingly repressive environment in Iran, which has seen human rights defenders, independent media, lawyers and online activists targeted for speaking out about what is happening in the country. The EU must act now. This resolution, which will be discussed tomorrow, demands that the protesters be freed unconditionally; calls upon you, Mr Borrell Fontelles, as the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to continue to raise our concerns about the human rights situation in Iran; and asks that the UN Human Rights Council conduct an investigation. The rights of the Iranian people and dual EU nationals cannot wait.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, more than 300 people were killed and thousands arrested during last month’s protests in Iran, following a brutal crackdown by the Iranian authorities. However, the Iranian government has not provided any information about the protests to date and continues to deny the grave human rights violations perpetrated against those protesters. The official death toll as well as the whereabouts of many detainees continue to be unknown. There are also credible claims that those who have been held in detention have been subjected to ill treatment. Journalists, students and human rights defenders have been among those detained and killed for defending their rights. We therefore have to call on the Iranian authorities to put an end to the ongoing crackdown on protesters and to ensure that a prompt and impartial investigation, led by the United Nations, is carried out to clarify the facts and hold accountable all those responsible.
