The EU and its Member States should join this call and ensure proper scrutiny of the facts by proposing an independent inquiry into those human rights allegations. The economic situation in Iran has been worsening as a result of the US sanctions, and the recent protests are a reflection of this economic unease. That is why I want to celebrate the efforts made by the High Representative in order to continue boosting the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the JCPOA, which remains the most important tool that we have to stabilise the region and also the most important tool that we have to have a proper dialogue on human rights with the country. We need, as Europe, to continue towards that path, to make sure that everybody respects that framework. And for that, I think that your efforts will be extremely necessary and important.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, already more than two years since the authoritarian regime of the ayatollahs was challenged in the streets. Three weeks ago, the government shut down the internet in an attempt to stem the spread of this protest. Iran, located at the heart of the power and domination games between China, Russia and the United States. Let us not forget that, as a balancing force against Saudi Arabia, Iran has helped bring peace to Syria. We condemn, without any appeal, the liberticidal policy of the Islamic regime and we support, of course, the Iranian people in their quest for freedom. But we also condemn Western diplomacy which, by turning a blind eye, by trading with the terrorist financiers Qatar and Saudi Arabia, aggravates the situation. In this Chamber, the majority likes to give the whole world moral lessons. A resolution is not diplomacy. Let's sweep our door: here too, freedom of expression is often threatened. The European Union is not legitimate to make an effective voice heard; it has lost all credibility in the Middle East after the Libyan and Syrian fiascos. Let the nations of Europe, the only real actors of diplomacy, defend their interests and peoples, choose their destiny.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, even the lowest, most cautious number of victims of the recent crackdown in Iran against peaceful protesters means an enormous death toll – a shocking death toll. Thousands are being kept behind bars. Thousands have been injured. In view of this situation, we have to raise our voice. I’m very grateful to the European Parliament that, across political divisions, we are able to prepare a joint resolution condemning the regime for the killings, asking the UN to independently investigate the issue, requiring the regime to publish reliable numbers of the victims, releasing bodies to the families of the victims, and putting an end to the continued impunity of those responsible for the crackdown and the violence against society in Iran.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Firstly, it is quite clear that human rights are universal, and that has not mattered where and under what circumstances. They are non-negotiable! In other words, there is no relativising explanation for the violation of human rights, for the detention of people, for the killing of people – there can be no such thing – and that is why we are not going anywhere but to stand behind the protesting Iranians and support their demands. Now that we have awarded the Sakharov Prize in 2019, I naturally call on the Iranian leadership again and again to finally release Nasrin Sotoudeh. Secondly, it is absolutely frivolous not to address the fact that US sanctions do no more harm to anyone than to the Iranian people. These sanctions must be removed, and this must also be made clear from here. The worsening of the social situation in Iran is not only made in Iran, but also made in the USA. Anyone who is really serious about human rights must also criticise the United States, which must stop its unilateral policy of interests in the Middle East, because that is destructive. Anyone who believes that more and more repression leads to regime change is really naive. The only people who really benefit from the current situation are the Iranian hardliners. But these are precisely the ones most responsible for the violation of human rights in Iran. But they are supported by it. I would ask you to take note of this connection. We should not be petty, nor should we be naive and address things as they are, and I believe that we are here on that too.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Mr President, like the others, I deplore the recent deaths and human rights violations in Iran and the continued imprisonment of political prisoners like Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe who should be freed immediately. But the number one policy aim in Iran is to stop it building a nuclear weapon and destabilising the Middle East, but it is now reinstating uranium enrichment. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) nuclear agreement offered hope, but we must brace ourselves for its failure and urgently look for a Plan B.  The Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (Instex) – the EU plan to circumvent US sanctions – is taking too long and offers too little. The fact that the US is the EU’s largest trade partner, a thousand times greater than trade with Iran, speaks volumes to the EU’s priorities. Its plan to route Iranian oil through Russia won’t help. The EU’s attempts at foreign policy in this area are in a mess. Iran is now threatening reprisals against the EU members.  It is right that a coalition of Member States and other global players is part of the solution, but without the active involvement of the US, the EU is whistling in the wind. Many people in this Parliament deny President Trump. I’ve lost count of how many virtue-signalling MEPs have tried to score cheap points by insulting Europe’s greatest protector and ally, but if we want to keep the Middle East nuclear-free, resume trade, and support the human rights of Iranians, only the Americans have the power, relationships and influence in the region to make this happen.  The EU needs to urgently restore friendships and influence in Washington, not Tehran, and I’m certain that Brexit Britain’s special relationship with the US can help.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Borrell! I was born in 1979, and as old as I am, this regime has been in Iran for so long. Previously, this society was on its way to a colourful situation, rather than a black-and-white situation in which society finds itself today, on the way to a brightness, not in the dark times in which Iranian society finds itself today. When we talk about protests being violently crushed, we must not look at the wrong images. This is not about bloody noses or some square wounds – which could be unjustifiable – there are more than a thousand deaths – a thousand deaths that the regime is responsible for in its own population. Mid-November – it was only a few weeks ago, and that is a few weeks before the beginning of the 20s of the 21st century. What do we have to do? We have to keep making it clear that we have a nuclear agreement. Not because we believe the regime is trustworthy, but precisely because we do not believe it to be trustworthy, we need the agreement in black and white to prevent Iran from developing weapons of mass destruction, because Iran is a security risk to the whole world. I therefore call on you, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to be serious about the diplomatic sanctions that you announced in your speech. We owe this to the Iranian citizens, who stand by them in the name of human dignity and freedoms.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Mr President, in less than a month this Parliament is once again debating the dramatic situation in Iran, which we know has worsened in recent weeks. The Iranian government not only ignored calls for restraint, but intensified the brutality of the repression of peaceful protests that took place across the country despeloted by the very serious economic, social and political situation. 304 people murdered, including 12 children, thousands of arbitrary detentions, inhuman and cruel treatment of detainees who remain unreachable, beatings, torture and direct incitement in the public media to the application of the death penalty. These are numbers and facts recently made public that we cannot ignore. Respect for human rights is a fundamental part of the dialogue we have with the other States, but it must also be done in the high-level political dialogue between the European Union and Iran. All means must be used, Commissioner, to persuade the Iranian authorities to assume their responsibilities and to comply with the international conventions to which they are committed.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Mr President-in-Office! The violent crackdown on demonstrations by disgruntled citizens, which resulted in more than 100 people dead and detained, the fate of which is still unknown today, reminds us of the brutality and uncompromised and violent ness of the theocratic regime in Iran. Of course, we can have different views and opinions as to whether or not the American withdrawal from the nuclear agreement was justified and whether or not the sanctions imposed are an appropriate move. However, nothing justifies the violence and brutality with which the Iranian regime has suppressed and continues to suppress the dissatisfaction of the population. The imposition of sanctions cannot and should not be an excuse for the brutality and violence of a regime that relies increasingly on the repressive apparatus and paramilitary forces with which violence is carried out at home, but also in the region.  Whatever the interests, the European Union must strongly condemn the regime's actions in Tehran and unequivocally tell it that, despite our interests, we will not depart from our fundamental values. We must demand from our interlocutors that at least minimum established human rights, international law and, last but not least, respect for our own national law.  The brutality of the regime, however, points to its instability and sense of danger, and the Iranian theocratic regime must be aware that the use of brutal force at home and the creation of regional hegemony will prove to be a viable one. The only way forward is the profound social, social and political changes that will enable Iran to gradually return to the international community.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, which people would accept that the price of petrol would double without protesting? We understand these protests in Iran. In France, motorists are harassed with 80 km/h, speed cameras, tolls, the price of diesel that soars. Iran's public order has been maintained only at the cost of a particularly authoritarian response from the state, a state which we hope to evolve: the end of the death penalty for apostasy of Islam and the clarification of the role of the guardians of the revolution, for example. However, what is our credit in Iran today? The Service for European External Action and French diplomacy are themselves very embarrassed by the role imposed on them during the so-called Vienna agreements to achieve the unilateral withdrawal of the United States. The origin and drafting of this resolution express a clear desire to continue to exert two forms of pressure against Iran: the banning of the international community and the continuation of sanctions. However, this strategy is not effective, because Iranian society is particularly nationalistic. It does not support crude foreign campaigns aimed at forcing the country's social developments. Let us renew a balanced relationship with Iran before any new initiatives.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: – Mr President, High Representative, let me tell you a tale of two teenagers. Nikta Esfandiari was only 14 when she was shot in the head by the Iranian regime. Her family had to look for three days before her body was handed to them. Meanwhile, the teenage sons and daughters of those responsible for Nikta’s death are living a life of luxury, shopping in European capitals, posing on Instagram in front of Ferraris and attending the most prestigious European and Western universities. High Representative, we need a European Magnitsky Act now: targeted sanctions against human rights abusers. Let the family members of Iranian henchmen know that the door to Europe is closed. Let the family members of the murdered Iranian protesters know that Europe is on their side.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to condemn the tremendous repression being carried out by the Islamist ayatollah regime in Iran. We are talking about a repression which, according to data that are contradictory simply because the regime has wanted to cover up and hide what it was doing against civilians, has claimed more than a thousand dead, more than seven thousand detainees, according to the United Nations, and even twelve children killed. A tremendous repression. A repression that, as I said, the regime wanted to silence at all costs, as well as evade its responsibility, even blaming third-party nations. We are talking about the internet being blocked to more than 80 million Iranians. The media has also been banned from recording on the streets and, of course, of course, the United States, Saudi Arabia, or Israel have been blamed for social discontent. Today, from here, from the European Parliament, what we want to say to the citizens of Iran, to the Iranians, is that they are not alone. Young people who cry on the streets for their freedom and rights are not alone. Women who protest the mandatory wearing of the veil are not alone every Wednesday. Homosexuals aren't alone. Journalists aren't alone. And incarcerated human rights activists are not alone. I would also like to focus on the importance of coherence in defending human rights in this House and appeal to certain sections of the left which seem to defend human rights in a different way depending on where these violations are taking place, and to call on us to be forceful. That is why I would like to say that I find the motion for a resolution to be voted on tomorrow as a sparse resolution and I appeal to the high representative to move from mere condemnation to sanctions.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, the United Nations has said that at least 7 000 people have been arrested in Iran since the mass demonstration erupted last month. We call for the immediate release of those arbitrarily detained. It is truly horrifying to hear about the security forces firing on protesters, and many people have been killed during this unrest. The internet shutdown in Iran made it difficult for outside groups to document the death toll and for journalists to paint the full picture of what was happening on the ground in dozens of cities. It is unacceptable that people who protest because of social and economic injustices are killed and injured. We Social Democrats condemn the actions of the regime and demand that the violence stop immediately. The people of Iran need the EU on their side. This is why I’m happy to stand by this resolution, where we demand a stop to the violence and call for the EU to continue raising human rights and concerns with the Iranian authorities in bilateral and multilateral exchanges.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, without data, Amnesty International is talking about 304 dead, the Iranian opposition is talking to us about more than 1,000 people killed, 4,000 injured, 12,000 arrested. Again, the closure of internet access, to which you have referred. But, despite this blockade, we get video images that tell of unspeakable cruelty. Shots fired from the security forces, firing from helicopters, from building roofs, at protesters. Families cannot even bury their children, their relatives today, and two weeks ago a large number of bodies have been discovered in rivers and lakes in that country. Parliament today expresses its condemnation of this brutal repression. And we join our voice with that of the United Nations high commissioner and call for an independent investigation, led by the United Nations rapporteur, to identify those responsible, so that they can respond. The necessary political dialogue with Iran cannot advance on the impunity of executioners and the forgetfulness of victims.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, High Representative, throughout the last parliamentary term, I have been urging Mrs Mogherini to take a much tougher approach towards the Iranian criminal regime. The situation clearly shows that such a regime cannot be a partner of us, countries that profess democratic values and the values of the rule of law. A regime that shoots people, at its citizens who are demonstrating, there are hundreds of dead, deserves nothing more than total condemnation and sanctions on our part. I therefore ask you to take a much more radical, tougher approach towards this country than your predecessor voted for, let us demand a clear investigation of these crimes against iran against its own population, and let us deal with the extent to which, for example, the nuclear agreement today is not a piece of paper and to what extent it still stands. I do not think that it is possible to have good relations with Iran if it behaves in this way towards its people, who do only one thing – protest against corruption, against the rising cost of living, and thus allow themselves to realise their fundamental right of assembly.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Mr President, we had first talked about dozens of deaths, and it was already terrible. But nominal and still provisional lists now show more than 300 shootings, sniper bullets. This regime is therefore afraid, this regime fears for its survival and panic, because it is as contested inside as rejected in its Lebanese and Iraqi protectorates. The Iran of the mullahs is now more descending than ascendant, but what should be done beyond moral condemnation? We must propose, Mr High Representative, dear Mr Borrel. Diplomacy, and first of all those of the Union, should soon advance ideas on the definition of Iranian and Sunni zones of influence, the organisation of regional cooperation and the establishment of security guarantees. It will take time to get these proposals heard, but it is precisely because it will take a long time for diplomacy to regain its rights without wasting a minute.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Mr President-in-Office, on Monday evening, I have already spoken at this place about the casualties caused by the brutal regime in Iran. But tonight, I would like to underline some of the things that urgently need to be taken.  We should continue to support the opposition in the European Union loud and clear, a rebel movement that is fighting for freedom and democracy in Iran. Then we should redefine the relationship with Iran, and we must not close our eyes to this, just like the US should impose new sanctions.  Of course, we should introduce some other concrete measures against the Iranian regime, which is not only brutal against its citizens, but also poses a threat in the region. It is becoming a factor of instability, developing new weapons, not only threatening Israel but also other countries in the region and also the European Union. In short, it would not be a bad idea to also organise some fact-finding mission to Iran.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Amnesty International has just reported that over 300 people were killed and thousands arrested in a violent crackdown against peaceful protests in Iran. The recent wave of protests has seen over 7 000 activists, journalists, students and protesters arrested, all of whom could now be facing torture whilst being detained. We cannot stand idly by while the Ayatollah blames this on a foreign plot to oust him. It’s quite clear that the Iranian authorities wish to crush all political dissent and opposition. When speaking about Iran, I must mention the ongoing cruel imprisonment of dual national, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, on trumped—up charges and also the situation of UK permanent resident, Aras Amiri, who has carried out extraordinary service as a promoter of Iranian arts and culture but now finds herself behind bars: a bargaining chip in a cynical game of diplomatic chess. Finally, I wish to raise awareness of the ongoing harassment of journalists and their families in Iran, including those working for the BBC Persian Service. If we value media freedom, we must defend it everywhere.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, my solidarity, obviously, first and foremost is with the victims of oppression anywhere and everywhere, and the reports of violent and lethal repression of demonstrations in Iran is, obviously, something I, naturally, condemn. But the problem is this: even though human rights are universal, all human rights abuses are not condemned equally by this Parliament. Sometimes the human rights abuses are exaggerated, sometimes they’re not. But do you know what? They’re always the abuses of other states, never our own: states that stand up to the United States and Europe, states that have an independent policy, states that are closed to Western capital, states in the firing line. It’s obviously natural and right to support the victims of repression, but the skewed emphasis in this Parliament to twist it into a one-sided imperialist human rights agenda that only condemns repression in Iran, China, Russia, whatever – never the United States or Europe and their clients. Where’s the speaking out against the repression of Palestinians brutally repressed by the vicious Israeli war criminals? This helps to downplay genuine human rights abuses. We weaken our own authority by this and we should do well to remember that.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, Dear High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, the number of victims caused by the security forces in response to demonstrations in Iran is estimated at at least 304, including 12 children and 13 women.  When those who should be at the forefront of defending the population shoot to kill in the crowd, it is clear that a limit has been crossed. Unfortunately, once order was restored in a brutal manner, a new phase of violent repression began, which saw the arrest of thousands of people, it seems at least 7 000 students, journalists, human rights defenders. No, there can be no impunity for all this.  Allow me, however, to make a dispassionate comment, which is in no way a justification for these acts, which I strongly condemn: the demonstrations originated from expensive petrol, which in turn is the result of the extremely punitive sanctions imposed by the United States, both on Iran and on anyone who trades with Tehran. Clearly, these have had a devastating effect on the civilian population without having the desired political effect.  This must, in my view, be a wake-up call. When an instrument strikes, voluntarily or not, the weakest, in the often vain hope of influencing those in power in this way, perhaps it should be radically rethought.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: –Mr President, I would like to address the High Commissioner as a member of the Subcommittee on Human Rights in our Parliament. Mr High Commissioner, minors died, young people, students, teachers, Iranian citizens died who had no other way to express their displeasure, except through protest.  The European Union, our diplomacy can no longer address a path of prudence. We need firm and determined action to condemn what is happening now in Iran. We cannot, for the sake of the Nuclear Agreement, tolerate what is happening there. Iran is a hotbed of instability for the entire region. If we look at Syria, if we look at Yemen, if we look at Lebanon, everywhere we see Iran. We need decisive action, that's what we want from our Commission.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, High Representative Mr Borrell, yes, unfortunately, Iran is also a constant in this Parliament's debates on human rights. Only this time the situation is chilling: the death toll above 300, and 7,000 arbitrary, illegal, incommunicado detentions with torture exposed to the death penalty. When we talk about this we are not simply talking about repression of the rights of manifestation and assembly. We're talking about a popular blood-drenched revolt. And so the European Union has to be used thoroughly. It is true that we always introduce the clause of the preservation of the nuclear agreement, but diplomacy can do much in its political dialogue, not only with the Iranian authorities, but also with the opposition, to ensure that when the time comes for the repressive leadership in Iran to change, a qualitatively different political situation really comes, where there is pluralism , where there is ideological, religious and creed freedom, and also a non-nuclear Iran.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, while the weapons of sanctions have contributed massively to the protests, the response of the Iranian state to those protests cannot be justified. The state has used lethal violence – live ammunition – against the protesters, and this is inexcusable and should be condemned. We should also be condemning the use of force by the right-wing governments in Bolivia and Chile, where people are being killed and thousands are also being imprisoned. We must recognise, too, that this brutal response is warmly welcomed by the US, who use the language of human rights as a further weapon against Iran. The head of Iran policy for the US is Brian Hook, and he said: ‘We should consider human rights as an important issue in regard to US relations with China, Russia, North Korea and Iran, because pressing those regimes on human rights is one way to impose costs, apply counter-pressure, and regain the initiative from them strategically’. The US administration has seen the proof of Washington’s maximum-pressure policy against Iran as working, causing the Iranian people to turn on their political system. This is called ‘foreign interference’. Mr Borrell, do you approve of the foreign interference in Iran? Do you think that Europe should still look to get the JCPOA back on track? Because America’s ambition is to undermine the prospect for the same.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this exchange of views has been very informative and I thank the House for the opportunity to know more about your views on this difficult issue, namely relations with Iran. I can assure you that we will not ignore the plight of the thousands of individuals in Iran who were involved in, or affected by, the protests. I confirm our commitment to address these issues with Iran, publicly and privately, until we’ve got clarity on the full scale of what has occurred and with the expectation that those identified as responsible for the violence will be held accountable. This is in general terms. I will try to answer some of the specific issues that you have raised. It has been asserted that support for the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) has prevented the European Union from focusing on other issues. That’s not true. We have engaged in a frank and active dialogue with Iran on all issues, maintaining a range of EU autonomous restrictive measures, including on human rights violations.  We don’t believe that we would be in a better situation to address those without the JCPOA being in place. I can assure you that this is my strong belief. The JCPOA was first enshrined by a United Nations Security Council resolution and was not an invention by Europeans. It was the United Nations Security Council which adopted this agreement and we view it as a crucial issue for regional and European security. No one wants to see a nuclear arms race in the region and no one has been able to come up with a peaceful way of ensuring that Iran does not develop a nuclear weapon.  Having said this, we have on several occasions since June 2019 expressed our strong concern about Iran’s reduction in its commitment and we will continue defending the objective and full obligation of this agreement. We will do our best in order to save the JCPOA Agreement. Other people say that we are too soft on Iran. I want to engage with you in a frank and deep debate, and not to say that everybody is happy. No. Let’s go to the real issues. Are we too soft on Iran? I don’t think so. The EU still has a number of sanctions in place: first, nuclear proliferation sanctions under the CPOA; second, human rights sanctions – currently 83 individuals and entities, including a ban on exports to Iran of equipment which might be used for internal repression and equipment to monitor telecommunications because, when you disturb the traffic on the internet, you do that with sophisticated telecom instruments – and, third, sanctions under our Syria and CP931 terrorist regime.  So we are not being especially soft or hard. We do what we have to do and personally I think that you will understand that the JCPOA is something that is important for us, but it doesn’t prevent us from taking a tough position when such things as the ones we have seen in Iran happen. It is the case for additional human rights listing in response to the protest. To tell the truth, there are currently no proposals for additional listing on the table.  Having said that, the process for the annual review of the human rights regime is ongoing. As things stand, we still have human rights sanctions in place, as I told you, which affect 83 individuals and entities in Iran. This is a difficult question and we will continue working on it, at the same time using our diplomatic capacity in order to save a deal that is very important for our security and, on the other hand, defending human rights in Iran and elsewhere with our sanctions regime, our diplomatic pressure and our permanent claim to respect human rights.  This has been a very intensive part-session. It was my first part-session, ‘mon baptême de feu’. I would like to thank all of you for all your contributions and for your support. I know that not everybody sees things in the same way. From the left to the right, there are different approaches and different understandings of what’s happening in this difficult world in which we have to live. Today, having covered four difficult issues, thank you all for your contribution and thank you for your support for my job.  (Applause)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Six motions for resolutions have been submitted to me in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday 19 December 2019 Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - More than 1,000 people have been killed and thousands injured in the unrest in Iran. More than 12,000 protesters have been arrested and detained in schools and state institutions. Any use of excessive force against peaceful protesters is unacceptable and all perpetrators must be held accountable, and all those arrested for peaceful protest must be released and given a fair trial. It is important that Iran fulfils its international obligations and allows people to exercise freedom of expression and peaceful freedom of assembly.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Next point is the Council and Commission Statement on the EU Strategy to End Female Genital Mutilation Worldwide (2019/2988(RSP)

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the rights of women and girls and gender equality have been the main cross-cutting priority of the Finnish Presidency in the field of development cooperation, following a rights-based approach to development including sexual and reproductive health and rights. We are serious about our joint commitment, under the European consensus on development and sustainable development goals, to work with partners to eliminate all forms of sexual and gender-based violence and discrimination, including harmful practices such as, in particular, female genital mutilation. The EU and its Member States have long demonstrated strong commitment and leadership at multilateral level in promoting the rights of women and girls and gender equality. The Joint EU-UN spotlight initiative to eliminate violence against women and girls is an exemplary case in point, an unprecedented global effort to invest in gender equality and women’s empowerment as a precondition and driver for the achievement of the sustainable development goals. In Africa, the spotlight initiative is addressing sexual and gender-based violence, child marriage, female genital mutilation and their linkages to sexual and reproductive health access. The recent International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD +25) Summit, co-hosted by Denmark, Kenya and the UN Population Fund in Nairobi, was extremely successful. Extensive financial pledges were made from both public and private sources, as well as political commitments, notably a reaffirmation of efforts to achieve zero female genital mutilation by 2030, in line with our commitment under the 2030 agenda for sustainable development. Our achievements and leadership are real, but we must continue pushing until we have lived up to our commitment to achieve the objective of zero harmful practices against women and girls. The UN has named 6 February as the international day of zero tolerance for female genital mutilation, and around that day, the European Commission will take stock, as every year, of EU efforts in this field. We look forward to this report. We would also look with keen interest at the proposal from the Commission to renew the EU’s strategic engagement for gender equality that will be expiring at the end of this month. This should, hopefully, include an EU strategy to end female genital mutilation around the world once and for all. Before concluding, let me recall that, unfortunately, a significant number of women in the EU live with the lifelong consequences of female genital mutilation or are at risk of it. Without dismissing our achievements, therefore, we are aware of the need to do more in Europe with respect to the implementation of national laws, specialised support services, or enhancing multidisciplinary actions with affected communities. But I am convinced that, by continuing to work together, we will be able to secure further achievements in Europe and globally. Thank you very much for this very important discussion.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the European Parliament for putting this important topic on the agenda today. I also thank the Finnish Government for their commitment towards gender equality. This is a subject that is very close to my heart and I am committed to doing everything within my power to eliminate this scourge, this suffering which millions of girls and women are made to endure, even now as we speak. It is essential that we expose and combat this severe violation of human rights, women’s rights and children’s rights.  The EU and the United Nations programme to eliminate all forms of violence against women and girls, with an investment of EUR 100 million, is the Spotlight Initiative, as was already mentioned. With this project, the scope is to leave no girl, no woman behind. The current EU projects in several African countries and the support the EU gave to the UNICEF programme on abandonment of female genital mutilation (FGM) have reached more than 1.5 million women, who received services for protection and care related to FGM. This programme also galvanised civic movement through the encouragement of more than 3 000 communities, representing 8.5 million individuals, to make a public declaration of abandonment.  We know that FGM exists also within the European Union. Estimates show that at least half a million girls and women who have suffered from genital mutilation live in Europe. The European Institute for Gender Equality plays a leading role in providing information and research on female genital mutilation in the EU. In all our Member States, FGM is a crime. The efforts to combat it and support its victims are also integrated in EU legislation, notably the Victims’ Rights Directive. The issue is covered in EU asylum legislation.  The Commission continues to provide funding through the DAPHNE strand of the EU programmes for projects aimed at combating gender-based violence, including FGM. The next call for proposals will open in early 2020 with an indicative budget of EUR 12.4 million.  Honourable Members, we need to do more to make sure that the predictions of another estimated 200 million FGM victims by 2030 will not materialise. President von der Leyen’s Agenda for Europe has put the prevention of gender-based violence and the protection of victims at the heart of the Union’s equality policy for these five years. I am fully committed to the fight against gender-based violence and I am sure I can count on the support of the European Parliament on this matter.  The forthcoming robust gender equality strategy, which we will adopt in 2020, will address violence against women directly through various measures, including those addressing FGM. It is important to work on different areas at the same time and to tackle the issue from different angles and across the portfolios. I believe we can continue to work on the five priority areas outlined in the 2013 Commission communication on ending female genital mutilation, that is: improving knowledge and data, supporting sustainable social change, protection, prosecution and combating FGM worldwide.  Women’s rights are indeed at the core of EU foreign policy, and this includes the fight against FGM. We need to work with our international partners across the world to support the implementation of the UN sustainable development goals, which cover violence against women. The European Parliament has an important role to play through its political networks around the world. We have to acknowledge that FGM is a sensitive matter to tackle. It encompasses a variety of areas, from general human rights to women’s right to bodily integrity, the tackling of gender-based violence and the right to health. This is why it is important that we work together with FGM survivors, FGM practicing communities and experts in an empowering manner, free of misunderstandings and misconceptions. We must avoid stigmatisation, racism and xenophobia at all costs. We should instead promote empowerment, cooperation and dialogue. Apart from funding and legislation, we must include all stakeholders at all levels, from our political dialogues with national administrations, to our support for health care professionals, religious and community leaders, and families in eradicating female genital mutilation once and for all. I look forward to your views today, and to working with you towards this mandate on this very important issue.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, can I welcome the words already spoken here tonight by the Representatives from the Council and the Commission? Female genital mutilation (FGM): three words that have come to be understood as culture, tradition, even as a medical procedure. But those three words, those three letters are none of those things. What those three words are: an assault – violence, violence against women. And violence against women which results, as we know, in fundamental life-changing injuries: injuries that damage women and the very essence of what it means to be a woman. As of October 2019, UNICEF estimates that 200 million women and girls have undergone FGM in 30 countries – and that is just an estimation, let’s be clear, with many cases going unreported. When they think of FGM, most people’s minds go to the African continent, to places like Guinea, where 97% of women have undergone FGM, including 45% of girls below 14 years of age; places like Ethiopia, where 65% of women have undergone FGM. But the reality is, it’s happening in countries across the world, in places like Indonesia, Malaysia, and so on. What would we say if this was our mother, our sister, our wife, our cousins? Would we be as complacent as we sometimes are? We would be outraged. And we have to be the voice for those women who cannot speak for themselves. We are working to make sure the Istanbul Convention is implemented. Be clear: FGM is violence against women, and we must use every resource available to us to eradicate it. How do we do this? It has to be a serious, top-priority re-engagement on this issue. We have to have political leadership from the political leaders around the world, men and women. We must engage in a global multi-stakeholder approach: NGOs, communities and families working together. UNICEF concluded, from the surveys they have conducted, that the majority of girls and women in most countries with available data think FGM should end. We need champions to make this happen, like Ms Kanko, who I thank for raising this issue, like Ifrah Ahmed, an Irish champion who is working with the government of Somalia to eradicate FGM. Violence against women is a crime, FGM is a crime, and we must do everything in our power to stop it.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Always, unfortunately always, the body of women is a battleground. In every culture, in every religion, on every continent and at any time. It is always the female body that is accessed. How can this be explained? We remember: it was the female bodies, for example in China, it was the women who were tied to their feet in such a way that they were crippled – the so-called lotus feet – it was not the feet of the men. We remember: it was the lacing of women – corset lacing – that deformed the body so much that women had lifelong consequences, it was not the bodies of men. And now in the present? Now it is genital mutilation – a mutilation that robs or partially robs women of sexuality – for life that causes pain. And sometimes women are sewn, no men are sewn, women are sewn. Here, too, there are cultures, cultures of virginity, for example, a virgin culture that is constantly popping up in Europe. It is always, always, always about one thing: it is about the control of men over the body of women, it is about the shaping of the body, it is about restriction, and it is about inflicting pain on women.

name: Irène TOLLERET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, today 500,000 women in Europe and 200 million worldwide are victims of female genital mutilation. Their private lives, their life as women are affected. They bear the consequences on their own. We must eliminate this scourge and, in order to do so, adopt a common and pragmatic approach. First, by ensuring the collection and dissemination of data. We need accurate, comparable data and to put indisputable figures on the table to measure the evolution of this phenomenon, including in Europe. We need to work together, putting in place preventive measures that involve and mobilize all stakeholders, including the communities concerned. We also need support and legal protection for all concerned. Commissioner, we now have all the means at our hands to deal with this problem. I welcome the Commission's commitment to publish, within the first 100 days of its mandate, a strategy that establishes equality and tackles the problem of female genital mutilation. We also have the Istanbul Convention, which refers to female genital mutilation and has not yet been ratified by seven Member States. We Europeans must be the voice of these women and their outrage. At the current rate, 68 million girls will be exposed to female genital mutilation between 2015 and 2030 if we do nothing. It's unacceptable, let's not let it happen. You have our full support for the implementation of this strategy.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, female genital mutilation covers all interventions that involve altering a woman's genitals for non-medical reasons and are a violation of the fundamental rights of women and girls. These practices also violate their right to sexual and reproductive health as well as their physical integrity. Mutilation is a universal problem that affects countries in Africa, the Middle East, Iraq, Iran, Indonesia and Europe. In Germany, according to a prevalence study, there are more than 20,000 circumcised women and more than 4,000 girls considered at risk of female circumcision. The victims of mutilation living in Europe are mainly from immigration; they are in total close to 500,000. Genital mutilation is based on a foundation of social norms and erroneous religious beliefs. Despite a clear setback and the development of laws in 24 of the 29 countries concerned in Africa, pockets of resistance still exist. The participation of dignitaries and religious of Islamic obedience in awareness campaigns could be an asset in the eradication of genital mutilation. These are obsolete traditions that, over time, have been falsely equated with the Islamic religion. There is nothing in the Qur'an, the Bible or the Torah that requires a woman to be excised. Awareness and education work, supported by health practitioners, with the participation of young people, the future Charming Princes, can bring a new lease of life to achieve zero tolerance by 2030. We need to break the taboo through awareness and prevention, to reorient female circumcisors to other income-generating activities, and to work with the communities that practice mutilation, without stigmatizing them. The European Union must support organisations that help protect the physical integrity of women and girls, while respecting each other's culture, so that we can achieve the abolition of female genital mutilation. We are not fighting against traditions, but for the elimination of an act of violence that affects the health of women and girls.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking here about the EU's strategy to combat the inhumane and misogynistic practice of female genital mutilation. We have just heard from Mr Fitzgerald, Mr Tolleret and Mr Herzberger-Fofana that they are deeply condemning this bestial FGM of young girls and are determined to combat this inhumane practice. Such hypocrisy is really unparalleled! Just three weeks ago, they rejected an amendment to the Istanbul Convention aimed at addressing and condemning this disgusting practice. Why? Because they seem to care about the unspeakable suffering of the girls and women involved. It was much more important to them to reject the amendment because it came from me – the persona non grata with the wrong party book. The resolution adopted contains 3 331 words, and my 176-word amendment would have expressed in the resolution the determination with which this disgusting practice must be combated and prevented. However, the rejection of female genital mutilation is mentioned only once somewhere under the far run and downgraded to the status of a footnote. So to whom do you want to sell to fight female genital mutilation? Shame on you! Incidentally, Mr Palop, Mr McGuinness, Mr Pereira, Mr Walsh and Mr Jones will also be speaking on this item today, to name but a few. They, too, rejected this amendment. If she, too, were to separate the usual speech bubbles of hypocritical concern, it would be a truly vile and deeply despicable disrespect in the presence of the speaker following me, Mrs Assita Kanko.

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, FGM affects every stage of your life. It becomes a part of who you are – your ability as a child to trust; how you feel when you fall in love; your experience when you are pregnant; the way you give birth. It changes how you love others, and how you love and treat yourself. FGM is the worst kind of violation to your body, your mind and your dignity at a time when you are a defenceless child, and it never goes away. You do your best to survive and thrive, but you must, because you end up keeping an eye on yourself to never forget your value is the same as everyone else’s.  This is also my daily struggle – and that of 200 million women and girls worldwide, including the 500 000 who live in Europe and the many victims who remain every day. Change is too late, too little, too slow. We urgently need strategies and an action plan that achieve far-reaching and lasting impact.  I was moved and very much inspired by The Restorers, our finalists for the Sakharov Prize, who are here this week. They remind us that behind every action we take, every choice we make, there is a girl whose hopes and future or dreams rely upon us. We must first of all see them. We must hear them. We must protect them. We must together enable them to fulfil their potential and live a bright future.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, female genital mutilation, like other sexist violence, is a serious violation of human rights and a form of discrimination that seeks to subject women sexually and reproductively. That's clear.  Mrs Anderson, the problem is that there are those who use anti-mutilation discourse to fuel racism and Islamophobia from moral superiority and ethnocentrism and cultural imperialism that shame us as Europeans. We're talking about a practice that's not just in Africa. Sometimes you want to stigmatize an entire continent and criminalize the migrants who come from there. Female genital mutilation also occurs in the Middle East, East Asia and Latin America. And in the last century it was given even in Europe and the United States to cure invented diseases such as female hysteria. You see. And, yes, it is a religious practice, but not only of Muslim communities, but also of Coptic Christians and some Jews who make, by the way, a sexist interpretation of the Qur'aan and the Bible, where it is not contemplated.  Let's not kid ourselves. The far right and the extreme right in Europe don't care about girls and women who are victims of mutilation. What matters to them is the crusade in favor of their particular way of understanding Christianity. That is why they can pursue this practice and in turn oppose the Istanbul Convention, which is the only framework from which it can be ended.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Madam President, it disappoints me that this debate has been scheduled at the end of the day and not given the platform it deserves, with more in attendance – men and women, and with all 28 Member States actively participating.  It is very clear that female genital mutilation has not benefited the 200 million girls and women who have had this trauma done to them and, to bring it closer to home, it will not benefit the 180 000 women and girls who are at risk of FGM right here in Europe.  It is done to control girls’ and women’s bodies. It is done to control the lives that they live and the lives they are deserving to live, and it’s done out of false ideology that a girl would, or could, positively benefit from FGM. We – and I say the collective ‘we’ – need to recognise that harmful practices such as FGM cannot be addressed on their own, but instead should be treated through a holistic and comprehensive approach to end all forms of violence and work to an EU strategy preventing FGM from continuing for future generations of our girls and women.  Prevention measures need to focus on mobilising communities, traditional faith leaders, – women and men – presenting them as agents of change. This recognition is a critical step, but it is simply not enough. We – and again the collective ‘we’ – need to fulfil our commitments and continue to recognise our real responsibility within the global community and end FGM.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, according to the World Health Organisation, it’s estimated that more than 200 million girls and women alive today have undergone female genital mutilation (FGM) in the countries where the practice occurs, and that includes EU Member States. Furthermore, there are an estimated three million girls at risk of being cut every year. FGM is a form of violence against women and girls. It’s not a defensible cultural practice, but another manifestation of patriarchy. We can and must end FGM, but we need to work with all sectors of society in order to educate families and communities, to empower women and girls to take control of their own bodies, and to encourage men to speak out about this brutal practice. Today, I met an inspiring group of girl coders from Kenya who were nominated for the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. They’ve created an award winning app called ‘i-Cut’, which puts the power into the hands of those at risk by sign posting them to the nearest police station, health centre or NGO that can help them. These girls, and others like them, are leading the way.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, female genital mutilation is a plague that continues to threaten millions of women in some countries in Africa and Europe. It is a clear violation of human rights, a denial of gender equality and an attack on children, which has a vaccine. It is manufactured with training, cooperation, control and prevention. And Europe must lead its use to definitively eradicate this nightmare from the catalogue of threats against women. Our strength is the many laboratories that locally and regionally manufacture antibodies for parents, daughters, who are at risk of not being able to prevent or suffer this aggression when traveling to their home countries. There are care protocols in some regions, such as the Basque Country, which are based on schools and health centres dedicated to primary care, a holistic strategy. Thus, education, health, social services and justice work in coordination. A network protects families, forms children and adults, prevents, heals and combats stigmatization. They also inspire cooperation measures outside Europe, which take advantage of the knowledge acquired. Take advantage of this experience from the Commission, too.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: – Madam President, female genital mutilation, or FGM, is one of the most extreme practices performed to control girls and women’s bodies and roles in society. As a gynaecologist and as a parliamentarian fighting for sexual and reproductive rights, I strongly condemn this abhorrent human rights violation. It causes horrendous suffering to women and girls around the entire world, and we have heard the figures: 200 million women worldwide; 500 000 in the EU; and 4.1 million girls at risk on every continent in the world, across all cultural and social-economic groups. We will need the whole world to bring this practice to an end. We will need both women and men to stand up condemning this practice. We need politicians from all parties to condemn the practice, without falling into hate speech or spreading misconceptions. Europe should continue to take the lead in ending this FGM, once and for all, around the whole world, and I therefore applaud this call for an EU strategy to put an end to FGM around the world.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on a mission to Nairobi with a delegation from Parliament, I came back shocked by the many stories of women who have undergone genital mutilation in addition to forced marriages. FGM is an extreme form of discrimination and violence against women. To excise is to cut the clitoris of young girls, even children, with scissors or razor blades. These are acts of torture that constitute an attack on the dignity of women. The disturbing truth is that our countries have imported on our soil cultural and religious traditions that practice these acts of barbarism. Today, about 124,000 girls in France have undergone this barbaric practice and 21% of girls from countries practising female genital mutilation are at risk. The European Commission estimates that more than half a million women in Europe have been maimed, alarming and intolerable figures. What kind of society do we become, when so many girls in our own country have to live with the fear of being maimed? At the last plenary session in Strasbourg, my group proposed an amendment on these acts of torture. We condemned this hideous practice, we advocated clear measures to be taken, but unfortunately the text was rejected for political reasons. The list is there: 450 parliamentarians voted against. In some areas, female genital mutilation may be based on tradition, but this is not our tradition. Such beliefs have no place in our societies. In France, young girls who are victims of female circumcision point out that French legislation was not strong enough to counterbalance the weight of social pressure. It is therefore high time that our countries systematically prosecute the perpetrators of female genital mutilation. I therefore urge Member States to enforce mandatory reporting of genital mutilation by health and education professionals. Let us put an end to this laxity, to this lack of courage, and put hard for this barbarism. I will remind you that Europe is the continent of Helen of Troy, Joan of Arc and Marie Curie, women who are at the heart of our history and who define who we are. Our duty is to protect this Europe, the cradle of women's rights, by constantly reminding us of these values of respect and freedom for all.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Female genital mutilation occurs mainly in parts of Africa and the Middle East, but it also occurs here. In Germany alone, the number of women mutilated is estimated at 20 000, in France 60 000. And then there is Sweden with the world's first self-proclaimed feminist government, almost 40,000, which gives Sweden an unpleasant top ranking in terms of the number of women affected per capita in Europe. Everything also indicates that this elaborate torture with lifelong consequences is carried out not only when the girls visit their parents' home country but on the spot in Malmö, Borlänge, Borås, a stone's throw from social offices, police stations and newspaper editors where one is more upset that girls may want to wear pink clothes. We cannot abolish Female Genital Mutilation around the world ourselves. But when it comes to girls in Europe, we have more responsibility and opportunities. Tougher penalties, information campaigns and more government intervention are a must, but this requires political will and priority. This is not acceptable anywhere in the world, but it is a shame that it occurs on our own turf.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, female genital mutilation is an intolerable form of violence against women. It is practiced in childhood and causes physical harm, irreparable injuries to physical and sexual health and emotional damage for life. This is a practice that particularly affects the most vulnerable: girls up to 15 years and the poorest classes. It is essential to criminalize and punish criminals, but also to prevent this violence, to bring awareness and awareness actions to the communities in which these crimes occur, to educate new generations for women's rights. In our view, the fight for the eradication of female genital mutilation is inseparable from the fight for the protection and strengthening of women's sexual and reproductive rights, the need for access to education and, in particular, sex education and improving maternal and child health conditions. The end of female genital mutilation will be a breakthrough in the rights of women and girls, and that is why we fight.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Madam President, the figures of this scourge are terrible and surely only partially and incompletely reflect reality. If we broadn our gaze to the reality we see, it is that, in addition to genital mutilation, most so-called cultural practices make women and girls their victims. We are talking about polygamy, forced marriages or within prohibited degrees of kinship, selective abortion, laceration of various parts of the body, the withdrawal of girls from certain areas of education, such as the practice of sport or activity with children, or the imposition of extreme dress and concealment codes. All these practices show that the multicultural model – it is certainly overrated – is largely built on the contempt for women's and girls' rights. We have an obligation to prevent and detect; an obligation which falls first and for all to the school, health services and social services. We have an obligation to ensure that these practices do not go unpunished. Rapid ratification of the Istanbul Convention is necessary and call on all Member States to introduce extraterritorial prosecution of this crime. And we have an obligation to assist the victims. In asylum procedures, yes, and for those already in our territory, assist them by applying protection systems and specific protocols for the treatment of violence against women. To tolerate, to look elsewhere, to condemn only verbally, is not to respect other cultures, it is simply to deny the protection of the law, to deny equality and to undermine the dignity of women.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Minister and the Commissioner for the time given to this issue. We know that FGM is a global issue, and we know it happens in every country around the world to girls. We also know that girls living in the EU have been cut, including about 2 000 in Wales, the country that I represent – and it’s a pretty small country – yet prosecutions are really low, alarmingly low. Earlier this year, the UK saw its only prosecution for FGM, 30 years after it was first made unlawful. This demonstrates how little attention is paid to the grave consequences for the girls and women involved. Last year Wales opened its first clinic for specific medical and psychological help for survivors of FGM. Specialised services like these are vital, yet it’s exactly these services which are most at risk after Brexit, because of key EU funding being lost. Strong legislation is essential in protecting and empowering women and girls in holding perpetrators to account. The Istanbul Convention and CEDAW – and we celebrate 40 years today of CEDAW – are two powerful tools tackling violence against women and girls, including FGM, yet these remain largely unimplemented in the UK. We must use legislative tools like this as part of a holistic approach, and I just mention a couple: community and youth engagement, tackling disinformation, discrimination, protection of women’s sexual and reproductive health and rights, training, funding and education. Let’s make this the last generation of girls to face the cruelty and human rights violation of FGM.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: Mr President, 200 million women live with the consequences of genital mutilation every day. Enough is enough! This just can't happen anymore. It's injustice. In Europe itself, almost 200 000 women are at risk of genital mutilation, a major injustice that is often concealed. The pain is carried in solitude, even though there are already so many fellow suitors. Making it negotiable is important, but it's really not enough. As the European Union, we must use our resources to tackle major problems, to protect women and girls. Violence against women is a major problem. I therefore call on the Commission to tackle this terrible injustice. It is very good that you are going to work on a strategy, but it is high time for a strategy with teeth and also to push through sanctions against the perpetrators, to go to extremes and to ensure that this kind of violence is reported. Please also provide the necessary infrastructure. And if funding for prevention and aid workers is a problem, then the European Union must step in. And if countries are lax in maintaining, then the Commission must side with the victims. Enough is enough! Please, make this strategy effective. I really want it to be a strategy with teeth.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We, the EU, often strike ourselves as the defender of human rights throughout the world, which seems to be a distasteful joke in the light of the number of children, girls and young women from the EU being mutilated each year. 180 000 a year are at risk of this abuse, according to the European Institute for Gender Equality. The majority of these girls are not blonde and blue-eyed, but look more like me, and many are convinced that it contributes to the fact that we, the EU and the Member States individually, do not fight the risk of genital mutilation of EU citizens with the necessary force. There is a destructive cultural relativism that contributes to the continued abuses.  If we really want to combat the oppression of girls and women, then we do it best by standing up for human rights and fighting racism and patriarchal, oppressive structures – in whatever colour and form they come.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, while one of the first UN resolutions against genital mutilation dates back to 1952, more than 200 million women worldwide are still victims and 3 million more are at risk of being victims every year. This is an eloquent testimony to the ineffectiveness of international action in what should yet be a priority fight for the women's cause. All the more so because if we rightly mention the plight of so many women in sub-Saharan Africa who, for example in Ethiopia, where I come back, suffer these atrocities at 65%, we are overshadowing that of an increasing number of women in Europe, including 125,000 in France. Reflecting immigration, of course, this situation is also the result of religious obscurantism, especially among some Muslim communities around the world. Research funded in 2008 by USAID was a clear recognition of this. Naming the real causes and the real culprits is a decisive and salutary first awareness in a fight that is now being played out even on our soil. I would like to see no more moral lessons from Mrs ' 123', who is no longer there — I do not think she should give me any lessons.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Madam President, every year thousands of women and girls are victims of genital mutilation all over the world. Practice equivalent to torture that is attentive to the physical and psychological integrity of women. It is time to take concrete steps to end this scourge. We cannot accept that, based on custom, tradition, culture, or religion, this type of behaviour should continue to be perpetuated. It is essential that the international community has zero tolerance towards the thousands of acts committed annually, inside and outside the Union, which constitute a serious violation of human rights. Fundamental rights, the dignity of the human person and equality between men and women are fundamental values of the European project. It is, moreover, a crime in all Member States, but cases with judicial conviction snares are told by one hand. Greater capacity is needed by Member States to protect women and girls at risk. It is essential that those responsible for these crimes committed in the EU and outside the EU are tried and community involvement in education and awareness of this scourge is vital. This is the only way we will achieve the proposed un-based objective of completely eradicating this practice by 2030. I hope that this will be a priority for the new Commission and that the EU will be at the forefront in this fight.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, the adoption of a European strategy to combat female genital mutilation in the world is essential. Social conventions, religious traditions, stereotypes associated with female sexuality cannot continue to be a reason to cause irreparable harm to the bodies of girls and women. Unfortunately, there is little safe data available on this scourge that should no longer exist in the 19th century. It is known that there are about 200 million victims in the world, 500,000 of whom are in the European Union. There are therefore three aspects that we consider fundamental. Firstly, that Member States collect more data on this phenomenon in their country and train their professionals to this end to be more effective in combating it. Secondly, to support innovative technology-based responses, such as the i-Cut App of the Group "The Restorers", Kenyan girls, finalists of the Sakharov Prize, which we have received here today and which I hope to one day receive to receive the award, as winners, and that we continue to defend the European Union's support for the Istanbul Convention, where the criminalisation of female genital mutilation is planned. We won't lower our arms as long as a single woman or girl is the victim of mutilation.

name: Mathilde ANDROUËT
text: Madam President, 500,000 women in the European Union have been victims of genital mutilation, and every year an increase of 180,000 are at risk of it. These figures, taken from the European Parliament's website, are accompanied by this comment: female genital mutilation is still practised in some countries in Africa, Asia and the Middle East. In a word, these monstrous practices are not European, and yet they take place on our continent. Before we play the righters of wrongs elsewhere, let's do the necessary work at home. Why did we get to this point? By importing millions of human beings, we are at the same time importing all practices, even the most inhumane ones. As we accept anarchic immigration, we give a pass for violence. In France, for example, the number of mutilated adult women rose from 62,000 in the 2000s to 124,355 at the beginning of our decade. What is true for female circumcision is equally true for violence against women. Let's open our eyes! We cannot be feminists and applaud the arrival of thousands of migrants who, in part, despise and discredit women, sometimes to the point of mistreating or raping them. Europe could be proud of never destroying the bodies of its daughters in the name of obscure practices. But to this European pride, you prefer the politically correct acceptance of everything and anyone: offering these women in pasture is the own of the vanquished. In the name of respect for women, let us restore European values to their status as winners.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I have listened with interest to your speech and your initiative, in which I am sure the European Parliament will support you. I am glad that most of the performers see this violence against women as a great danger. Personally, I see two levels of this problem. Firstly, this violence that is taking place here in Europe, and then the violence against women that is taking place in third countries. You need to have instruments for both, but probably different. It is necessary, in my opinion, to draw up European Commission programmes that are clearly directed against this violence here in Europe. It is a shame that there are still tens of thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, of circumcision cases against women in Europe, especially in the environment of migrants arriving in Europe. It is necessary to say clearly to these people: you come here, you operate here, but you have to accept and respect our European values. And that is the protection of human rights and gender equality. Here I think we have some catching up to do. It is necessary for law enforcement, criminal authorities to cooperate, so that this conduct is really severely punished, including by the courts in each Member State. I think that cooperation between member states is not very great here and that we know about tens of thousands of cases. Let us say realistically: how many people in Europe have been affected for such behaviour? How many people have been convicted? Here's your role where you can operate. In addition, of course, it is necessary to operate in the Third World, where the work will be longer, more demanding, but I see the primary problem and your role right here in Europe at the moment. Here we owe it to those who live here or who come here and want asylum, dignity and protection of their human rights.

name: Vera TAX
text: – Mr President, imagine: you are an 8-year-old girl. You have no idea what's in store for you. One day you'll be called. You're being held and you can't cry. An adult is ready with a razor. Unceremoniously, your clitoris will be cut away. 200 million women and girls worldwide are victims of this heinous crime. They are usually mutilated before the time they are 15. Let me be very clear: this barbaric practice is never justifiable, based on tradition, culture or religion. I support the Commission in its fight to eradicate genital mutilation. Millions of girls are still at risk every year. That is why the EU must put an end to this as soon as possible.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: – We have said a lot about the mutilation of the female genitalia, this barbaric act, you have said, and in this spirit I would like to stress here, in addition to the terrible barbarity, the importance of prevention rather than horrification. So let's look at what can actually be done about prevention. Today, a very good example was that, at the initiative of my fellow Member Kanko, we were able to receive a group of young Kenyan girls called 'The Restorers', as others have mentioned, and indeed have a dialogue with the younger generations. Let us note that only in Africa, the continent I love dearly, 42 percent of the population is under the age of 14. With the new generations growing up on the youngest continent, we need to do much more, much more efficiently, but this can only be achieved through dialogue and education. We must stand up for the women and girls in the conflict who are among the most at risk. When we talk about tradition, tradition, it has nothing to do with religion. Education is an indispensable tool for gender equality and women's empowerment and empowerment. More than 18 million young girls in sub-Saharan Africa do not attend primary school, according to Unesco. We need to change that, work with local agencies, governments, churches.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I fully join my colleagues who have spoken here today. Female genital mutilation is an absolutely barbaric practice, it is indeed a crime. I don't know any justification for any social, cultural norms or customs. It's just a crime, and that's what they have to be called. I feel great shame that this negotiation is also on the rise in the European Union, in our space. We have been talking about this repeatedly since the last period and this is really striking that in the European Area this practice is on the rise. Yes, they are closed communities or communities of newly arrived refugees, but clearly the control component is failing. Those who are supposed to oversee this action from the point of view of criminalising it are closing their eyes. This is not being investigated, I think, a very sad picture of our particular world in the European Union. We should all unequivocally condemn this. First of all, to be on your own doorstep, and at the same time, of course, to devote efforts of persuasion, diplomatic efforts towards our partners in third countries. I think that the European Commission has put forward a good initiative, and I fully support it. It should be linked precisely to diplomatic efforts to convince how to supervise other countries. Millions of women, female circumcises, are really worth our activity, and I thank you for it.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Presidency for their contribution to this debate and to thank all honourable Members for their interventions, which reflect a shared commitment to fight against female genital mutilation. I am emboldened by the fact that we are all together in this. I will take your ideas into account in the development of the new Gender Equality Strategy and throughout my work in the European Commission.  I am grateful for the dedication and support of this Parliament towards this cause and I look forward to continuing with our collaboration. As mentioned by quite a few of the honourable Members here, I hope that the remaining six Member States will ratify the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention requires that the state parties criminalise FGM, including coercion or procurement of this violation.  I will work so that the EU will manage to ratify the Convention during this term, but I count on your support to convince the remaining Member States. We must all keep in mind that women and girls should not be made to wait.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Before I give you the floor, President-in-Office of the Council Tuppurainen: this is your last speech in front of the European Parliament, so I would like to grab the occasion to thank the Finnish Presidency, and especially you, for your efforts for our ever-stronger Europe. Thank you. (Applause)

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, 2020 will be marked by a line-up of important milestones in regard to gender equality, such as: the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action; the 5th anniversary of the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development; the 20th anniversary of the UN Security Council Resolution on Women, Peace and Security; and lastly, the renewal of the EU Strategic Engagement for Gender Equality 2016-2019. In February, we will indeed celebrate the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation (FGM).  Ladies and gentlemen, let’s now put an end to FGM once and for all. All women and girls should be allowed to live free and safe, as whole individuals. In the light of the proposed accession of the EU to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, the Istanbul Convention, the Finnish Presidency calls on all actors to devote special attention to ensuring coherence between internal and external EU policies and action.  Combating all forms of violence against women and young girls is a core element of the respect for human rights and fundamental rights. Our Finnish Presidency has continued working on the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention, and we have encouraged those that still have not ratified the Istanbul Convention to do so. I have no doubt that, among those actors, the European Parliament – you, as representatives – will continue to lead on those issues that are at the heart of our common EU values.  Thank you again for this very important debate, and it this indeed a great honour to conclude the Finnish Presidency with this important topic. President, allow me to thank you all for this extraordinary autumn. It has indeed been a tremendous time with you here in the Parliament, debating all kinds of different topics. I’ve spent hours representing the Council and the Member States in this plenary here in Strasbourg and in Brussels, and it has been worth every minute. Thank you so much. Thank you all. Our Presidency eventually comes to an end, but the fight for human rights, democracy and the rule of law continues. Thank you all, and I wish you all a Merry Christmas. I hope you all can spend some time with your families and your loved ones.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place in plenary on Feb. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – All forms of gender-based violence, no matter in the EU or around the world, are zero-tolerant. I strongly support the Council and Commission’s commitment to combatting gender-based violence, putting it as top priority in the EU Gender Equality Strategy and, in particular, to working collectively to eradicate female genital mutilation (FGM). FGM severely violates the fundamental rights of women and girls worldwide and has serious life-long consequences on women’s health, physically but also psychologically. We must strengthen the data collection at the EU level for mapping women victims in the Member States, enhance supportive measures, in close collaboration with national authorities, health professionals, and civil society, and accelerate the EU’s ratification of the Istanbul Convention. Effective measures on eliminating the barriers of reporting FGM and successful prosecution are also urgently required. At the international level, the EU should be more active in supporting the implementation of CEDAW, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and other international instruments. A long-term strategy for eliminating gender-based discrimination and ensuring long-term sustainable cultural change must be explored.
